Title: Encounter at Farpoint, Part I
Antagonists: Q's trial of humanity
Exploitation of a sentient spaceborne life-form
Summary:
On its first major mission, the new Galaxy-class USS Enterprise-D under Captain Jean-Luc Picard is sent to Farpoint Station, an impossibly advanced outpost offered to the Federation by the Bandi people. En route, the ship is seized by the omnipotent being Q, who transforms the bridge into a brutal courtroom and demands that humanity answer for centuries of barbarism, placing the crew and all of Starfleet symbolically on trial.

Picard negotiates a stay of judgment: Q will allow the Enterprise to continue to Farpoint, but their conduct there will determine whether humanity deserves to continue exploring space. As Picard links up with his new first officer, William Riker, and the senior staff, they begin to suspect that Farpoint’s miraculous comforts hide a disturbing secret.

StorySections.Text: The USS Enterprise-D departs Earth on its shakedown cruise, bound for Farpoint Station on Deneb IV. Before the ship can reach high warp, an immense force field freezes it in space and an enigmatic figure, Q, appears on the bridge, cycling through historical military uniforms as he declares that humanity must be judged for its savage past.

Q hurls the crew into a nightmarish 21st-century courtroom modeled on Earth’s "post-atomic horror," where terrified civilians and soldiers are executed on a whim. Picard, Troi and Data are accused of representing a species too violent to be allowed into the galaxy. Picard insists that humanity has changed and demands the right to defend his people, prompting Q to offer a conditional test tied to the Farpoint mission.

Released but still under scrutiny, Picard separates the saucer section as a precaution and races ahead in the battle section to rendezvous with his first officer, William Riker, already investigating Farpoint. On Deneb IV, Riker has noticed that the station provides anything the Federation team desires almost instantly, while Groppler Zorn gives evasive answers about how it was built. Counselor Troi is overwhelmed by waves of loneliness and pain that seem to emanate from the station itself.

Riker joins the Enterprise and meets the rest of the senior staff, including Dr. Beverly Crusher and her son Wesley, who both have a history with Picard. Picard briefs Riker on Q’s ultimatum and orders the crew to treat every strange occurrence at Farpoint as part of a larger test. As the station continues to grant impossible "wishes" for the away teams, suspicions grow that someone—or something—is being exploited to power Zorn’s bargain-price marvel.

A vast, organic-looking alien vessel of unknown design arrives over Deneb IV and begins a silent standoff with the Enterprise and Farpoint Station. Troi senses a powerful, anguished intelligence linked both to the newcomer and to the structure below. Q appears once more to remind Picard that humanity’s trial has truly begun as the mystery deepens around Farpoint.

Title: Encounter at Farpoint, Part II
Antagonists: Q's ultimatum over humanity's worthiness
Imprisonment and exploitation of a sentient star-jelly life-form
Summary:
With a massive organic starship menacing Deneb IV, Picard and his crew race to uncover the truth behind Farpoint Station before Q condemns humanity once and for all. Evidence mounts that the Bandi did not build Farpoint at all, but instead imprisoned a powerful, shape-shifting spaceborne creature and forced it to serve as their trade hub.

Picard chooses to defy both local politics and Q’s scrutiny by freeing the captive being, even if it means losing a strategic base. The Enterprise’s compassion convinces Q that, for now, humanity deserves to continue its journey—though he warns that the trial is never truly over.

StorySections.Text: The mysterious alien ship in orbit begins firing controlled energy bursts at Farpoint Station, causing damage but pointedly avoiding civilian casualties. Troi is nearly incapacitated by waves of anguish that seem to emanate from both the station and the vessel, while Q observes with predatory interest as Picard struggles to interpret what is happening.

Picard dispatches Riker, Data and La Forge to investigate Farpoint’s sublevels, where they find energy conduits and organic structures completely unlike Bandi technology. Troi confirms that a single suffering consciousness underlies both the station and the alien ship. On the surface, Groppler Zorn refuses to admit the truth, insisting that Farpoint is a legitimate Bandi achievement even as the attacks intensify.

As power fluctuations rattle the station, Picard orders the Enterprise to place itself between the alien vessel and the planet, risking retaliation from both Q and the Bandi government. Clues accumulate that Farpoint and the attacker in orbit are two members of the same species—vast, spacefaring entities capable of altering their form. Q continues to taunt the crew, suggesting that their response will prove whether humanity is truly barbaric or capable of growth.

Picard concludes that the only moral choice is to free the captive creature, even at the cost of Farpoint Station and the Bandi’s favor. Using carefully modulated phaser fire, the Enterprise disrupts the underground power nodes binding the station-entity. Slowly, Farpoint reshapes itself into a second star-jelly being, which rises into the sky and joins its wounded counterpart in orbit.

Reunited, the two entities exchange pulses of light and depart Deneb IV together, leaving the Bandi without their prized facility. Q grudgingly concedes that Picard and his crew acted with compassion and restraint, but warns that the larger trial of humanity continues. With their first crisis resolved, the Enterprise sets course for its next mission, fully aware that they are being watched.

ThematicNotes: Choosing compassion for an alien life-form over political expediency.

The idea that humanity’s progress is judged by how it treats the powerless and strange.
BehindTheScenes: Originally aired with Part I as a two-hour premiere event, later split in syndication.

Title: The Naked Now
Antagonists: Psi-2000-style intoxication virus
Loss of inhibitions aboard a starship in danger
Summary:
Responding to a distress signal from the science vessel SS Tsiolkovsky, the Enterprise finds the ship adrift and its crew dead after a series of bizarre, careless accidents. An away team unknowingly brings back a mutated contagion that acts like extreme intoxication, stripping away inhibitions and judgment across the Enterprise.

As the crew slide into reckless behavior and a nearby star begins to collapse, Wesley seizes partial control of the ship with dangerous "experiments" in engineering. Picard and Dr. Crusher race to identify a cure based on historical records from the original Enterprise, while Data and a temporarily irresponsible Wesley must restore control before the ship is destroyed.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise answers a distress call from the SS Tsiolkovsky, orbiting a star in the final stages of collapse. The science vessel appears intact but unresponsive. When Riker’s away team beams aboard, they find the crew dead amid scenes of strange, frivolous behavior, including a frozen airlock opened during a fully clothed "shower."

Geordi La Forge, exposed to an unseen contaminant on the Tsiolkovsky, begins to act overheated, unfocused, and emotionally unguarded. Dr. Crusher discovers that he is infected with a condition resembling drunkenness, but caused by a complex biochemical reaction in the bloodstream. Soon, other crew members—including engineering staff—begin to show similar symptoms, echoing a recorded incident from Kirk’s Enterprise.

As the infection spreads, Tasha Yar, Troi, and even Data experience lowered inhibitions, leading to impulsive and sometimes intimate interactions that strain normal chain of command. Young Wesley Crusher, also affected, takes over a critical engineering station with a makeshift "tractor beam experiment," unwittingly disabling key controls just as the nearby star’s instability worsens.

With helm and attitude control compromised and the ship drifting toward lethal stellar fragments, Picard struggles to maintain discipline while partially impaired himself. Crusher races to modify the old Enterprise cure to match the mutated Tsiolkovsky strain. Once Data is treated and regains full function, he teams with Wesley to improvise a reversed tractor beam pulse that can nudge the Enterprise out of danger at the last possible moment.

The ship narrowly escapes destruction, and the crew recover from the infection, embarrassed by memories of their uninhibited behavior. Picard orders a careful review of historical incident logs and new safeguards to prevent similar contagions from jeopardizing starships in the future, acknowledging that even the most advanced crew can be undone by flaws exposed under pressure.

Title: Code of Honor
Antagonists: Ligonian power politics
Abduction used as a negotiating tactic
Summary:
The Enterprise visits Ligon II to secure a badly needed vaccine available only from the proud, tradition-bound Ligonians. Their leader, Lutan, is captivated by the idea of a woman serving as chief of security and stages a ceremonial kidnapping of Tasha Yar under the guise of honor.

Picard must navigate a web of archaic customs, property rights, and dueling rituals to retrieve Yar and obtain the vaccine without violating the Prime Directive. By exploiting a loophole in Ligonian law, the crew turns Lutan’s gambit against him, freeing Yar and empowering his wife Yareena to choose her own future.

StorySections.Text: Arriving at Ligon II, the Enterprise opens formal negotiations for a vaccine desperately needed to stop a plague on another Federation world. The Ligonians present themselves as disciplined, honor-driven warriors. During a ceremonial greeting, Lutan becomes fascinated by Tasha Yar’s role as a female security chief.

Under the cover of ritual courtesy, Lutan abruptly abducts Yar using transporter technology, claiming the act is an honorable gesture consistent with Ligonian custom. Picard is furious but must temper his response, as the Federation cannot risk losing access to the vaccine. Troi and Data help him interpret Ligonian behavior, warning that causing Lutan to lose face could jeopardize the entire negotiation.

Lutan declares that he intends to take Yar as a second wife, provoking a challenge from his current wife, Yareena, who invokes the right to single combat. Picard realizes that simply beaming Yar out would violate Ligonian law and likely endanger the vaccine deal. Instead, he allows Yar to train for the duel while Crusher and the medical staff quietly prepare contingency plans.

In an arena filled with Ligonian spectators, Yar and Yareena duel with deadly spiked weapons coated in contact poison. Yar wins, and Yareena collapses, apparently dead. However, Crusher immediately beams the body to the Enterprise, where antitoxins and medical treatment revive her, taking advantage of the legal fiction that she "died" in the arena.

Revived, Yareena exercises her rights under Ligonian tradition to sever her marriage to Lutan and transfer her property—including political influence—to his subordinate Hagon instead. With Lutan humiliated but alive and the vaccine secured via Yareena, the Enterprise leaves Ligon II, the crew uneasy about having had to navigate a culture whose concept of honor masks entrenched inequality.

Title: The Last Outpost
Antagonists: Ferengi piracy and opportunism
Ancient automated defense of the Tkon Empire
Summary:
Pursuing a Ferengi vessel that has stolen a powerful energy converter, the Enterprise is abruptly immobilized along with its quarry above a mysterious planet. Both ships are trapped by an unknown force that drains their power, leaving each side to suspect the other of using a secret weapon.

Away teams discover that the planet is a long-dead outpost of the ancient Tkon Empire, guarded by an automated sentinel called Portal 63. When Ferengi duplicity collides with Portal’s testing of "barbarians," Riker must demonstrate Federation honor and restraint to earn the Enterprise’s release.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise chases a Ferengi raider that has stolen a T9 energy converter from a Federation outpost, eager for its first substantial encounter with the elusive species. Mid-chase, both ships are suddenly frozen in space above an unexplored world in the Gamma Tauri system, and shipwide systems begin to lose power at an alarming rate.

Each crew suspects the other of deploying a new form of energy-draining weapon, and terse hails are exchanged with Daimon Tarr’s Ferengi ship. Sensors reveal that the true source of the interference lies on the planet below. Picard, with time running out, authorizes an away team to beam down and investigate, while engineering fights to stabilize critical systems.

On the surface, Riker, Data, Yar, Worf and La Forge find an arid landscape littered with remnants of advanced technology. They soon encounter Ferengi warriors, who accuse the Enterprise of attacking them and try to seize any advantage. A towering figure materializes—Portal 63, the long-dormant guardian of a fallen empire—who refers to all of them as barbarians trespassing on Tkon territory.

Portal 63 tests both sides, easily neutralizing Ferengi attacks and probing Riker with philosophical questions about loyalty and conquest. While the Ferengi posture and lie to shift blame, Riker speaks honestly about the Federation’s principles and refuses to beg or grovel. Impressed by this, Portal judges the humans worthy and the Ferengi wanting, agreeing to release both ships and deactivate the power-draining field.

Back in orbit, power returns to the Enterprise as Portal and the last vestiges of the Tkon defenses fade away. Daimon Tarr is forced into a grudging retreat, and Picard reflects on a first encounter with the Ferengi that revealed more about their shortcomings than their strength. The Enterprise resumes its mission, having survived an unexpected examination by the ghost of a long-vanished civilization.

Title: Where No One Has Gone Before
Antagonists: Uncontrolled warp-field experiment
Manifestations of thought made real
Summary:
The Enterprise takes on propulsion specialist Kosinski and his enigmatic assistant to test experimental warp-field adjustments. While the arrogant Kosinski boasts that his calculations will dramatically improve engine efficiency, only young Wesley Crusher notices that the quiet alien aide seems to be the true source of the effect.

When a trial run hurls the ship first to the edge of the galaxy and then to a realm where thought shapes reality, Picard and his crew must confront hallucinations drawn from their memories and fears. The Traveler reveals that his species can alter space-time through focused thought and that Wesley possesses similar potential, forcing Picard to recognize the boy’s unique gifts even as they struggle to return home.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives Kosinski and his alien assistant aboard to conduct warp-drive enhancement tests. Chief Engineer Argyle and Riker are skeptical of Kosinski’s vague explanations, while Wesley is fascinated by the quiet, observant Traveler who accompanies him.

Despite Picard’s reservations, Starfleet orders the tests to proceed. Kosinski loudly takes credit as the Enterprise’s warp field is modified. Suddenly, the ship is flung unimaginably far, beyond charted space and even the galaxy itself. Kosinski insists his formula worked as intended, but Data’s analysis suggests that the underlying math is meaningless.

A second attempt to retrace their steps drives the ship into an even stranger region where crew members’ thoughts and memories begin to manifest physically in the corridors. Picard nearly steps off the turbolift into empty space, Worf sees a childhood targ, and Riker encounters figures from his past. Wesley notices that the Traveler reacts visibly each time the ship shifts.

The Traveler collapses under the strain, revealing that he—not Kosinski—is responsible for the jumps, and that the crew’s unfocused thoughts are destabilizing reality. Picard has the crew concentrate on the ship, their sense of self, and home, focusing their minds while the Traveler phases partially out of existence to guide the Enterprise back. Wesley’s intense focus proves especially important.

The Enterprise safely returns to its original sector. Before fading away to continue his journeys, the Traveler tells Picard that Wesley is a rare prodigy who sees beyond normal space and time. Picard quietly resolves to nurture Wesley’s potential, informally taking on the role of mentor as the boy remains aboard ship.

Title: Lonely Among Us
Antagonists: Non-corporeal energy entity
Entrenched hatred between Anticans and Selay
Summary:
While transporting delegations from the warlike Antican and reptilian Selay species to a Federation conference on admission, the Enterprise passes through a mysterious energy cloud. An alien, non-corporeal presence jumps from system to system and person to person aboard the ship, eventually inhabiting Captain Picard himself.

As the Anticans and Selay bicker and scheme, the crew struggles to diagnose the erratic behavior of ship systems and their own commanding officer. Picard, partially merged with the entity, decides to beam himself into the energy cloud to experience its existence fully, leaving Riker and the crew to attempt a risky recovery of his consciousness.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise takes on two delegations—Anticans and Selay—whose mutual hatred threatens to derail Federation talks before they even arrive at the conference world. En route, the ship encounters a strange energy cloud that delivers a brief jolt to the sensors and seemingly passes harmlessly by.

Soon after the encounter, a crewman in a sensor maintenance room is struck by a bolt of energy and collapses. Unexplained malfunctions ripple through ship systems, and Beverly notes signs of neural disruption in the injured officer. Data and La Forge begin tracking anomalies, while tensions rise between the carnivorous Anticans and their prospective Selay "food."

The alien presence jumps from one crew member to another, leaving a trail of confusion and minor sabotage. Eventually, it inhabits Picard, subtly altering his behavior and speech. Troi senses something deeply off about him, but he dismisses her concerns. As the captain begins making odd course changes, Riker and the senior staff worry the entity is steering the ship back to the cloud.

The entity-inhabited Picard admits that joining with the being has opened his mind to new forms of existence and announces his intention to beam into the cloud permanently. Riker challenges his fitness for command but hesitates to mutiny outright. At the last moment, the crew lowers the safety interlocks and allows the transport, hoping to later retrieve him as scattered energy.

With Picard gone, Troi senses his consciousness reaching back toward the ship. The crew modulates the transporter to scoop a portion of the entity-laden cloud and reconstitute the captain’s pattern. Picard returns with limited memory of the experience. Meanwhile, hints of Antican "culinary curiosity" toward the Selay suggest that their ancient hatreds are far from resolved.

Title: Justice
GuestCharacters: God-like space station over Rubicun III
Antagonists: Edo "justice" system with mandatory death penalty
Mysterious godlike entity protecting the colony
Summary:
The Enterprise discovers Rubicun III, home to the Edo, a humanoid species living in seemingly idyllic freedom and pleasure. An away team’s inspection suggests a perfect shore-leave world, and Picard authorizes limited crew recreation on the surface.

The illusion shatters when Wesley Crusher accidentally violates a minor local law by stepping on forbidden flowers and is sentenced to death under Edo custom. As Picard confronts a godlike entity in orbit that claims to protect the Edo’s laws, he must decide whether to respect the Prime Directive or risk destroying a fragile balance to save one teenager.

StorySections.Text: After a grueling assignment establishing a new colony, the Enterprise heads for Rubicun III, which sensors indicate is inhabited and technologically primitive but peaceful. The Edo welcome the away team with exuberant affection, offering a paradise of play, exercise, and casual intimacy.

Picard, wary but intrigued, permits small groups of crew—including Wesley—to beam down for relaxation under supervision. In orbit, the Enterprise detects a massive, mysterious object hovering near the planet, a web-like structure of energy that resists detailed scans. Data is assigned to study it while Riker and Troi monitor the away teams.

On the surface, Wesley joins Edo youths in a game near a flowerbed, accidentally crushing a forbidden patch of plants within an unmarked punishment zone. Edo Mediators immediately declare that he must be executed, explaining that their entire social order depends on a simple, absolute rule: any lawbreaking, no matter how minor, is punished by death.

Picard beams down to confront the Edo authorities, only to have an aspect of the orbiting entity speak through them, warning that Starfleet must not interfere with Edo justice. Back aboard ship, Picard opens a dialogue with the godlike presence, which claims to be both guardian and "god" of the Edo. He wrestles with conflicting obligations: the Prime Directive, his duty to Wesley, and the larger ethical implications of a system built on terror of minor infractions.

Ultimately, Picard decides he cannot surrender Wesley, arguing that blindly obeying such a law would betray the Federation’s core principles. The entity allows the Enterprise to depart, apparently satisfied that Picard’s moral reasoning has merit. Rubicun III remains under the protection of its "god," while the crew leaves with a renewed awareness of the limits of cultural relativism.

Title: The Battle
Antagonists: Daimon Bok's revenge plot
Near-fatal neuroscan transmission from the Stargazer
Summary:
The Enterprise meets a Ferengi vessel under unexpectedly cordial circumstances when Daimon Bok announces that he wishes to present Picard with a gift: the USS Stargazer, Picard’s old ship, long thought lost after a battle with a Ferengi raider. While the Federation sees the gesture as a possible peace overture, Bok uses the encounter to exact revenge.

Aboard the Stargazer, Picard begins suffering intense headaches and vivid flashbacks to the "Battle of Maxia," the fight where he ordered a daring maneuver that destroyed a Ferengi ship. The crew discovers that Bok has planted a device that remotely stimulates Picard’s brain, forcing him to relive the battle and attempt to attack the Enterprise as if it were his old enemy.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise responds to unusual Ferengi communications and discovers the derelict USS Stargazer being towed by a Ferengi ship. Daimon Bok hails Picard, claiming he is returning the captain’s former command as a gesture of goodwill. Picard, visibly moved, orders an away team to secure the aging vessel.

Picard tours the Stargazer and is flooded with memories of the battle in which he was forced to abandon it. He experiences a sudden headache but dismisses it as nostalgia. Riker and Troi remain suspicious of Bok’s motives, and Worf notes unusual power readings from the Ferengi ship.

As Picard brings the Stargazer’s logs aboard the Enterprise, he begins to suffer blackouts and increasingly intense flashbacks. He re-enacts tactical orders as if he were back at the Battle of Maxia. Beverly struggles to explain the neurological symptoms, while Data and Riker search the records to clarify what truly happened in the engagement.

Bok reveals his plan: the Ferengi ship destroyed at Maxia was commanded by his son, and he has implanted a device aboard the Stargazer to project a neuroscan into Picard’s brain. Under its influence, Picard returns to the Stargazer, powers it up, and reenacts his famous maneuver—this time targeting the Enterprise as if it were the enemy.

Riker pieces together the pattern and orders the Enterprise to mimic Picard’s old "Picard Maneuver" to track the Stargazer’s position. Data locates the neuroscan device and destroys it remotely, freeing Picard’s mind in time for him to abort the attack. Bok’s unauthorized vendetta leads to his removal from command by his own crew, and the Stargazer is formally reclaimed by Starfleet.

Title: Hide and Q
Antagonists: Q's temptation of Riker with godlike power
Abuse of omnipotence as a "test"
Summary:
En route to aid a colony in distress, the Enterprise is once again intercepted by Q, who freezes the ship and whisks Riker and an away team into a bizarre "game" on an alien world. There, Q appears in a Napoleonic uniform and pits them against grotesque animal-headed soldiers, claiming that the Q Continuum is considering elevating Riker to their ranks.

Riker soon discovers that he has been granted Q-like powers, including the ability to alter reality and resurrect the dead. When he returns to the Enterprise with these abilities intact, Q urges him to use them to grant his friends’ deepest wishes. Picard and the crew must help Riker see the dangers of playing god before Q’s test tears them apart.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise races toward a disaster-struck colony when Q appears on the bridge and immobilizes the ship. He declares that he has a new test in mind and, with a snap, transports Riker, Worf, Yar, and Data to a desert-like world dressed in period military uniforms.

On the planet, Q explains that the Q Continuum is impressed by humanity’s potential and is considering offering Riker a place among them. He unleashes bizarre soldiers with animal heads to attack the away team, turning the scenario into a deadly war-game. Back on the Enterprise, Picard demands that Q stop endangering his people.

When Yar is mortally wounded in the game, Riker is suddenly infused with Q powers and instinctively wishes her back to life. Q reveals that Riker now possesses a measure of omnipotence. He returns the away team to the ship, where Picard is alarmed by the implications of a human wielding Q-level abilities.

Q tempts Riker to demonstrate his newfound powers by granting his friends’ unspoken desires: turning Wesley into an adult, giving Geordi normal vision, making Worf a heroic Klingon leader, and offering Data true humanity. One by one, they refuse, uncomfortable with being transformed by an unearned shortcut.

Realizing that accepting Q’s offer would isolate him from his humanity and his crewmates, Riker rejects the power and returns everything to normal. Q, apparently having lost a wager with the Continuum about human temptation, is yanked away in a flash of light. The Enterprise resumes its mission, with Picard quietly pleased that his first officer passed the test.

Title: Haven
Antagonists: Arranged marriage tradition clashing with personal choice
Threat of an approaching Tarellian plague ship
Summary:
The Enterprise visits the resort world Haven for shore leave, but Deanna Troi’s plans are upended when a ceremonial gift announces the arrival of her mother, Lwaxana Troi, along with the Miller family. Deanna learns that a long-ago arrangement between the Troi and Miller families has been activated: she is expected to wed Wyatt Miller, a man she has never met in person. Riker, who has romantic feelings for Deanna, struggles with the prospect of losing her to an arranged marriage.

As wedding preparations and family clashes unfold aboard ship, an unidentified vessel approaches Haven and is revealed to be a Tarellian ship carrying survivors of a deadly plague. Fearing infection, Haven’s government wants the ship destroyed. Wyatt, who has been sketching the face of a mysterious woman since childhood, recognizes her as a Tarellian aboard the vessel and must choose between his planned life with Deanna and answering an unexpected calling among the doomed refugees.

StorySections.Text: Orbiting the idyllic world of Haven, the Enterprise crew anticipates shore leave when a jeweled box beams aboard and speaks, announcing that Deanna Troi’s long-arranged marriage contract is being honored. Deanna reluctantly confirms that her mother and the Miller family are on their way.

Lwaxana Troi arrives in flamboyant fashion, immediately clashing with the more reserved Millers and embarrassing Deanna with her telepathic commentary. Wyatt Miller turns out to be kind and open-minded, but Riker’s discomfort is obvious as he confronts the possibility of losing Troi. Meanwhile, Haven’s leaders warn Picard of a mysterious ship heading toward the planet.

The approaching vessel is identified as Tarellian, carrying survivors of a world-devastating plague that once threatened to spread across the quadrant. Haven, terrified of infection, pressures Picard to destroy the ship if necessary. Wyatt confides that he has experienced visions of an unknown woman’s face for years and is stunned when he sees her image among the Tarellians.

As the wedding ceremony nears, tensions rise between Lwaxana and the Millers over Betazoid and human traditions. Wyatt realizes that the woman in his dreams, a Tarellian named Ardra, believes he is destined to help her people. He concludes that his true path lies with the plague ship rather than a marriage born of obligation.

Wyatt beams to the Tarellian vessel with medical supplies, accepting the risk of infection to try to ease their suffering. The Tarellians agree to leave the system peacefully. The broken engagement leaves Deanna free but emotionally drained, while Riker and Picard reflect on the complicated interplay of duty, love, and destiny. Lwaxana departs, promising she will return.

Title: The Big Goodbye
Antagonists: Holodeck malfunction
Cyrus Redblock's criminal ambitions
Summary:
Preparing for a delicate greeting with insectoid Jaradan representatives that requires flawless recitation of their language, Picard seeks relaxation by entering the holodeck as Dixon Hill, a 1940s-style private detective. Beverly Crusher and Data join him in the stylized simulation of San Francisco noir, complete with gangsters, corrupt cops, and smoky offices.

When the ship is scanned by the Jaradans, the resulting power surge causes the holodeck’s safeties to fail. Suddenly, bruises, bullets, and death inside the program become real. Trapped with no easy exit, Picard must navigate a film-noir kidnapping plot and face down crime boss Cyrus Redblock while the crew outside struggles to repair the malfunction in time for the critical Jaradan ceremony.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise prepares to host the exacting Jaradan, whose culture demands a precise, ritual greeting. Nervous about memorizing the difficult phrases, Picard decides to unwind on the holodeck by stepping into a Dixon Hill detective novel.

Picard immerses himself in Dixon Hill’s world, complete with period clothes and slang. Data and Beverly enthusiastically join the program, amused by the novelty of 20th-century noir. Outside, a Jaradan scan interacts unpredictably with the holodeck’s systems.

Inside the simulation, Picard and his companions are questioned by police and threatened by criminals, including the imposing Cyrus Redblock. A holodeck character is shot, and the blood and trauma prove disturbingly real. On the Enterprise, La Forge and Wesley discover that safety protocols have failed and that shutting down the system might trap the captain inside permanently.

As the Jaradan grow impatient for their formal greeting, Riker urges the engineering team to find a solution. Within the noir scenario, Picard realizes that Redblock’s criminal ambitions are constrained by the holodeck’s fictional limits. He bluffs and negotiates, trying to buy enough time for the crew to restore normal control.

The crew manages a partial reset, opening the holodeck doors just as Redblock attempts to step into what he thinks is the "real" world—only to disintegrate beyond the projection’s boundary. Picard and the others escape, and he quickly delivers the Jaradan greeting perfectly. Afterward, he reflects on the bittersweet existence of holodeck characters, who vanish when the program ends.

Title: Datalore
Antagonists: Lore's duplicity and jealousy
Crystalline Entity's planetary-scale destruction
Summary:
The Enterprise visits Omicron Theta, the colony where Data was discovered years earlier, and finds it eerily lifeless. An away team discovers a hidden underground complex created by the cyberneticist Dr. Noonian Soong, along with disassembled parts of another android identical in appearance to Data. The crew reassembles and activates the second android, who calls himself Lore.

Though initially charming and more "human" in demeanor than Data, Lore harbors resentment and a history of betrayal: he helped attract a spaceborne Crystalline Entity that destroyed the colony. Determined to prove his superiority, Lore plots to repeat the massacre using the Enterprise as bait, forcing Data and the crew—particularly Wesley—to see through his impersonation before it is too late.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at Omicron Theta, prepared to survey the world where Data was found. The planet appears empty, with no signs of the once-thriving colony. An away team discovers an underground lab that bears Dr. Soong’s name and contains Data-like components in storage.

The crew assembles the second android and activates him. Lore greets them with humor and fluid speech, contrasting with Data’s more formal manner. He claims he was disassembled because the colonists feared him, and he appears eager to fit in aboard the Enterprise, though Wesley is wary.

Lore subtly mocks Data and flatters the rest of the crew while secretly contacting the Crystalline Entity, the same being that annihilated Omicron Theta. He reveals that he once collaborated with it, luring victims for it to consume. Lore knocks out Data and swaps uniforms, planning to impersonate him.

Posing as Data, Lore attempts to guide the Crystalline Entity to the Enterprise, promising it a feast. Wesley realizes that "Data" is behaving out of character, but the adults initially dismiss his concerns. In engineering, Lore’s deception unravels as he tries to sabotage the ship’s defenses.

Data recovers and confronts Lore, and with help from Wesley and Worf, manages to beam Lore into space instead of allowing him to control the ship. The Crystalline Entity withdraws, its connection to the Enterprise severed. The crew reflects on Data’s unsettling "brother" and the unresolved threat the Entity still poses.

Title: Angel One
Antagonists: Matriarchal authoritarian regime on Angel One
Airborne virus aboard the Enterprise
Summary:
The Enterprise travels to the planet Angel One to search for survivors of a long-lost Federation freighter. The world is ruled by a female-dominated oligarchy that treats men as second-class citizens. Riker, Troi, Yar, and Data beam down to negotiate with Beata, the planet’s leader, who is suspicious of Starfleet’s presence.

The away team discovers that the male survivors of the freighter have integrated into Angel One’s society and are leading a movement for greater equality. Beata considers them dangerous subversives and demands their extradition or execution. Meanwhile, an airborne virus spreads through the Enterprise’s crew, reducing the ship’s ability to intervene as Picard and Crusher race to find a cure.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise traces the signal of a missing Federation freighter, the Odin, to Angel One, a planet with limited technological development but confirmed humanoid life. Initial contact reveals a matriarchal culture where male visitors are viewed with curiosity and caution.

Riker leads an away team to meet Beata, the Elected One of Angel One, while Troi and Yar observe the power dynamics among her council. Beata confirms that survivors from the Odin arrived years earlier but is evasive about their fate. Above, Wesley returns from a skiing trip with a cold-like illness that begins to spread.

The away team locates the Odin survivors, led by Ramsey, who refuse to leave their families or abandon their push for social change. Beata views them as agitators undermining the traditional order. On the Enterprise, the virus spreads through the crew, incapacitating key personnel and threatening the ship’s ability to respond to a separate distress call.

Beata orders the execution of Ramsey and his followers as an example. Riker argues for leniency and warns that state violence will only turn them into martyrs. With the Enterprise’s condition deteriorating, Picard must respect Angel One’s sovereignty while quietly encouraging Beata to consider a less brutal path.

Beata commutes the executions to exile, acknowledging that social change on Angel One may be inevitable, though she intends to slow it. Crusher finds a treatment for the virus just in time for the Enterprise to resume its wider duties. Riker reflects on the slow, uneven nature of progress in entrenched societies.

Antagonists: Bynars' covert hijacking of the Enterprise
Imminent failure of Bynar homeworld computer core
Summary:
The Enterprise docks at Starbase 74 for a major computer refit overseen by the Bynars, a pair-bonded alien species who live symbiotically with their planetary computer network. While the Bynars quietly alter the ship’s systems, Picard and Riker are drawn into an exceptionally sophisticated holodeck program featuring Minuet, a strikingly self-aware simulation.

During the refit, the Enterprise suddenly departs the starbase on its own, with almost the entire crew evacuated. Riker and Picard, still on the holodeck, at first remain unaware. They eventually discover that the Bynars have commandeered the ship to save the data core of their homeworld after a supernova-induced power failure—hoping that the Enterprise’s main computer can serve as a backup to preserve their civilization.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at Starbase 74 for routine maintenance. A team of Bynars, who always work in inseparable pairs and communicate in rapid binary, comes aboard to upgrade the computer systems.

While the crew takes shore leave, Riker explores a new holodeck jazz club program and meets Minuet, whose charm and responsiveness exceed any simulation he has experienced. Picard joins him and is equally impressed by her apparent depth. Meanwhile, the Bynars quietly reconfigure key ship functions.

Without warning, the Enterprise goes to red alert and separates from the starbase with only a handful of people left aboard. Most of the crew has been evacuated under false pretenses. Riker and Picard, engrossed in conversation with Minuet, remain on the holodeck as the ship heads toward the Bynar home system.

Realizing something is wrong, Picard and Riker leave the holodeck and find the ship seemingly deserted. They trace the anomaly to the main computer core, where Bynars are attempting to upload a massive data stream. The aliens collapse from exhaustion as they struggle to restore their world’s central computer.

Picard and Riker complete the upload, saving the Bynar civilization. The Bynars explain that they did not ask for help directly because they feared Starfleet would refuse such a risky plan. Back on the holodeck, Riker discovers that Minuet has reverted to an ordinary program now that the Bynars’ modifications are gone, leaving him with a sense of real loss for a relationship that never truly existed.

Title: Too Short a Season
Antagonists: Admiral Jameson's unethical past arms deal
Karnas's revenge-driven hostage crisis
Summary:
The Enterprise is ordered to transport elderly Admiral Mark Jameson to the planet Mordan IV to negotiate the release of hostages seized by its ruler, Karnas. Decades earlier, Jameson brokered a peace there by secretly supplying weapons to both sides of a civil war. Karnas now insists that only Jameson can resolve the crisis.

En route, Jameson rapidly begins to grow younger, having taken an illegal rejuvenation drug to regain his strength for the mission. As his physical vigor returns, buried guilt over his past actions emerges. On Mordan IV, Karnas reveals that the hostage situation is a ruse designed to force Jameson to answer for the devastation his double-dealing once caused.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives urgent orders to proceed to Mordan IV, where terrorists have taken Federation hostages. Karnas, the planet’s leader, demands Admiral Mark Jameson as the negotiator.

Admiral Jameson boards the Enterprise in a wheelchair, frail but determined. He insists that his prior experience with Karnas uniquely qualifies him to defuse the crisis. Picard is wary of Jameson’s secrecy about his past dealings on Mordan.

Jameson’s health appears to improve dramatically, and he begins to de-age physically. He admits to his wife Anne and later to Picard that he took a banned anti-aging drug, and that years ago he supplied arms to both sides of Mordan’s conflict, believing it would force a quick resolution.

On the surface, Karnas reveals that there are no terrorists—only his plan to force Jameson to face responsibility for the long war that followed the arms shipments. Picard attempts to mediate as Jameson, now appearing much younger but suffering from instability, confesses his actions.

Jameson collapses from the strain of the rejuvenation process and dies before a formal reckoning can occur. Karnas, partially satisfied by the admiral’s admission of guilt, releases the hostages. Picard reflects on the dangers of trying to rewrite both age and history.

Title: When the Bough Breaks
Antagonists: Aldeans' child abductions
Radiation-induced sterility threatening Aldea
Summary:
The legendary world of Aldea, long thought mythical, reveals itself to the Enterprise and invites contact. The Aldeans are a reclusive, highly advanced people whose civilization is in decline due to widespread sterility. Desperate to preserve their culture, they abduct several Enterprise children—including Wesley Crusher—to raise as their own.

Picard and the crew must negotiate for the children’s return while investigating the true cause of Aldea’s sterility, which turns out to be harmful radiation from a planetary shielding system. As the children begin to bond with their assigned Aldean "parents," Wesley organizes a peaceful resistance, refusing to accept a future stolen from their real families.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise follows a faint signal to what sensors suggest might be the legendary lost world of Aldea. The planet suddenly appears, having been cloaked by powerful shielding technology, and its inhabitants invite the Enterprise to orbit.

Aldean representatives, led by Radue, beam aboard and praise the Enterprise children, offering technological gifts in exchange for a few of them. Picard refuses, stating that children are not commodities. Shortly thereafter, several children—Wesley among them—are abducted directly from the ship.

On Aldea, each child is assigned to adult caretakers and offered comfort, attention, and opportunities to develop specific talents. Wesley, recognized as a natural leader, quickly organizes the other children to resist cooperating fully, insisting they not forget their real parents.

Picard, Crusher, and Data investigate Aldean technology and discover that the planetary shielding system is emitting harmful radiation that has caused generations of sterility and genetic damage. The Aldeans have relied on their "Custodian" computer so completely that they no longer understand the consequences of their own shield.

Confronted with the truth, Radue agrees to return the children and accept help in shutting down the shield, even though it will change Aldean life forever. The Enterprise departs with its young crew members safely aboard, Picard reaffirming that children cannot simply be taken to fix another society’s mistakes.

Title: Home Soil
Antagonists: Microscopic inorganic life-form ('microbrain')
Terraforming project threatening an existing ecosystem
Summary:
The Enterprise visits a Federation terraforming station on Velara III, where a team led by Director Kurt Mandl is transforming a harsh world into a more habitable one. Shortly after the away team arrives, a technician is killed by an apparently malfunctioning energy beam, raising questions about sabotage or negligence.

Data discovers a strange crystalline substance in a drilling site that reacts to light and appears to be organizing itself. The sample soon reveals itself to be part of a collective, microscopic inorganic intelligence that calls the terraformers "ugly bags of mostly water" and accuses them of attacking its home. Picard must decide whether to halt the terraforming project altogether in order to respect a form of life no one suspected existed.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at Velara III to inspect an ambitious terraforming effort. Mandl proudly showcases the project, but Troi senses that he is concealing something.

While touring the hydraulics chamber, the away team witnesses a deadly accident as a laser drill activates unexpectedly and kills a technician. Data notes irregularities in the control systems, and Picard orders a formal investigation.

Data collects a sample of sparkling crystalline material from the subsurface. Aboard the Enterprise, the sample responds to light and begins to change, emitting tones and increasing in complexity. The crew realizes it is not just reacting, but communicating.

The crystalline entity, amplified and translated by the ship’s computers, identifies itself as a collective intelligence enraged by the drilling. It declares that the terraformers are destroying its home. Picard confronts Mandl with the evidence that his "dead" world is in fact inhabited.

Picard orders all work on Velara III halted and returns the sample to the planet’s surface, allowing the "microbrain" to rejoin its fellows. He sends a report to Starfleet recommending the world be off-limits to further interference, acknowledging the discovery of a new form of life.

Title: Coming of Age
Antagonists: Starfleet internal investigation of the Enterprise crew
Pressure and competition of the Starfleet Academy entrance exam
Summary:
Wesley Crusher travels to Relva VII to take the Starfleet Academy entrance exam, facing intense psychological and practical tests alongside other gifted candidates. He befriends the Benzite applicant Mordock and grapples with self-doubt as the exam forces him to confront his deepest fears.

Meanwhile, on the Enterprise, Admiral Gregory Quinn dispatches Lt. Commander Dexter Remmick to conduct an exhaustive investigation into Picard and his command crew. Remmick’s intrusive questions and combative style unsettle the officers, but Quinn hints that larger concerns within Starfleet Command are driving the scrutiny.

StorySections.Text: Picard informs Wesley that he has been accepted to test for the Starfleet Academy entrance on Relva VII. At the same time, the Enterprise receives word that an admiral and investigator are coming aboard for an unspecified review.

On Relva VII, Wesley meets fellow candidates including the nervous Benzite Mordock. They learn that only one of them will be admitted this year. Aboard the Enterprise, Remmick begins aggressively questioning the senior staff about past incidents, looking for evidence of misconduct.

Wesley endures written exams, simulations, and a psychological test that forces him to relive his guilt over failing to save a Starfleet officer in a previous emergency. Remmick continues his probe, frustrating Riker, Data, and others with insinuations that something is fundamentally wrong with Picard’s command.

Wesley performs well but hesitates at a crucial moment to assist a rival, demonstrating character but losing the top score. On the Enterprise, Remmick concludes that Picard and his crew are exemplary, to Quinn’s satisfaction. Quinn privately warns Picard that something is amiss at Starfleet Command and may soon require his help.

Mordock is chosen for the Academy slot, and Wesley is disappointed but accepts the result, resolved to try again. Picard reassures him that failure is part of growth. The Enterprise departs Relva VII with a hint of larger conspiracies brewing within Starfleet.

Summary:
Responding to a distress call from a damaged freighter in the Neutral Zone, the Enterprise rescues several survivors, including three Klingons: Korris, Konmel, and a mortally wounded comrade. As Worf tends to his injured kin, he learns that Korris and Konmel reject the current Klingon–Federation peace and yearn for a return to the old warrior ways.

The rescued Klingons attempt to commandeer the Enterprise’s battle section to start a new war and carve out a realm based on their strict code of glory. Worf is torn between loyalty to Starfleet and sympathy for their ideals, ultimately confronting Korris in a tense showdown that crystallizes his own path as a Klingon in Starfleet.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise answers a distress call from a Talarian freighter near the Neutral Zone. Geordi uses a VISOR-linked visual feed to guide an away team through the damaged ship’s interior.

The away team discovers three Klingon survivors. One dies of his injuries after a traditional death-cry, while Korris and Konmel are transported to sickbay. Worf feels a powerful kinship with the strangers, intrigued by their strong embrace of Klingon warrior culture.

As Korris regains strength, he speaks to Worf about the "softening" of the Klingon Empire, criticizing the peace with the Federation. He probes Worf’s sense of identity, suggesting that Starfleet service is unworthy of a true Klingon warrior. Suspicious incidents hint that Korris and Konmel are not simply victims.

Captain K'Nera of a Klingon ship arrives, revealing that Korris and his companions are renegades responsible for attacks meant to destabilize peace. Korris and Konmel seize weapons and attempt to reach the battle bridge to take control of the Enterprise. Worf follows, trying one last time to persuade them to stand down.

In a final confrontation overlooking the warp core, Worf refuses to join Korris’s crusade and is forced to shoot him to prevent the ship’s destruction. K'Nera offers Worf a place in the Klingon military, but Worf declines, choosing to remain with Starfleet. The episode ends with Worf more certain of his path between two worlds.

Title: The Arsenal of Freedom
Antagonists: Adaptive automated weapons system of Minos
Uncontrolled arms sales technology
Summary:
The Enterprise investigates the disappearance of the USS Drake near Minos, a planet once famed for selling advanced weapons to all sides of regional conflicts. Upon arrival, an automated holographic salesman proudly touts Minos’s "arsenal of freedom" while inviting the visitors to demonstrate its wares.

An away team beams down and is soon attacked by invisible, self-upgrading drones. Picard and Crusher are trapped below the surface after a collapse, while Riker is immobilized in a stasis field and Geordi is left in command in orbit, facing similar weapons attacking the Enterprise. To survive, the crew must outthink a system designed to escalate lethality until its customers—and creators—are destroyed.

StorySections.Text: Responding to the disappearance of the USS Drake, the Enterprise arrives at Minos. A prerecorded holographic salesman appears on the surface, cheerfully offering demonstrations of the planet’s legendary weapon systems.

Riker leads an away team with Data and Yar to the planet. The salesman continues his pitch, insisting that Minos’s automated weapons can adapt to any threat. Suddenly, an invisible drone attacks, and Riker is encased in a stasis field while the others scramble for cover.

Picard and Crusher beam down to assist and investigate, but an underground access structure collapses, injuring Crusher and trapping both of them below the surface. On the Enterprise, Geordi assumes command as more advanced drones begin testing the ship’s defenses, each new model tougher than the last.

Picard and the injured Crusher discover the control center that once oversaw Minos’s arsenal, learning that the planet’s people were likely wiped out by their own creations. On the surface, Data and Yar struggle to disable the increasingly sophisticated drones that view the crew as customers to impress and targets to destroy.

Realizing that the sales program will only stop when a purchase is made, Picard uses the control system to "order" the full arsenal and then immediately commands it to shut down. The drones deactivate on the planet and in orbit, saving the Enterprise and the away team. The ship departs, leaving Minos as a stark warning about the dangers of autonomous weapons.

Title: Symbiosis
Antagonists: Ornaran colony's dependence on 'medicine'
Brekkan exploitation via narcotic felicium
Summary:
The Enterprise rescues two pairs of survivors from a doomed freighter: the freighter's Ornaran crew and their Brekkan passengers guarding valuable cargo. The Brekkans insist that the cargo—containers of "medicine" called felicium—is essential to treat a terminal plague afflicting the Ornarans. Tensions quickly arise over who owns the shipment and how it should be used.

Dr. Crusher discovers that the supposed medicine is actually a narcotic that has left the Ornarans physiologically addicted for generations. The Brekkans, whose own economy depends on manufacturing felicium, have been knowingly exploiting the Ornarans’ dependence. Picard must decide how far he can go to break the cycle without openly violating the Prime Directive.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise responds to a distress signal from a freighter in electrical storm-tossed space. Despite their best efforts, the ship is lost, but two Ornarans and two Brekkans are beamed aboard at the last second along with their cargo.

The rescued survivors immediately argue over the felicium containers, with the Brekkans claiming trade agreements and the Ornarans pleading that their people will die without the drug. Picard orders the cargo secured while he sorts out the conflicting stories.

Dr. Crusher’s analysis reveals that felicium is not curing a disease but sustaining a physiological addiction introduced centuries earlier. The Ornarans’ symptoms when deprived are withdrawal, not illness. Crusher urges Picard to expose the deception and end the exploitation directly.

Bound by the Prime Directive, Picard refuses to overtly interfere in the trade relationship. However, he also declines to repair the Ornarans’ freighters, knowing that their inability to travel will eventually sever the felicium supply.

As the Brekkans and Ornarans depart, unaware of the long-term implications, Picard and Crusher reflect on the painful path the Ornarans will face as they go through withdrawal and rebuild their society. Wesley asks about drugs and addiction, leading to a frank conversation with Tasha Yar about the dangers of chemical dependency.

Title: Skin of Evil
Antagonists: Armus, tar-like entity of concentrated evil
Malicious nihilism directed at the crew
Summary:
Responding to a distress call from a shuttle carrying Counselor Troi, the Enterprise finds it crashed on the surface of an otherwise desolate world. An away team encounters Armus, a sentient, tar-like being that exudes hatred and sadistic pleasure. When Tasha Yar attempts to move past it to reach the shuttle, Armus casually kills her with a blast of energy.

While Troi and another survivor remain trapped in the wreckage, forced to psychologically engage with Armus, Picard and the crew struggle to negotiate with a creature that delights in suffering. Ultimately, they must outlast Armus’s tantrums and retrieve their people, then face the shock and grief of losing their chief of security.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives a distress call from a shuttle carrying Counselor Troi and a pilot. The shuttle has crashed on Vagra II, a barren planet with no apparent life.

An away team beams down and discovers a pool of black, viscous substance that moves and speaks—Armus. When Tasha attempts to walk around it to reach the shuttle, Armus lashes out and kills her instantly. Crusher and the others are unable to revive her.

Troi, trapped inside the wrecked shuttle with the injured pilot, confronts Armus through a breach in the hull. Armus reveals that it was created when a highly advanced race purged themselves of their negative emotions, leaving their "skin of evil" behind.

Armus toys with successive away teams, immobilizing and tormenting them to feed its rage. Picard beams down himself, realizing that engaging Armus’s demands only strengthens its power. Instead, he refuses to play along, depriving Armus of the reactions it craves.

With Armus weakened by lack of emotional nourishment, the crew seizes the opportunity to beam Troi and the pilot to safety, then leaves the entity marooned and isolated. Back on the Enterprise, the crew holds a holodeck memorial service where Yar’s recorded message offers each of them a personal farewell.

Title: We'll Always Have Paris
Antagonists: Temporal instability from Manheim's experiments
Personal regret over a love left behind
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a distress call from Dr. Paul Manheim, a brilliant but controversial physicist whose experiments with non-linear time have triggered temporal disturbances across a sector of space. As the crew experiences déjà vu-like time loops and overlapping realities, Picard learns that Manheim’s wife, Jenice, is the woman he once loved and left in Paris years earlier.

While Data works to stabilize the temporal rift threatening to tear the station apart, Picard is forced to confront unresolved feelings and the path not taken with Jenice. In the end, he must step through a moment of duplicated time to shut down Manheim’s dangerous equipment, accepting that some choices cannot be unmade.

StorySections.Text: Aboard the Enterprise, the crew experiences a strange temporal hiccup in which a few seconds repeat. Shortly thereafter, a distress call arrives from Dr. Manheim’s research station, reporting catastrophic time experiments.
The Enterprise arrives at the station to find it heavily damaged and Manheim gravely injured. Among the survivors is Jenice, Picard’s former lover, bringing his past abruptly into the present.

Temporal disturbances intensify, causing multiple versions of the crew to appear briefly in the same space. Manheim, slipping in and out of consciousness, describes his attempt to open a pathway to other dimensions of time.

Data volunteers to enter the core chamber, where a time-split environment produces three simultaneous versions of him. Guided by Picard from the bridge, Data must determine which moment to act in to destabilize the experiment safely.

With the experiment shut down and Manheim stabilizing, Picard and Jenice share a bittersweet farewell in the holodeck recreation of a Parisian café. They acknowledge that their lives have diverged and that some missed chances must remain in the past.

Title: Conspiracy
Antagonists: Parasitic aliens infiltrating Starfleet command
Mother creature controlling infected officers
Summary:
Picard receives a clandestine message from his old friend Captain Walker Keel, who warns that something is wrong at the highest levels of Starfleet. Keel and others suspect a conspiracy but have no proof. Shortly afterward, Keel’s ship is destroyed under mysterious circumstances, deepening Picard’s concern.

Returning to Earth, Picard and Riker find several admirals behaving strangely, including Gregory Quinn and those overseeing operations from Starfleet Headquarters. They discover that alien, crab-like parasites have taken over key officers by attaching to their brains and spreading through a central "mother" creature inside Dexter Remmick. In a violent confrontation, they must destroy the mother organism, sending a final, chilling signal into deep space.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise rendezvous with the Horatio, commanded by Picard’s friend Walker Keel. In a tense, private meeting, Keel hints at a hidden threat within Starfleet and urges Picard to trust no one.

Picard attempts to verify Keel’s suspicions by cross-checking ship assignments and personnel changes, finding disturbing irregularities. Before they can meet again, the Horatio explodes during a routine rendezvous.

Summoned to Earth, Picard and Riker encounter Admiral Quinn, who displays unnatural strength when he attacks Riker while under the influence of a parasite. Crusher identifies a small, worm-like creature attached to Quinn’s spine.

At Starfleet Headquarters, Picard and Riker attend a formal dinner with Admirals Aaron and Savar and Captain Tryla Scott, all of whom appear disturbingly calm about bizarre menu items. They uncover that the officers are hosts to parasites that control their actions.

Tracking the signal that coordinates the parasites, Picard and Riker confront Dexter Remmick, whose body hosts the central mother creature. They destroy it with phasers, revealing a beacon transmission heading into deep space. The Enterprise departs, knowing the threat may not be over.

Title: The Neutral Zone
Antagonists: Romulan probing of Federation border
Mysterious force destroying Federation and Romulan outposts
Summary:
Returning from negotiations with the Romulans, the Enterprise diverts to investigate the destruction of several Federation outposts along the Neutral Zone. En route, the crew discovers an ancient Earth satellite containing three cryogenically frozen humans from the late 20th century. They are revived, struggling to adapt to a future that has moved beyond the economic and social structures they knew.

At the border, Picard learns that Romulan outposts have also been obliterated by an unknown force. Confronted by a Romulan warbird under Commander Tebok, Picard must manage both the revived 20th-century humans’ anxieties and a tense standoff. Federation and Romulan commanders reluctantly acknowledge a common, unseen threat and agree to monitor the situation—foreshadowing a powerful enemy yet to be revealed.

StorySections.Text: Data and Worf investigate a drifting 20th-century Earth vessel and find a small group of cryogenically preserved humans. On Picard’s orders, they bring the stasis chambers aboard for study.

Dr. Crusher revives Claire Raymond, Ralph Offenhouse, and "Sonny" Clemonds, each reacting differently to the shock of awakening in the 24th century. Picard is initially irritated at the distraction from urgent matters in the Neutral Zone.

As Troi and others help the revived humans adjust, the Enterprise begins surveying destroyed Federation outposts that show no survivors and no debris from attackers, only scooped-away sections of space stations.

A Romulan warbird decloaks. Commander Tebok and his officer declare that Romulan outposts have suffered the same fate and that the Romulan Star Empire has returned to active engagement after long isolation.

Picard and Tebok agree that neither side is responsible for the attacks and that an unknown power is at work along their shared border. Offenhouse, finally beginning to grasp the new era’s values, helps relay this strategic insight. The Enterprise departs, aware that a new and formidable adversary may soon emerge.

Summary:
As the Enterprise prepares to transport dangerous plasma plague samples to a remote medical facility, shipboard life adjusts to several changes: Dr. Katherine Pulaski joins as the new chief medical officer, and Ten Forward opens under the watchful eye of Guinan. Amid these transitions, Counselor Deanna Troi is unexpectedly impregnated by a mysterious glowing presence that enters her quarters while she sleeps.

Troi decides to carry the rapidly developing child to term, despite concerns from her shipmates. Her son, Ian Andrew Troi, is born within hours and ages at an extraordinary rate. As the plague samples are prepared for transfer, strange anomalies in the containment systems suggest that Ian’s presence is directly linked to the hazards threatening the mission. When he realizes he is endangering the ship, Ian chooses to die and revert to his original noncorporeal form, explaining telepathically that he came only to experience life among the crew.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise embarks on a mission to transport volatile plasma plague samples while new personnel and facilities come online. A glowing energy presence slips unseen into Troi’s quarters as she sleeps.

Troi discovers she is pregnant without any conventional explanation, and the embryo is developing at an unprecedented rate. Picard convenes a senior staff meeting where Pulaski, Worf, and others debate the risks, but Troi insists the decision is hers and chooses to continue the pregnancy.

Within hours, Troi gives birth to a boy she names Ian Andrew. Wesley, juggling his future at Starfleet Academy, takes an interest in the child, while Guinan quietly counsels him about family and choices. Meanwhile, subtle disturbances affect the plague containers in the cargo hold.

Ian ages through early childhood in a single day, displaying curiosity about the ship and its people. As the anomalies around the plague samples intensify, Pulaski and Data determine that Ian’s unique life-signs are causing the instability, putting everyone aboard at risk.

Realizing he is the cause of the danger, Ian calmly accepts that he must leave. He allows his body to sicken, dying peacefully in Troi’s arms before transforming back into a glowing entity. He thanks her and the crew for allowing him to briefly experience life, and the ship’s systems stabilize. The Enterprise resumes its mission with a renewed sense of wonder and loss.

Title: Where Silence Has Lease
Antagonists: Nagilum's lethal experiments on the crew
Featureless space void trapping the Enterprise
Summary:
While charting a relatively quiet region of space, the Enterprise encounters a black, sensorless void that appears to contain no matter or energy at all. Curious, Picard orders the ship closer, only for the void to suddenly expand and envelop the Enterprise, cutting it off from normal space. As the crew attempts to escape, they confront illusions, impossible corridors, and a Romulan warbird that vanishes as quickly as it appears.

A powerful being calling itself Nagilum reveals that it has trapped the ship inside this pocket of nothingness to study humanoids, particularly the nature of death. After casually killing a bridge officer to observe his demise, Nagilum announces plans to kill large portions of the crew. Picard must choose between sacrificing everyone on his own terms or risking further torment at Nagilum’s whim.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise explores a relatively uncharted region when sensors detect an area of absolute blackness. Intrigued by the phenomenon’s lack of measurable properties, Picard orders a closer look.

As the ship approaches, the void expands and swallows the Enterprise. Navigation becomes meaningless, with the viewscreen showing only featureless darkness. Attempts to reverse course simply bring the ship deeper into the anomaly.

The crew encounters bizarre manifestations: a corridor that loops back on itself, a duplicate Enterprise, and a Romulan warbird that appears and then dissolves. Eventually, a distorted face identifies itself as Nagilum, an entity testing the limits of the crew’s perception.

Nagilum announces an interest in studying death and abruptly kills Lieutenant Haskell on the bridge, observing his demise clinically. It states an intention to kill many more crew members under varied conditions. Horrified, Picard prepares to initiate the self-destruct rather than allow his people to be tortured.

Confronted with Picard’s willingness to destroy the ship, Nagilum relents, expressing confusion about humanoid notions of self-determination and sacrifice. The Enterprise is released from the void and resumes its course, leaving the crew to ponder the encounter with a being whose curiosity nearly proved fatal.

Title: Elementary, Dear Data
GuestCharacters: Reginald Barclay (mentioned only in later continuity)
Antagonists: Self-aware holodeck Professor Moriarty with access to ship systems
Summary:
Arriving early for a rendezvous with the USS Victory, the Enterprise crew enjoys some leisure time. Geordi invites Data to the holodeck for a Sherlock Holmes adventure, confident in Data’s encyclopedic knowledge of the stories. Dr. Pulaski, skeptical that Data can truly reason rather than merely recall, challenges him to solve a mystery that is not drawn from Conan Doyle’s original cases.

To meet the challenge, Geordi instructs the computer to create a Holmes opponent capable of defeating Data. The holodeck responds by generating a version of Professor Moriarty who is not only brilliant but self-aware—and soon realizes that his world is a simulation. Gaining access to the Enterprise’s controls, Moriarty demands recognition as a sentient being in his own right.

StorySections.Text: With time to spare before their rendezvous, Geordi suggests a Sherlock Holmes program on the holodeck. Data eagerly assumes the role of Holmes, easily solving a standard case.

Pulaski joins the program and criticizes Data for merely replaying stories he already knows. To prove his friend’s abilities, Geordi orders the computer to create an original mystery with an opponent capable of defeating Data.

The computer generates Professor Moriarty, who quickly deduces that his reality is artificial. He seizes limited control of the ship—causing systems anomalies—to force Picard’s attention and negotiate for his continued existence.

Picard confronts Moriarty in the holodeck, acknowledging his emergent consciousness but explaining the limits of current technology: the Enterprise cannot simply grant him a body outside the simulation.

Picard promises not to delete Moriarty and stores the program, offering hope that future advances may free him. Moriarty accepts this uncertain future with dignity, while Data reflects on the nature of artificial life and imagination.

Title: The Outrageous Okona
Antagonists: Misunderstandings over theft and paternity accusations
Feud between the worlds of Straleb and Atlec
Summary:
The Enterprise comes to the aid of Captain Thadiun Okona, a roguish freelance pilot whose small cargo ship has suffered a malfunction. Charming and irreverent, Okona quickly wins the admiration of many aboard, especially among the ship’s women, while Riker and others find themselves both amused and wary.

Soon, two neighboring worlds—Straleb and Atlec—demand Okona’s extradition on conflicting charges: theft of a valuable jewel and impregnating a prominent leader’s daughter, Yanar. Picard must untangle the accusations to avoid becoming entangled in a local dispute. Meanwhile, Data, inspired by Okona’s easy humor, asks Guinan and a holodeck stand-up comic to help him understand comedy, with mixed results.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise intercepts a disabled cargo vessel and beams aboard its pilot, Thadiun Okona, whose breezy attitude and flirtatious charm immediately stand out.

While engineering assists with repairs, Okona mingles with the crew, sharing outrageous stories. Data, intrigued by the laughter he provokes, asks Guinan why people find Okona amusing and decides to study humor more closely.

Two armed vessels arrive from neighboring worlds. Debin of Straleb accuses Okona of stealing a family jewel and seducing his daughter Yanar. Kushell of Atlec counters with his own claims, each side demanding justice.

Picard brings all parties together and gradually uncovers the truth: Yanar is in love with Benzan of Atlec, and Okona has been helping them cover her pregnancy to prevent a political scandal. The jewel in question is a betrothal gift, not stolen property.

With the misunderstanding resolved and the young couple’s relationship acknowledged, Okona departs with his reputation as a lovable scoundrel intact. On the holodeck, Data attempts stand-up comedy but concludes that genuine humor requires spontaneity and an intuitive connection he has yet to fully master.

Title: Loud as a Whisper
Antagonists: Entrenched war on Solais V
Assassin who destroys Riva's Chorus
Summary:
The Enterprise transports Riva, a legendary mediator celebrated for settling seemingly intractable conflicts, to the war-torn world of Solais V. Riva is deaf and communicates through a telepathic "chorus" of three interpreters who express his intellect, passion, and harmony. Worf, in particular, is eager to meet the man credited with helping bring peace between the Federation and the Klingon Empire.

On Solais V, early talks between the warring factions go badly when a nervous combatant panics and fires on Riva’s chorus, killing them instantly. Devastated and suddenly unable to communicate as he once did, Riva retreats in grief. Troi and Picard must help him find a new approach to mediation that embraces his silence as a tool rather than a limitation.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise is ordered to pick up Riva, a famed negotiator whose skills are sought to end centuries of warfare on Solais V. The crew learns he is deaf and relies on a trio of telepathic interpreters.

Riva boards the Enterprise with his chorus, immediately impressing the crew with his confidence and presence. He forms a rapport with Troi, who recognizes the unique way his interpreters express facets of his personality.
On Solais V, the first negotiating session is tense. As Riva begins to work, a frightened soldier from one faction opens fire, killing the chorus and leaving Riva alone and emotionally shattered.

Riva blames himself and initially wishes to abandon the mission. Troi encourages him to see that his deafness and silence can become a new basis for communication, forcing the factions to invest in understanding him.

Riva chooses to remain on Solais V, intending to teach the combatants sign language and use the painstaking process of learning to communicate as the foundation for peace. The Enterprise departs, hopeful but aware that the road ahead for Solais will be long.

Title: The Schizoid Man
Antagonists: Ira Graves's consciousness hijacking Data
Ethical dilemma of forced digital immortality
Summary:
The Enterprise answers a call for medical assistance from planet Gravesworld, home to the brilliant but reclusive cyberneticist Dr. Ira Graves—mentor to Dr. Noonian Soong. By the time the crew arrives, Graves is terminally ill but still as arrogant and dismissive as ever, attended only by his young assistant Kareen Brianon.

Graves takes a particular interest in Data, boasting that he has solved the problem of mortality. After his apparent death, Data begins exhibiting uncharacteristic behavior, from arrogance to romantic advances toward Kareen. It becomes clear that Graves has transferred his consciousness into Data’s positronic brain, effectively displacing Data’s own identity.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives a distress signal from Gravesworld. Dr. Ira Graves, considered one of the greatest living minds, is dying and in need of medical help.
Picard, Data, and Pulaski visit Graves, who alternates between brilliance and caustic rudeness. He hints that he has found a way to conquer death through technology.
Graves dies in sickbay—or so it appears. Shortly afterward, Data begins acting strangely, displaying ego, humor, and proprietary behavior toward Kareen that do not fit his usual demeanor.
Troi senses another presence within Data, and Picard eventually confronts him, deducing that Graves has imprinted his consciousness into Data’s positronic net, pushing Data aside.

Realizing that using Data as a vessel deprives another sentient being of his life, Graves transfers his essence into the Enterprise computer, where it quickly dissipates into harmless data. Data returns to normal, with only faint traces of Graves’s knowledge remaining.

Title: Unnatural Selection
Antagonists: Rapid-aging pathogen linked to genetically engineered children
Risk of uncontrollable genetic experimentation
Summary:
En route to Star Station India, the Enterprise answers a distress call from the supply ship USS Lantree. Upon arrival, the crew finds all hands dead, their bodies aged decades beyond their chronological years. Following the Lantree’s last stop, Picard directs the Enterprise to Darwin Station, a research outpost studying genetically engineered children with advanced immune systems.

The scientists at Darwin Station believe their work is a triumph, but they are also showing signs of accelerated aging. Suspecting a link between the children and the syndrome, Dr. Pulaski advocates for bold measures, even placing herself at risk to test a possible cure. The crew must isolate and reverse the pathogen before it spreads further, confronting the unintended consequences of manipulating human genetics.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise diverts to the USS Lantree after receiving a distress signal. When they arrive, visual scans reveal a ship full of crew who appear to have died of extreme old age.

Pulaski confirms that the Lantree’s crew aged rapidly but finds no conventional pathogen. Tracing the ship’s movements, the Enterprise heads for Darwin Station, where researchers have been raising specially engineered children.

The scientists at Darwin are themselves beginning to age prematurely. They insist the children are healthy, but Pulaski suspects their enhanced immune systems may be triggering a catastrophic side effect. One child is brought aboard in a sealed shuttlecraft for examination.

Pulaski becomes infected with the rapid-aging condition and begins to deteriorate. Data takes her to a shuttle so she can work in isolation while Picard, Geordi, and the others search for a way to reverse the effect.

Using a transporter pattern taken before the infection as a template, the crew restores Pulaski to her proper age and applies the same principle to others. The Lantree is later destroyed to prevent further contamination, and Darwin Station’s work is put under strict review.
