Title: A Matter of Honor
Antagonists: Cultural misunderstandings aboard the Klingon ship Pagh
Hull-eating microorganism misinterpreted as sabotage
Summary:
As part of a Starfleet exchange program, Commander Riker volunteers to serve temporarily aboard a Klingon Bird-of-Prey, the IKS Pagh, while the Enterprise hosts Ensign Mendon from the Benzite world. Riker must quickly adapt to the harsh discipline and warrior ethos of Captain Kargan’s crew to earn their respect and survive.

When Mendon discovers a strange microorganism eating away at the Enterprise’s hull plating, a miscommunication delays his report. The same organism is later found on the Pagh, leading Kargan to suspect sabotage by the Federation. Riker must navigate Klingon honor, suspicion, and his loyalty to Picard to prevent an incident from escalating into open conflict.

StorySections.Text: Starfleet’s officer exchange program offers Enterprise crew members the chance to serve on other species’ vessels. Riker volunteers for assignment aboard a Klingon ship, intrigued by the challenge.

Riker beams to the Pagh with a hearty attitude and accepts Klingon traditions such as rough mess-hall behavior and direct challenges. Meanwhile, Ensign Mendon joins the Enterprise bridge crew and struggles with unfamiliar protocols.

Mendon identifies a peculiar organism on the Enterprise hull but, following Benzite custom, delays reporting until he has a full solution. Later, the same organism is detected on the Pagh, which Kargan interprets as evidence of a Federation plot.

Kargan decides to attack the Enterprise. Riker, bound by Klingon chain of command but loyal to Picard, maneuvers events so that he gains control of Kargan’s targeting device and has himself beamed from the Pagh to the Enterprise at the critical moment.

With Riker safely aboard and the Pagh’s weapons locked onto empty space, Picard and Kargan exchange formal words, and the misunderstanding is resolved. The hull organism is neutralized with phasers, and Riker’s successful tour cements his reputation as someone who can thrive even in a Klingon crew.

Title: The Measure of a Man
Antagonists: Starfleet's attempt to treat Data as property
Bruce Maddox's proposed disassembly of Data
Summary:
At a starbase along the Enterprise’s route, cyberneticist Commander Bruce Maddox arrives with a bold proposal: to disassemble and study Lieutenant Commander Data in hopes of reproducing Dr. Soong’s work and creating many more android officers. Data, concerned about Maddox’s incomplete understanding of positronic technology, refuses to undergo the procedure.

Maddox responds by having Data transferred to his command as Starfleet property. Picard challenges the order, leading to a formal hearing overseen by JAG officer Captain Phillipa Louvois. The hearing will determine whether Data is a sentient individual with rights or a piece of equipment that Starfleet can requisition at will—forcing Picard and Riker into opposing roles in court.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at a starbase for routine business. Data receives a visit from Bruce Maddox, who enthusiastically outlines his plan to replicate Data’s design.

When Maddox reveals that his procedure will require dismantling Data and that his theories are not fully tested, Data declines to participate. Maddox then cites Starfleet regulations to claim Data can be reassigned as property.

Picard contests Maddox’s move, prompting Captain Louvois to convene a hearing to decide Data’s status. Riker is reluctantly assigned to argue that Data is a machine without full rights, while Picard defends Data’s personhood.

During the hearing, Riker presents evidence of Data’s mechanical nature, even deactivating him, nearly costing Picard the case. Picard counters by questioning Maddox’s assumptions and appealing to broader principles about sentience, self-awareness, and freedom.

Louvois ultimately rules that Data has the right to choose, acknowledging that Starfleet cannot own him. Data declines Maddox’s procedure but leaves the door open to future cooperation. Riker is relieved that Data bears him no ill will, and the crew celebrates a quiet but profound affirmation of individual rights.

Title: The Dauphin
Antagonists: Political tensions surrounding Salia's future rule on Daled IV
Anya's extreme protectiveness and shapeshifting interventions
Summary:
The Enterprise is tasked with transporting Salia, a young woman destined to rule the war-torn world of Daled IV and unite its warring factions. Accompanied by her stern governess Anya, Salia has spent her life in isolation preparing for leadership, with little chance to experience normal adolescence.

Wesley Crusher is immediately smitten and begins courting Salia with advice from Riker, Guinan, and others—each offering wildly different perspectives on love. When it is revealed that both Salia and Anya are shapeshifters with formidable abilities, Anya’s fierce protectiveness leads to confrontations as she tries to shield Salia from any perceived threat, including the Enterprise crew.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives orders to transport Salia and her guardian Anya to Daled IV, where Salia is fated to become a unifying ruler. Wesley is curious about the mysterious passengers.
Wesley meets Salia and is instantly drawn to her. Anya, however, is strict and dismissive, insisting that Salia avoid unnecessary interactions and focus on her duty.

As Wesley and Salia spend time together, Anya’s overprotectiveness escalates. When she discovers a potential medical risk in sickbay, Anya reveals her shapeshifting nature, transforming into fearsome forms and alarming the crew.

Picard insists that Salia be allowed some autonomy, while Anya argues that any risk to her ward is unacceptable given Daled IV’s fragile future. Salia ultimately reveals her own shapeshifting abilities to Wesley, fearing that her true form will affect his feelings.

Salia chooses to honor her duty and transport down to Daled IV, even though it means parting from Wesley. Heartbroken, Wesley watches her departure from the observation lounge, consoled by the crew’s gentle reminders that first love is rarely simple or lasting.

Title: Contagion
Antagonists: Runaway Iconian computer program
Risk of Federation–Romulan conflict over the Neutral Zone
Summary:
The Enterprise rushes into the Neutral Zone after Captain Donald Varley of the USS Yamato sends a desperate message about catastrophic systems failures tied to the fabled Iconian homeworld. Before Picard can learn more, the Yamato explodes with all hands lost, apparently due to some form of technology-based contagion.

Tracking Varley’s last course, the Enterprise locates a long-hidden Iconian base just as a Romulan warbird under Subcommander Taris arrives, ready to accuse Starfleet of treaty violations. An alien computer program begins infecting the Enterprise’s systems, causing malfunctions from life support to navigation. Picard leads an away team into the Iconian control center, where he must decide whether to preserve or destroy the gateway technology that has just killed an entire crew—and now threatens two more.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise responds to a distress call from the USS Yamato. Captain Varley reports severe, inexplicable system failures before the Yamato suddenly explodes, leaving the Enterprise crew horrified and searching for answers.

Picard reviews Varley’s logs and learns of his obsession with locating Iconia, a vanished civilization rumored to have possessed incredible technology. The Enterprise follows the Yamato’s last trajectory toward a dangerous region near the Neutral Zone.

Upon arriving at the Iconian world, sensors reveal a subterranean control complex and an ancient gateway system. A Romulan warbird commanded by Subcommander Taris appears, accusing the Enterprise of violating the Neutral Zone as both ships begin suffering similar system failures.

Picard, Data, and Worf beam into the Iconian base, where Data interfaces with the control systems and is nearly overwhelmed by the alien program. Realizing the technology is too dangerous to fall into anyone’s hands, Picard initiates a self-destruct sequence for the facility and escapes through a gateway back to the Enterprise.

Geordi stops the alien program by rebooting the Enterprise from clean system backups, while the Romulan ship, having been given a crucial hint, also survives. The Iconian base collapses in a controlled explosion, and Picard reflects on the loss of both a great danger and a remarkable piece of history.

Title: The Royale
Antagonists: Endless "Hotel Royale" simulation trapping the away team
Misinterpreted alien attempt to create a human environment
Summary:
Investigating unusual debris in the atmosphere of an otherwise inhospitable gas giant, the Enterprise discovers wreckage from a 21st-century Earth spacecraft. Sensors also detect an impossible anomaly on the surface: a pocket of breathable air surrounding a revolving-door entrance to a garish 20th-century casino hotel.

Riker, Data, and Worf beam down and find themselves trapped inside the "Hotel Royale," a tacky environment populated by one-dimensional characters reenacting the plot of a bad novel. As they search for an exit, they uncover the tragic story of Colonel Stephen Richey—an astronaut inadvertently rescued by aliens who built the hotel simulation based solely on the trashy novel, unknowingly condemning him to live out his life in this artificial purgatory.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise discovers anomalous readings from a gas giant and identifies wreckage from the long-lost Earth ship Charybdis. Amid lethal storms below, sensors find a small, stable pocket of Earthlike conditions.

Riker leads an away team to the anomaly, where they pass through a revolving door and emerge into the bustling lobby of the Hotel Royale. No one inside seems aware of the galaxy beyond the casino’s walls.

Attempts to leave fail as the away team keeps looping back into the hotel. Data and Riker observe that the staff and guests are acting out fixed roles from an overblown melodrama involving gangsters, gamblers, and a long-suffering heiress.

The team finds Richey’s journal in an upstairs room, revealing that benevolent aliens tried to reconstruct a human environment for him after accidentally killing his crewmates. Using the novel’s own rules, Riker, Data, and Worf realize they must "buy" the hotel to end the story and free themselves.

Data wins enough money at the craps table to purchase the Hotel Royale, completing the narrative. The simulation collapses, allowing the away team to beam out. Back aboard the Enterprise, Picard reflects on the kindness and tragic ignorance of the aliens who built an eternity out of a very bad book.

Title: Time Squared
Antagonists: Temporal distortion that destroys the Enterprise
Fatalistic loop embodied by the future Picard
Summary:
The Enterprise encounters a drifting shuttlecraft apparently identical to one of its own, bearing a single occupant: an unconscious Jean-Luc Picard from six hours in the future. Sensor records within the shuttle depict the Enterprise being destroyed as it spirals helplessly into a mysterious energy vortex.

As the crew struggles to reconcile the paradox, the future Picard intermittently regains consciousness, disoriented and unable to explain his decisions. The log shows him abandoning the Enterprise in the shuttle just before its destruction, haunting the present-day Picard with the possibility that he might someday choose to leave his crew to die. Determined to break the cycle, Picard decides to face the anomaly differently—even if it means defying the evidence of his own future actions.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise detects a small craft tumbling in space. When tractored aboard, it is revealed to be an Enterprise shuttle with its registry and logs matching one that still sits in the ship’s own hangar.

Inside the shuttle, the crew finds a barely alive duplicate of Picard and records that appear to be from six hours in the future. Initial playback shows chaotic readings and a glimpse of the ship being pulled toward a swirling spatial anomaly.

As the future Picard revives, he can offer only fragments of information. Meanwhile, Troi senses the captain’s mounting unease at the idea that he might have chosen to abandon ship in the timeline the logs describe.

When the predicted temporal conditions begin to repeat, the Enterprise encounters the same vortex. Present-day Picard realizes that following his apparent future course—fleeing in the shuttle—may itself be what seals the ship’s fate.

Picard stuns his future self and destroys the shuttle, refusing to repeat the earlier decision. He then keeps the Enterprise in place rather than attempting to escape, causing the vortex to vanish and ending the loop. The future Picard disappears, leaving the crew with unanswered questions about the true nature of the anomaly.

Title: The Icarus Factor
Antagonists: Long-simmering resentment between Riker and his father
Worf's sense of isolation from Klingon traditions
Summary:
Starfleet offers Commander Riker command of the USS Aries, a prestigious step toward his own captaincy. The news arrives with an unexpected messenger: Kyle Riker, Will’s estranged father, whose sudden reappearance dredges up years of unresolved anger and abandonment.

As Picard encourages Riker to weigh his career options, Kyle presses his own perspective, leading to increasingly heated confrontations. Meanwhile, Worf’s agitation over the day’s events prompts his friends to realize he is approaching an important Klingon rite without family support. Both storylines bring buried emotions to the surface, forcing Riker and Worf to confront their pasts in order to move forward.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives a special courier: Kyle Riker, who brings classified orders offering Will command of the USS Aries. The reunion between father and son is awkward from the first moment.
Riker and Kyle clash over old grievances, including Kyle’s decisions after Will’s mother died. Troi observes that their anger masks unresolved affection neither wants to acknowledge.
Picard offers measured counsel as Riker weighs the Aries posting against his loyalty to the Enterprise. In parallel, Worf snaps at his crewmates, prompting concern from Data, Geordi, and Wesley.

Data and the others arrange a holodeck recreation of a Klingon Rite of Ascension so Worf can undergo the ceremony with his adopted "family" as witnesses. On the phaser range, Riker and Kyle literally face off in an Anbo-jyutsu match that doubles as an emotional release.

After the ritual and the match, Worf feels more grounded, and Riker and Kyle reach a tentative reconciliation. Riker ultimately declines command of the Aries, choosing to remain on the Enterprise for the time being.

Title: Pen Pals
Antagonists: Planetary tectonic catastrophe on Drema IV
Prime Directive restrictions on interference
Summary:
While the Enterprise surveys a region of space where several planets are undergoing catastrophic geological upheavals, Data picks up a faint subspace transmission from a frightened child. Against regulations, he answers and begins a quiet correspondence with Sarjenka, a girl from Drema IV whose world is facing imminent destruction.

As the crew’s broader survey reveals that Drema IV will soon become uninhabitable, Data brings Sarjenka’s plight to Picard, forcing a debate over the Prime Directive. At the same time, Wesley leads his first mineral survey team, struggling with the realities of command and responsibility. Ultimately, Picard must decide whether to risk violating non-interference to save an innocent civilization already unknowingly touched by Starfleet actions.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise undertakes a long-term geological study of several planets. Data, idly scanning subspace frequencies, hears a child’s pleading voice calling for help.

Intrigued and moved, Data quietly replies to the signal and begins conversing with Sarjenka, who describes the quakes and disasters wracking her world. Meanwhile, Picard assigns Wesley to command the planetary survey team, giving the young ensign a chance to prove himself.

As more data comes in, it becomes clear that Drema IV is doomed without outside intervention. Data, torn between duty and compassion, finally brings his secret correspondence to the captain’s attention.

Picard convenes his senior officers to debate whether the Prime Directive allows any action now that contact has already occurred. A compromise solution is reached: the Enterprise will stabilize the planet’s geology in a way that minimizes cultural contamination.

Data beams down to bring Sarjenka briefly aboard while the enterprise completes its intervention, then returns her home with her memory altered to erase knowledge of the Enterprise. Picard and Data reflect on the cost of both action and enforced forgetting.

Title: Q Who
Antagonists: The Borg Collective
Q's dangerous "lesson" for humanity
Summary:
When young engineer Sonya Gomez collides with Captain Picard in Ten Forward, the ship’s newest crew member gets an unexpected audience with Guinan—and a front-row seat to a test of humanity. Q appears on the bridge, demanding a place on the crew once more. When Picard refuses, Q snaps his fingers and hurls the Enterprise thousands of light-years across the galaxy.

There, the crew encounters the Borg, a collective of cybernetic beings who view other species as raw material to be assimilated. The Borg cube methodically probes the Enterprise, cutting out a section of the ship and its crew as a sample. Picard realizes that Starfleet is outmatched and reluctantly begs Q to send them home, learning that humanity’s journey into the galaxy has awakened enemies they are not yet prepared to face.

StorySections.Text: In Ten Forward, Guinan offers quiet guidance to nervous new officer Sonya Gomez. Moments later, Q manifests on the bridge, mocking Starfleet’s confidence and demanding to join the crew.
Picard refuses Q’s demand, prompting the entity to fling the Enterprise deep into unexplored space. Scans detect an immense, geometric starship of unknown design on an intercept course.

Guinan warns Picard that the Borg are a ruthless, relentless foe. A Borg drone beams aboard without permission, scanning and sampling the ship. Worf kills it, but the Borg simply adapt and continue their analysis.

The Borg cube cuts out an entire section of the Enterprise, killing crew members. Even after a desperate attack, the cube rapidly regenerates. Realizing they cannot win, Picard admits that Q has proven his point about the dangers awaiting humanity.

At Picard’s plea, Q returns the Enterprise to Federation space. Guinan grimly notes that the encounter was merely postponed, not avoided—the Borg now know of the Federation, and someday they will come.

Title: Samaritan Snare
Antagonists: Pakleds' deceptive plea for help
Picard's risky heart surgery away from the Enterprise
Summary:
The Enterprise encounters the Pakleds, an apparently unsophisticated alien species whose ship seems to be in distress. Believing they are dealing with a harmless, technologically backward people, the crew sends Geordi La Forge over to assist with repairs. Once aboard, Geordi discovers the Pakleds are not as simple as they appear: they have been stealing technology from other species and now plan to keep him as leverage to obtain more.

Meanwhile, Captain Picard reluctantly travels with Wesley to Starbase 515 for a cardiac procedure, revealing his artificial heart and a youthful brush with death. While Picard is away, Riker must manage the Pakled crisis and rescue Geordi without provoking violence, ultimately turning the Pakleds’ limited understanding against them.

StorySections.Text: Wesley is surprised to be assigned as Picard’s shuttle companion to Starbase 515. Aboard the Enterprise, a distressed Pakled vessel hails the ship, asking for help in broken, childlike phrases.

Picard begrudgingly opens up to Wesley about his need for cardiac surgery and hints at the bar fight that originally damaged his heart. On the Pakled ship, Geordi begins repairs while the aliens repeat that they "look for things" and "want to make their ship go."

The Pakleds suddenly take Geordi hostage, demanding advanced technology from the Enterprise. Riker, Troi, and Worf realize they have misjudged the aliens, who have cobbled together their capabilities through theft.

Riker and Pulaski stage a ruse, pretending that the Enterprise is preparing a dangerous weapon. Geordi secretly collaborates from the Pakled ship, adjusting their systems so that a staged "weapon test" appears to threaten them.

Frightened, the Pakleds agree to release Geordi and back down. Picard’s surgery is completed successfully, and he returns to the ship somewhat embarrassed by Wesley’s knowledge of his past—but alive and healthy.

Title: Up the Long Ladder
Antagonists: Genetic stagnation of the Mariposan clone colony
Impending destruction of the Bringloidi agricultural settlement
Summary:
Responding to a centuries-old distress signal, the Enterprise discovers two very different human colonies descended from the same expedition. One, the Bringloidi, is an agrarian community led by the outspoken Danilo Odell and his daughter Brenna, evacuated from their failing world as solar flares threaten their homes. The other, the Mariposans, are a sterile, hyper-ordered society of clones suffering from degrading genetic copies.

While the Bringloidi struggle to adapt to the sterile environment of the Enterprise, the Mariposans request genetic samples from the crew to refresh their failing clones—an appeal Picard and Pulaski refuse on ethical grounds. The solution may lie in forcing the two groups to cooperate, blending traditional reproduction with the Mariposans’ structured environment to forge a new, more sustainable society.

StorySections.Text: An ancient distress call leads the Enterprise to a threatened agricultural colony. Picard orders an evacuation, bringing the boisterous Bringloidi aboard just as solar activity makes their planet uninhabitable.
Danilo Odell and the Bringloidi disrupt shipboard routines with livestock, loud music, and rustic habits. Brenna quickly draws Riker’s eye, matching his flirtation with her own sharp wit.

Tracing the original expedition’s path, the Enterprise locates the Mariposan colony: a settlement of identical individuals produced entirely by cloning, now facing genetic breakdown after too many replication cycles.

The Mariposans attempt to take DNA from Riker and Pulaski without consent, prompting Picard to intervene. He proposes an alternative: merging the two colonies, with Bringloidi genetic diversity revitalizing Mariposa’s population.

Though initially resistant, both groups grudgingly accept the arrangement. Picard envisions a future in which the Bringloidi and Mariposans combine the best of their traditions, avoiding extinction through cooperation.

Title: Manhunt
Antagonists: Lwaxana's overaggressive pursuit of a husband
Hidden threat posed by the Antedean assassins
Summary:
The Enterprise is tasked with transporting two silent Antedean delegates to a major peace conference. En route, Picard receives unexpected additional passengers: Lwaxana Troi and her valet Mr. Homn. Lwaxana, in the throes of a Betazoid midlife cycle that greatly heightens her sex drive, decides that Picard would make a perfect husband.

As Lwaxana romantically pursues Picard across the ship—forcing him at one point to hide in a Dixon Hill holodeck program—her presence also helps uncover a serious danger. Sensing that the apparently catatonic Antedeans harbor malicious intentions, she reveals them as would-be assassins planning to attack the conference, turning a comedic visit into an unlikely save-the-day intervention.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise takes aboard two Antedean delegates in stasis for transport to a diplomatic conference. Soon after, Lwaxana Troi beams aboard with Mr. Homn, immediately setting her sights on Picard.

Lwaxana announces she is in the Betazoid "Phase" and intends to find a husband, treating the Enterprise as a matchmaking ground. Picard grows increasingly uncomfortable under her telepathic and verbal advances.

To escape Lwaxana’s attention, Picard retreats into a Dixon Hill holodeck adventure, but she finds and joins him there, inserting herself into the noir setting. Deanna struggles to mediate between her mother and the captain.

As the delegates near their destination, Lwaxana abruptly shifts focus, revealing that the Antedeans are not just shy but actively concealing hostile intent. Security scans confirm they are carrying explosives.

The Antedeans are arrested, and Lwaxana, pleased to have saved the day, loses interest in Picard as a mate—for now. The captain breathes a sigh of relief as the Enterprise continues to the conference.

Title: The Emissary
Antagonists: Klingon sleeper ship T'Ong believing the war continues
Worf and K'Ehleyr's unresolved personal conflict
Summary:
The Enterprise is diverted to rendezvous with an unusual courier: a probe containing K’Ehleyr, a half-Klingon, half-human emissary. She brings alarming news: a Klingon battlecruiser, the T’Ong, launched decades earlier with its crew in suspended animation, is about to awaken. Believing the Empire and Federation are still at war, they are expected to attack the nearest Federation colonies.

K’Ehleyr and Worf share a complicated romantic history that reignites as they work together on a plan to stop the T’Ong without slaughtering its crew. While K’Ehleyr argues for destroying the ship, Picard and Worf search for a way to reach the awakened warriors through honor and authority instead of phasers.

StorySections.Text: Picard receives a high-priority signal redirecting the Enterprise to a set of coordinates. There, the crew recovers a probe carrying K’Ehleyr, who emerges irritated but all business.
K’Ehleyr briefs the senior staff on the T’Ong and its mission from a bygone era of open war. She and Worf exchange cold, barbed greetings that hint at a painful past.

Frustrated by what she sees as naive Federation optimism, K’Ehleyr vents her anger in Worf’s holodeck calisthenics program. Their sparring turns into a renewed romantic encounter, which Worf wishes to formalize through marriage rites that she rejects.

When the T’Ong awakens and prepares to attack nearby colonies, Worf proposes a risky strategy: he and K’Ehleyr will appear to the T’Ong crew as their commanding officers, invoking Klingon tradition to order them to stand down.

Disguised in Klingon uniforms, Worf and K’Ehleyr successfully convince Captain K’Temoc and his crew that the war is over and that attacking would be dishonorable. K’Ehleyr transfers to the T’Ong to help acclimate the warriors to the 24th century, parting from Worf with the suggestion that their paths will cross again.

Title: Peak Performance
Antagonists: Sirna Kolrami's arrogance and manipulative war games
Ferengi interference during the Starfleet exercise
Summary:
To sharpen Starfleet’s readiness in the wake of renewed tensions with the Borg, the Enterprise participates in a tactical exercise overseen by noted strategist Sirna Kolrami. In the simulation, Picard commands the Enterprise while Riker takes charge of the lightly armed USS Hathaway, with crews split between the two ships for a mock battle.

Kolrami’s smug certainty that Picard will easily defeat Riker—and that android officer Data is no match for his own gaming prowess—creates friction among the crew. When a real Ferengi vessel commanded by DaiMon Bractor arrives, misinterpreting the exercise as an opportunity to capture a crippled Federation starship, the harmless war game suddenly becomes a potentially lethal confrontation.

StorySections.Text: Sirna Kolrami, a famed Zakdorn strategist, comes aboard the Enterprise to supervise a war games exercise designed to test Starfleet’s tactical capabilities in the face of new threats.

Picard assigns Riker to command the outdated Hathaway against the Enterprise in a simulated battle. Riker assembles a skeleton crew and revels in the challenge of making the "hopeless" ship competitive.

Kolrami defeats Data at the game of strategema, leaving the android shaken and questioning his own abilities. On the Hathaway, Riker and his team scrounge for parts and devise creative tactics to compensate for their underpowered vessel.

During the exercise, an opportunistic Ferengi ship commanded by DaiMon Bractor appears and believes the disabled Hathaway to be easy prey. The Ferengi threaten both ships, unaware the battle they interrupted was only a simulation.

Riker and Picard coordinate a bluff: the Hathaway makes a short warp jump while the Enterprise fakes its own destruction, convincing the Ferengi they face hidden reinforcements. The Ferengi withdraw. Later, Data rematches Kolrami at strategema, playing for a draw by adopting a defensive strategy that frustrates Kolrami into quitting, restoring Data’s confidence.

Title: Shades of Gray
Antagonists: Neural parasite from the planet surface infecting Riker
Risk of irreversible brain damage during experimental treatment
Summary:
After being wounded by a thorn while on a survey mission to a jungle world, Commander Riker falls ill aboard the Enterprise. Dr. Pulaski discovers that an alien microorganism from the planet has invaded his nervous system, forming dangerous growths along his spine and threatening his brain.

Conventional treatments fail, forcing Pulaski to attempt an experimental therapy that stimulates Riker’s brain with electrical impulses to fight the infection. As the procedure proceeds, Riker experiences vivid recollections of past missions and relationships, while the parasite adapts to each new neural pattern. The crew must fine-tune the therapy before the organism reaches Riker’s higher brain functions and kills him.

StorySections.Text: On a planetary survey, Riker is scratched by a thorny plant while rescuing a stranded officer, dismissing the injury as minor. Back aboard the ship, he suddenly collapses in pain.
Pulaski determines that an alien microorganism is migrating through Riker’s nervous system, encasing his spinal cord. Attempts to remove the growth physically are deemed too dangerous.

Pulaski decides to stimulate Riker’s brain, hoping his immune response will counter the parasite. As the procedure begins, Riker relives intense memories of danger and conflict from previous missions.

The organism adapts to the negative emotional patterns associated with fear and pain, growing stronger. Pulaski shifts strategies, prompting memories associated with positive emotions and relationships instead.

Responding to the new pattern, Riker’s body finally overcomes the infection. He awakens fully recovered, trading light banter with Picard, Troi, and Pulaski as the Enterprise leaves the planet behind.

Title: Evolution
Antagonists: Runaway nanite swarm interfering with the Enterprise
Risk to the Burleigh pulsar experiment
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts renowned scientist Dr. Paul Stubbs for a once-in-a-lifetime experiment to study a series of stellar matter eruptions from the binary Kavis Alpha system. As the ship maneuvers into position, critical systems begin to fail in seemingly random ways, threatening both the mission and the safety of the crew.

The trail leads back to Wesley Crusher’s latest science project: a pair of laboratory nanites that have escaped and multiplied throughout the ship’s computers. Far from being mere malfunctioning tools, the nanites demonstrate emergent intelligence. Picard, Beverly, and Data must balance Stubbs’s desperation to save his career-defining experiment with the responsibility to recognize and protect a new form of life that now resides within the Enterprise.

StorySections.Text: As the Enterprise approaches Kavis Alpha to observe a rare stellar phenomenon, Wesley hurriedly checks on a container of experimental nanites in his quarters before heading to duty, unaware that something has gone wrong.

Stubbs pressures Picard to prioritize his experiment above all else. Meanwhile, unexplained computer malfunctions escalate, temporarily disabling key systems at critical moments and raising fears of sabotage or mechanical failure.

An investigation reveals that Wesley’s nanites escaped their containment and have proliferated through the ship’s computers, altering software and hardware alike. Stubbs, furious that his life’s work is at risk, secretly attacks the nanites, provoking a coordinated, more dangerous response.

Data allows the nanites to speak through his body, revealing a nascent collective intelligence. Picard brokers a truce in which the Enterprise will transport the nanites to an uninhabited world, while Stubbs is given a second chance to complete his observation.

With the nanites relocated and the experiment ultimately successful, Wesley confronts the consequences of his oversight. Guinan gently helps him see that mistakes are part of growing up—and that he has also helped bring a new lifeform into existence.

Title: The Ensigns of Command
Antagonists: Sheliak Corporate's eviction deadline
Gosheven's refusal to evacuate the colony
Summary:
The Enterprise receives a message from the Sheliak Corporate invoking an old treaty: a human colony on Tau Cygni V has three days to evacuate before the Sheliak arrive to claim the planet—and to exterminate any humans who remain. Data is dispatched to lead the evacuation, only to discover a thriving colony of more than 15,000 people who have no intention of abandoning the world they spent generations taming.

While Picard and Troi attempt to negotiate an extension with the rigidly legalistic Sheliak, Data wrestles with how to persuade the colonists’ leader, Gosheven, that resistance is futile against a vastly superior foe. With the deadline looming, Data must find a way to command not just by rank, but by understanding what will finally convince stubborn humans to move.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise intercepts a formal Sheliak transmission citing a century-old treaty and demanding that all humans be removed from Tau Cygni V before their colony ship arrives.

Picard sends Data ahead to prepare the evacuation while the Enterprise races to meet the Sheliak ship. On the surface, Data is greeted by Gosheven, who proudly describes the colonists’ hard-won triumph over the planet’s hostile environment.

Gosheven and the town council reject Data’s warnings, insisting they will fight rather than surrender their homes. Ard’rian McKenzie, a curious colonist fascinated by Data, becomes his ally and confidante, urging him to find a way to make the threat real to her people.

As Picard stalls the Sheliak by exploiting obscure treaty clauses, Data sabotages the local aqueduct with a low-level phaser strike, demonstrating how easily the colony’s infrastructure can be destroyed. Faced with undeniable proof, the colonists reluctantly agree to evacuate, and Picard secures time to relocate them.

With the evacuation underway and the Sheliak appeased, Ard’rian says goodbye to Data, grateful for his unconventional leadership. Data returns to the Enterprise having learned more about persuasion, authority, and human stubbornness.

Title: The Survivors
Antagonists: Mysterious attacker that destroyed the Rana IV colony
Kevin Uxbridge's buried guilt and immense power
Summary:
Responding to a distress signal from the Federation colony on Rana IV, the Enterprise finds the planet’s surface devastated and its population of 11,000 apparently wiped out—except for a single untouched patch of land containing a house, a garden, and two elderly survivors, Kevin and Rishon Uxbridge. The couple insist they are simple colonists who somehow escaped the attack and refuse offers of relocation.

As the crew investigates, Deanna Troi is tormented by an endless musical motif in her mind, and a powerful alien warship repeatedly appears to drive the Enterprise away. Picard gradually realizes that the attackers, the invulnerable ship, and even parts of what the Enterprise sees on the surface may all be illusions tied to Kevin himself, leading to a revelation about his true nature and the terrible choice he once made.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at Rana IV to find a wrecked colony and a single pristine homestead. Picard, Riker, and Troi beam down to meet Kevin and Rishon Uxbridge, who seem oddly calm amid the devastation.
Kevin and Rishon insist on staying in their home, rejecting evacuation. Back on the ship, Troi becomes distracted and distressed by a lilting waltz that she hears continuously in her mind.

A heavily armed alien vessel appears from nowhere and attacks the Enterprise, then vanishes after Picard returns fire. Picard’s instinct tells him the threat is connected to the Uxbridges, whose story does not quite add up.

Picard allows the attacking ship to destroy the Uxbridges’ house in a controlled scenario, only to witness it reappear unharmed. Confronted, Kevin admits that he is a powerful non-corporeal being who created an illusion of Rishon and the homestead after failing to protect the colony from the Husnock.

Kevin reveals that, in a moment of grief and rage, he annihilated the entire Husnock species in retaliation. Horrified by the scale of his own act, he accepts Picard’s decision to leave him and his illusion in peace, beyond the Federation’s judgment.

Title: Who Watches the Watchers
Antagonists: Cultural contamination of the Mintakan proto-Vulcan society
Religious belief in "the Picard" as a god
Summary:
The Enterprise travels to Mintaka III, where a hidden Federation outpost covertly observes a proto-Vulcan society just emerging into a rational, pre-industrial culture. When a power failure exposes the outpost, an injured Mintakan named Liko is accidentally transported to the Enterprise and treated by Dr. Crusher. Despite an attempt to erase his memory, Liko returns to his village with fragmented recollections of Picard and advanced technology.

Liko and others interpret these memories through a religious lens, reviving long-abandoned superstition and worship of "the Picard" as a god. Picard must weigh the Prime Directive against the need to correct the damage, ultimately deciding that the only honest way to undo the myth is to reveal the truth of who he is and demonstrate his own mortality to Mintakan leader Nuria.

StorySections.Text: An accident at the hidden Federation outpost on Mintaka III severely injures one of the anthropologists and compromises the holographic camouflage shielding it from the proto-Vulcan villagers nearby.

While attempting to stabilize the outpost, Crusher beams the critically injured Mintakan Liko to the Enterprise for treatment. Despite efforts to wipe his short-term memory, he awakens with partial recollections of Picard and starship technology.

Back in his village, Liko describes "the Picard" as a powerful being who saved and then returned him. His daughter Oji and others begin to reframe old myths around this new figure, unsettling Mintakan leader Nuria.

Troi and Riker go undercover as Mintakans to assess the damage, but Troi is exposed and taken as a potential sacrifice to win Picard’s favor. Picard instead beams Nuria to the Enterprise and shows her the reality of his crew and their mortality.

Nuria returns to the village convinced that Picard is no god, helping to dismantle the emerging religion. The Enterprise withdraws, having risked deeper contact in order to preserve the Mintakans’ hard-won rational culture.

Title: The Bonding
Antagonists: Residual Koinonian defense mechanisms
Alien entity's misguided attempt to replace Jeremy's mother
Summary:
During an away mission to the ruins of a long-dead Koinonian civilization, a hidden explosive device kills Lieutenant Marla Aster, leaving her young son Jeremy orphaned aboard the Enterprise. Worf, who was leading the mission, feels a deep sense of responsibility and invokes a Klingon ritual that would symbolically adopt Jeremy into his family.

As the crew struggles with their own memories of loss—particularly Wesley, who lost his father years earlier—an alien entity from the planet manifests aboard the ship in the form of Marla Aster. The being offers Jeremy a recreated life on an illusory version of their old home, forcing Picard and the others to confront whether this comforting deception serves the boy’s healing or simply avoids his grief.

StorySections.Text: An away team led by Worf explores Koinonian ruins when a buried explosive device suddenly detonates, killing Marla Aster and shocking the crew.
Back on the Enterprise, Picard must inform Jeremy of his mother’s death. Worf, consumed by guilt, asks to perform the Klingon Rite of R'uustai, binding Jeremy to him as family.
An apparition of Marla Aster appears aboard the ship, claiming to have been transported away before the explosion. Beverly and Troi are skeptical, and scans soon reveal an alien energy signature.

The Koinonian entity, unable to comprehend human grief, offers to create a perfect replica of Jeremy’s former life on the planet. Picard, Worf, and Troi argue that Jeremy must be allowed to mourn and move forward in the real world, not in a fabricated paradise.
Jeremy chooses to remain on the Enterprise, accepting Worf’s offer of familial bond. The entity departs, and the ship holds a ceremony recognizing Jeremy’s loss and his new connection with Worf.

Title: Booby Trap
Antagonists: Ancient Promellian booby trap in the asteroid field
Rising radiation threatening the Enterprise crew
Summary:
The Enterprise discovers the wreck of an ancient Promellian battlecruiser adrift within a dense asteroid field, its crew long dead but its systems intact. When the Enterprise moves in to investigate, it becomes ensnared in the same energy-draining trap that claimed the Promellians, with the ship’s power slowly bleeding away as ambient radiation climbs toward lethal levels.

Geordi La Forge turns to the holodeck for help, constructing a simulation of Dr. Leah Brahms, one of the designers of the Enterprise’s warp engines. As he and the holographic Brahms collaborate to understand the trap, Picard prepares to pilot the ship manually through the asteroids, relying on instinct rather than computers to escape.

StorySections.Text: Surveying a debris-filled system, the Enterprise detects a derelict Promellian battlecruiser perfectly preserved amid the ruins of an ancient battle.

Excited by the archaeological opportunity, Picard orders a closer look. Once inside the asteroid field, the Enterprise becomes snared in a network of energy-draining booby traps, mirroring the fate of the Promellian ship.

As the ship’s power dwindles and radiation levels rise, escape options narrow. Geordi creates a holodeck recreation of Dr. Leah Brahms to consult on radical ways to reconfigure the engines and power distribution.

Geordi and the holographic Brahms determine that conventional propulsion and shields only feed the trap. They propose shutting down most automated systems and flying the ship out on minimal power, using short engine bursts timed to exploit gaps in the field.

Picard personally takes the helm, threading the Enterprise through the asteroids and out of the trap. Afterward, Geordi reflects on his unexpected emotional connection to the Brahms simulation, setting up future complications when he meets the real Leah Brahms.

Title: The Enemy
Antagonists: Deadly storms on Galorndon Core
Romulan–Federation tension over a border incident
Summary:
Answering a distress call near the Neutral Zone, the Enterprise discovers a crashed Romulan scout ship on the storm-wracked planet Galorndon Core. Geordi La Forge is stranded on the surface with a surviving Romulan, while Worf oversees the care of another critically injured Romulan brought aboard the ship.

As electromagnetic storms disrupt transport and communications, Geordi and his hostile companion must cooperate to survive. Aboard the Enterprise, Dr. Crusher determines that the injured Romulan can be saved only by a ribosome-compatible transfusion from Worf—a request Worf refuses due to his deep-seated hatred of Romulans for their role in his parents’ deaths. Meanwhile, Commander Tomalak arrives in a warbird, accusing Picard of kidnapping and threatening war if his missing personnel are not returned.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise picks up a weak distress signal near the Neutral Zone and traces it to Galorndon Core, a world with violent electromagnetic storms. An away team discovers wreckage from a Romulan scout ship.

A storm forces the away team to retreat. Geordi falls into a crevasse and is left behind as the others beam out. Another Romulan survivor regains consciousness on the Enterprise in critical condition.

On the surface, Geordi and a Romulan officer reluctantly join forces to navigate the treacherous terrain, learning to rely on each other’s strengths. In sickbay, Crusher informs Worf that his unique biology could save the dying Romulan.

Worf, haunted by memories of Khitomer, refuses to donate, forcing Picard to respect his decision even as the Romulan expires. Tomalak arrives, demanding answers and assuming the worst of Starfleet’s intentions.

Geordi and his Romulan companion are finally rescued, their cooperation providing a rare moment of understanding. Picard confronts Tomalak with the truth, defusing the standoff but leaving the cost of prejudice and war painfully clear.

Title: The Price
Antagonists: Cutthroat negotiations over the Barzan wormhole
Devinoni Ral's manipulative use of his empathic abilities
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts delicate negotiations over the rights to a newly discovered wormhole controlled by the resource-poor Barzan government. Access to the wormhole’s distant terminus could make whoever controls it a major power in the quadrant. Representatives from several factions, including the Federation and the Ferengi, vie for the contract.

Counselor Deanna Troi finds herself romantically drawn to Devinoni Ral, a charismatic negotiator who secretly shares her empathic abilities and uses them to manipulate opponents. As Ral’s tactics grow more ruthless, Troi must confront the conflict between her feelings and her ethical obligation to expose his unfair advantage—while a probe mission reveals that the "stable" wormhole may be anything but.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise welcomes delegations to bid on the Barzan wormhole, a potential stable passage to the distant Gamma Quadrant. Troi, exhausted from counseling duties, reluctantly attends a reception for the negotiators.
Troi meets Devinoni Ral, who quickly charms her. Meanwhile, Picard works with Federation representative Mendoza and Riker to develop a strategy for securing the wormhole rights.

A Ferengi team led by DaiMon Goss poisons Mendoza to knock the Federation out of contention, forcing Picard to appoint Riker as replacement negotiator. Ral subtly manipulates rivals by exploiting his unacknowledged empathic insight.

Data and Geordi dispatch a shuttle to test the wormhole’s terminus, accompanied by two Ferengi, Arridor and Kol. Their findings show that only the Barzan side is stable; on the far end, the exit shifts unpredictably, marooning the Ferengi when they refuse to return.

Troi publicly reveals Ral’s secret empathic abilities and his manipulation of the talks, undermining his position. The Barzan government ultimately keeps control of the now-questionable wormhole, and Troi reflects on the cost of choosing ethics over romance.

Title: The Vengeance Factor
Antagonists: Blood feud between Acamarian central government and Gatherers
Yuta's engineered vendetta
Summary:
The Enterprise is dispatched to mediate a fragile reconciliation between the Acamarian central government and a band of nomadic raiders known as the Gatherers. Sovereign Marouk hopes to end generations of bloodshed by offering amnesty and resettlement to the Gatherers’ leader, Chorgan, and his followers.

Accompanying Marouk is her loyal servant Yuta, a quiet young woman who captures Riker’s attention. As negotiations progress, a series of unexplained deaths among former clan leaders hints at a hidden agenda. Data and Crusher uncover that Yuta was genetically altered years earlier to age slowly and deliver a lethal, clan-specific pathogen by touch, leaving Riker to confront the woman he has begun to care for before she completes her mission of vengeance.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise intercepts a Gatherer raid and successfully follows the raiders back to their base. Picard learns of the long-standing Acamarian civil strife and Marouk’s plan to offer them a way home.
Marouk and Yuta come aboard to meet with Picard and his officers. Riker and Yuta share a quiet attraction, while Worf and Data study the Gatherers’ tactics and history.

During a diplomatic visit to a Gatherer encampment, an elder dies suddenly after a brief encounter with Yuta. Examination reveals signs of a tailored biological weapon, suggesting targeted murder rather than natural causes.

Data and Crusher trace a pattern of similar deaths to an ancient Acamarian clan wiped out in a massacre. Evidence points to Yuta as the surviving instrument of vengeance, altered to kill members of the rival Lornak clan decades after the fact.

Riker confronts Yuta as she moves to assassinate Chorgan. When she refuses to abandon her mission, Riker is forced to stun her repeatedly, ultimately killing her to prevent further bloodshed. The talks continue, tainted by the cost of ending the feud.

Title: The Defector
Antagonists: Romulan deception over a supposed border incursion
Jarok's inner conflict and sacrifice
Summary:
A Romulan scout ship flees across the Neutral Zone and requests asylum aboard the Enterprise. Its pilot claims to be a low-ranking logistics officer with information about a secret Romulan base being built in Federation space—an outpost that could tip the strategic balance and spark war.

Under questioning and deception of their own, Picard and his crew discover that the defector is actually Admiral Alidar Jarok, a senior Romulan officer who has risked everything to prevent a war he believes his government is on the brink of starting. But as the Enterprise moves to investigate the alleged base, it becomes increasingly unclear whether Jarok has accurate information or has himself been misled.

StorySections.Text: During a Dixon Hill holodeck program with Data, Picard is interrupted by an emergency: a Romulan scout has crossed the Neutral Zone and is being pursued by a Warbird. The scout’s pilot pleads for asylum.

The Romulan claims to be a logistics clerk named Setal, offering intelligence about a military buildup that would violate the Treaty of Algeron. Picard orders Worf to grant provisional asylum while verifying the story.

Under pressure and subtle interrogation, the defector admits he is actually Admiral Alidar Jarok, once responsible for brutal actions against the Federation. He insists he is trying to prevent a catastrophic war his leaders are planning.

The Enterprise crosses into contested space to check Jarok’s claims and finds an empty stretch of stars—no secret base, only an ambush as Commander Tomalak’s Warbird decloaks, prepared to showcase Federation aggression.

Picard reveals his own counter-move: cloaked Klingon cruisers uncloak in support of the Enterprise, forcing Tomalak to withdraw. Jarok, realizing he has been used and can never return home, takes his own life, leaving a letter for his family that they may never receive.

Title: The Hunted
Antagonists: Angosian government's treatment of its augmented veterans
Roga Danar's conditioned combat responses
Summary:
The Enterprise arrives at Angosia III to evaluate the world’s petition for Federation membership. While orbiting the apparently peaceful, orderly society, the crew helps recapture Roga Danar, an escaped prisoner whose astonishing resourcefulness and restraint raise questions about why he is so feared by his own government.

Picard learns that Danar is one of many veterans from Angosia’s last war who were chemically and psychologically enhanced into perfect soldiers, then confined to a penal colony when they proved too difficult to reintegrate. The more Troi and Data learn about Danar’s plight, the harder it becomes to see him as a criminal rather than a victim of state policy, forcing Picard to decide how far the Enterprise can go in exposing a dark Angosian secret.

StorySections.Text: During membership talks with Angosia III, the Enterprise helps track a prisoner transport escapee. The fugitive, Roga Danar, evades sensors and security in ways that shock the crew.

Captured and brought aboard, Danar proves polite and articulate yet extremely dangerous, exploiting every opportunity to study the ship’s routines. Angosian officials describe him as irredeemably violent, offering few details about his past.

Troi and Data discover that Danar was an ordinary citizen before being altered into an ideal soldier during Angosia’s recent war. His "crimes" consist mainly of trying to escape the remote colony where he and others were exiled after the fighting ended.

Danar escapes again, this time using transporter tricks and his conditioning to infiltrate the Enterprise and eventually return to Angosia’s capital. Picard confronts Prime Minister Nayrok with evidence that the government has abandoned its veterans rather than helping them heal.

With Danar and other enhanced soldiers surrounding the capital, Nayrok begs Picard for armed intervention. Picard refuses to take sides in a domestic conflict, leaving the Angosians to face the consequences of their policies.

As the Enterprise departs, Picard hopes that Angosia will find a way to address its veterans’ needs rather than continue to hide them, while Troi reflects on the moral cost of turning people into weapons.

Title: The High Ground
Antagonists: Ansata separatist terrorist campaign
Rutia IV government's entrenched resistance to change
Summary:
On Rutia IV, where the Enterprise is overseeing medical relief efforts, a bombing in a public marketplace injures several people, including natives and a Starfleet officer. Dr. Beverly Crusher insists on treating victims on the surface, demonstrating Starfleet’s impartial humanitarian commitment. Her presence draws the attention of the Ansata separatists, a militant group waging a violent campaign against the Rutian government.

Crusher is abducted by the Ansata leader, Kyril Finn, whose group uses dangerous dimensional transporter technology that is slowly destroying their bodies. As Picard navigates political pressure from Rutian security chief Alexana Devos and the moral implications of the conflict, the crew must rescue Beverly without becoming instruments of either side’s propaganda.

StorySections.Text: During a visit to a Rutian marketplace, a bomb detonates, causing chaos and casualties. Crusher immediately begins treating the wounded, refusing to return to the Enterprise while lives can still be saved.
Crusher is kidnapped in the aftermath by Ansata terrorists using a portable dimensional device. Devos briefs Picard on years of violent attacks, describing the Ansata as uncompromising extremists.
In the Ansata base, Crusher confronts Kyril Finn about his tactics. Finn counters by arguing that peaceful avenues have failed and that violence is the only language the Rutian government hears.

Data and Wesley analyze the dimensional technology, discovering that each jump causes cumulative damage to the users’ cellular structure. Picard and Devos prepare a rescue, wary of escalating the conflict further.

An assault on the Ansata base results in Finn’s death and the collapse of his cell’s immediate plans. Crusher pleads for medical attention for the surviving terrorists, insisting that mercy must not be a casualty of politics.

As the Enterprise departs, Devos acknowledges that the violence may continue despite short-term victories. Crusher and Picard reflect on the intractable nature of some conflicts and the costs borne by civilians.

Title: Deja Q
Antagonists: Impending destruction of Bre'el IV due to a falling moon
Calamarain seeking revenge on Q
Summary:
While the Enterprise struggles to keep a destabilized moon from crashing into the surface of Bre’el IV, Q abruptly appears on the bridge—naked, terrified, and claiming to have been stripped of his powers by the Q Continuum. Now fully mortal, he begs Picard for sanctuary from the many beings he has angered over the centuries.

Skeptical but unwilling to let him die pointlessly, Picard confines Q to the ship as they continue working on the Bre’eli crisis. As Q attempts (and fumbles) at being human with Data’s reluctant guidance, one of his old victims, the Calamarain, arrives to exact revenge, forcing Q to decide whether his new-found understanding of mortality includes a capacity for self-sacrifice.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at Bre’el IV, where a moon is spiraling toward the planet. In the midst of tense calculations, Q materializes on the bridge claiming he has been cast out of the Continuum and made human.
Picard orders Q confined, uncertain whether to believe his story. Guinan tests his claims with a painful jab, confirming that Q can now feel physical sensations for the first time.
Data is assigned to watch over Q, who struggles comically with hunger, fatigue, and fear. Engineering attempts to use tractor beams and other methods to stabilize the moon, with limited success.

The Calamarain, a gaseous species previously tormented by Q, attack the Enterprise to reach him. Q, seeing that his presence endangers the ship, takes a shuttle in a misguided attempt to lure them away.

Moved by Q’s self-sacrificial act, the Continuum restores his powers, halting the Calamarain and returning the moon to a safe orbit. Q briefly "rewards" Data with a moment of genuine laughter before departing in his usual theatrical fashion.
With Bre’el IV saved, Picard and his crew contemplate whether Q learned anything lasting from his time as a mortal, while Guinan suggests that even a being like Q is not immune to growth.

Title: A Matter of Perspective
Antagonists: Conflicting holodeck reconstructions of events on the Tanuga research station
Nel Apgar's secret attempt to weaponize his research
Summary:
After supervising a scientific project on a Tanugan research station, Commander Riker returns to the Enterprise—only to be arrested by Investigator Krag on charges of murdering Dr. Nel Apgar. The station exploded shortly after Riker beamed out, and the widowed Manua Apgar testifies that Riker assaulted her and threatened her husband.

Seeking the truth, Picard agrees to let the Tanugans use the Enterprise holodeck to reenact testimony from multiple witnesses. As each account unfolds, discrepancies emerge, revealing biases and omissions that cast doubt on the initial accusations. Data’s analysis of the station’s power emissions points to a more dangerous secret: Apgar’s work on a new energy source had veered into weapons research, and the explosion may have been the result of his own attempt to kill Riker.

StorySections.Text: Riker returns from a routine mission to a Tanugan research station. Moments later, a Tanugan vessel arrives and Investigator Krag accuses him of murdering Dr. Nel Apgar.

Picard allows Krag to question Riker, who insists the explosion occurred after he left the station. Manua Apgar and an assistant provide damning statements portraying Riker as aggressive and inappropriate.
Using the holodeck, the Tanugans reconstruct events as each witness remembers them. The holo-dramatizations differ noticeably from Riker’s account, casting doubt on whose memories are reliable.

Data and Geordi analyze unusual energy readings, linking them to Apgar’s work on a Krieger wave converter. Evidence suggests the device could be adapted into a powerful weapon and that Apgar may have tried to use it to kill Riker.
A final holodeck reconstruction incorporating the new data shows Apgar firing the device at Riker as he transports out, triggering the catastrophic overload that destroyed the station.
Faced with this evidence, Krag drops the charges. Picard notes that while the truth emerged, the process revealed how easily perception and memory can distort events.

Title: Yesterday's Enterprise
Antagonists: Altered timeline in which the Federation is at war with the Klingon Empire
Battle at Narendra III that never occurred
Summary:
A temporal rift appears ahead of the Enterprise, and through it emerges the battle-damaged starship Enterprise-C, missing for 22 years. In the instant the older ship crosses into the present, history changes: the Enterprise-D becomes a warship, the Federation is locked in a long, losing conflict with the Klingon Empire, and Tasha Yar is alive, never having died on Vagra II.

Only Guinan senses that reality has gone wrong. As Picard struggles to reconcile the tactical advantage of keeping the Enterprise-C with Guinan’s insistence that it must return to its own time and face likely destruction, the crew of both ships confront the idea that their best chance for peace lies in a sacrifice already overdue. Tasha, learning that her original death was meaningless, chooses to join the Enterprise-C’s final stand at Narendra III.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise encounters a mysterious temporal rift. A battered starship emerges and is identified as the USS Enterprise-C, missing in action decades earlier.

Reality shifts as the Enterprise-D becomes a combat-ready vessel. Worf is absent from the bridge; Tasha Yar is alive and serving as security chief. Guinan senses that the timeline has changed in a profound and wrong way.

Captain Rachel Garrett of the Enterprise-C reports that her ship was defending a Klingon outpost at Narendra III when it was pulled through the rift. Picard, now a wartime captain, learns that the Federation is losing a brutal war against the Klingons.

Guinan insists that the Enterprise-C must return to its own time and complete its defense of the outpost, creating a legacy that leads to peace rather than war. Picard agonizes over sending the damaged ship back to almost certain destruction.

As Klingon ships close in, Captain Garrett is killed, and Lieutenant Richard Castillo prepares to take command. Tasha, having learned from Guinan that her death in the original timeline was meaningless, requests a transfer to the Enterprise-C.

Picard sends the Enterprise-C back through the rift under heavy fire. The temporal distortion collapses, restoring the original, peaceful timeline. Guinan later quietly confirms to Geordi that she wants to hear more about Tasha Yar, hinting at the echoes left by the altered history.

Title: The Offspring
Antagonists: Starfleet's attempt to remove Lal from Data's care
Lal's cascading neural failure
Summary:
Without prior notice, Data reveals to Picard that he has created a new android—his child, Lal—using his own programming and newly developed techniques. Lal gradually chooses a humanoid female appearance and begins the daunting process of learning to interact with the crew and understand emotions.

Starfleet Command, represented by Admiral Haftel, takes immediate interest in Lal as a unique research opportunity, insisting that she be transferred to a specialized facility. Picard argues that Data has the same right to raise his child that any sentient being does. As the debate unfolds, Lal’s rapidly evolving positronic brain begins to destabilize under the strain of her emotional development, leading to a crisis neither Data nor Starfleet can avert.

StorySections.Text: Data invites Picard, Troi, and Riker to his lab and introduces them to Lal, an unfinished android body he calmly refers to as his child.
Lal explores different species and genders before choosing a human female form. The crew takes on mentoring roles as she begins working in Ten Forward to observe and emulate social interaction.

Guinan helps Lal navigate early social confusion, while Troi and Crusher counsel Data on parenting responsibilities. Lal unexpectedly experiences emotions, surpassing Data in ways he does not fully anticipate.

Admiral Haftel arrives, impressed by Lal’s progress but determined to have her relocated for study. Picard resists, invoking Data’s rights as a parent and referencing previous legal recognition of Data’s personhood.
Lal begins suffering neural instability brought on by her emotional awakening. Data and Haftel work together desperately to save her, but the damage spreads beyond repair.
Lal dies in Data’s arms after expressing love for him. Later, Data quietly incorporates her memories into his own neural net, ensuring that a part of Lal will live on through him.

Title: Sins of the Father
Antagonists: Conspiracy within the Klingon High Council
Duras's false accusation against Mogh
Summary:
As part of a cultural officer exchange program, a stern Klingon named Kurn joins the Enterprise as acting first officer, subjecting the crew to harsh discipline. Kurn privately reveals to Worf that he is Worf’s younger brother, sent away after the Khitomer massacre. He has discovered that their late father Mogh is being posthumously accused of betraying the Klingon Empire to the Romulans.

To defend his family’s honor, Worf returns to the Klingon homeworld to challenge the accusation before the High Council. Chancellor K’Mpec presides over a trial riddled with political maneuvering, as Council member Duras pushes the charges forward. Picard serves as Worf’s cha’DIch—his legal advocate—while Data and the crew search for evidence that the true traitor may be someone far more powerful than a dead officer.

StorySections.Text: Kurn arrives on the Enterprise and immediately enforces a rigid command style, causing friction with Riker and the crew. He seems to pay special, critical attention to Worf.

Kurn reveals his true identity to Worf and explains that Mogh has been accused of collaborating with the Romulans at Khitomer. He urges Worf to return home and challenge the charge to preserve their family honor.
On Qo'noS, Worf confronts the High Council. Chancellor K’Mpec warns him that the case is politically sensitive, but Worf insists on pressing ahead, naming Picard as his cha’DIch.
As Duras presents damning "evidence" against Mogh, Data and the Enterprise crew uncover records indicating that the true traitor was someone from the powerful Duras family, not Worf’s father.

K’Mpec privately admits that exposing the Duras family would plunge the Empire into civil war. To preserve stability, he pressures Worf to accept discommendation—formal disgrace—so the truth can remain hidden.

Worf accepts discommendation for the sake of the Empire, instructing Kurn to remain silent about their relationship. As the Council turns its back on him, Worf walks away, his personal honor intact but publicly denied.

Title: Allegiance
Antagonists: Unknown aliens conducting captivity experiment
Picard duplicate placed aboard the Enterprise
Summary:
Without warning, Captain Picard is abducted from his quarters and replaced on the Enterprise by a convincing duplicate. The real Picard awakens in a featureless room with three strangers: a nervous Bolian named Mitena Haro, an academic Mizarian called Tholl, and a fierce Chalnoth warrior named Esoqq. None of them know why they have been taken.

As the four captives struggle to survive and cooperate, the Picard double resumes command of the Enterprise, making increasingly erratic decisions—from out-of-character camaraderie to risky orders—that unsettle his officers. Both situations are part of a larger experiment by unseen aliens testing leadership, loyalty, and group dynamics.

StorySections.Text: Picard is reading in his quarters when a strange light engulfs him. Moments later, an identical Picard appears in bed, seemingly unaware that anything unusual has happened.

The real Picard finds himself in a confined chamber with Haro, Tholl, and Esoqq, all claiming to have been abducted from different locations. Each brings a distinct cultural perspective to their shared predicament.

Aboard the Enterprise, the duplicate Picard begins acting oddly—singing in Ten Forward, altering long-standing routines, and pressing for risky strategic exercises. Riker, Troi, and Data quietly compare notes on his behavior.

In the cell, tensions flare as Esoqq’s hunger and instincts clash with the others. Picard observes that their environment responds to their actions, suggesting they are being studied. He begins testing the limits of their prison.

Picard encourages his fellow captives to stage a mutiny against their unseen jailers, forcing the observers to reveal themselves. On the Enterprise, the crew confronts the duplicate just as the experiment reaches its climax.

The aliens, exposed, admit they sought to understand command and loyalty through live experimentation. Picard sternly explains why their methods were unacceptable before sending them away and resuming his rightful place on the Enterprise.

Title: Captain's Holiday
Antagonists: Ferengi treasure hunter Sovak
Vorgons Ajur and Boratus seeking the Tox Uthat
Summary:
Stressed and irritable after a series of missions, Picard is badgered by Troi and Riker into taking a much-needed vacation on the pleasure planet Risa. Hoping for quiet archaeological reading, he instead becomes entangled with Vash, a charming and morally flexible treasure hunter who is searching for a legendary 27th-century artifact called the Tox Uthat.

A Ferengi named Sovak and two mysterious visitors claiming to be time-traveling security agents from the future—Ajur and Boratus—also seek the Uthat. As alliances shift, Picard must determine whom to trust and decide the fate of a device said to be capable of stopping a star’s fusion reaction.

StorySections.Text: On the Enterprise, Troi and Riker conspire with Crusher and others to pressure a reluctant Picard into taking shore leave. He finally agrees to visit Risa.
Arriving on Risa, Picard tries to relax but is immediately approached by locals assuming he wants company, as well as by Vash, who quickly involves him in her search for the Tox Uthat.

Sovak, a Ferengi rival, confronts Picard and Vash, demanding any clues they possess. Ajur and Boratus appear, claiming to be from the future and insisting the Uthat must be preserved for their people.
Picard and Vash locate the hidden Uthat, realizing its destructive potential is very real. The various factions converge, each trying to claim the device for their own ends.
Refusing to let anyone exploit the Uthat, Picard uses a transporter to destroy it, calling the time-travelers’ bluff and leaving Sovak empty-handed.

As he prepares to leave Risa, Picard and Vash part on flirtatious but uncertain terms, hinting that their paths may cross again. Back on the Enterprise, the crew is delighted to see that the captain’s "quiet" holiday was anything but.

Title: Tin Man
Antagonists: Romulan race to reach the living starship
Tam Elbrun's unstable telepathy and isolation
Summary:
The Enterprise is ordered to escort Tam Elbrun, a brilliant but troubled Betazoid telepath, to make contact with a newly discovered living starship orbiting the star Beta Stromgren. The enormous organic vessel, nicknamed "Tin Man," appears to be ancient and emotionally distressed, radiating powerful energy waves.

Tam, burdened by the constant mental noise of other minds, feels an immediate, overwhelming connection with the alien ship, which he names Gomtuu. As a Romulan warbird races the Enterprise to claim or destroy the living vessel, Picard must keep Tam focused on peaceful communication while balancing Starfleet’s orders and the safety of his crew.

StorySections.Text: Starfleet Intelligence briefs Picard on the discovery of a living starship orbiting an unstable star. Tam Elbrun, with a history of controversial missions, comes aboard as the Federation’s best hope for communication.

Troi, who knew Tam from an earlier period, warns Picard about his difficulty filtering other minds. Tam’s abrasive behavior quickly puts him at odds with the crew, even as he senses Gomtuu’s loneliness.
A Romulan warbird appears, intent on reaching Gomtuu first. As both ships race toward Beta Stromgren, Tam’s connection with the living vessel deepens, and he insists that it is tired of existence.

When the Romulans open fire, Gomtuu reflexively unleashes a massive energy wave that destroys the warbird and cripples the Enterprise. Tam realizes that the ship acted in pain and self-defense, not malice.
Understanding that both he and Gomtuu are outcasts overwhelmed by contact with others, Tam chooses to join with the living starship, promising to guide it away from inhabited space.
Gomtuu and Tam disappear into the depths of space, leaving the Enterprise to limp away from the unstable star. Troi and Data reflect on Tam’s fate and the possibility that he has finally found peace.

Title: Hollow Pursuits
Antagonists: Barclay's holodeck addiction and avoidance of real-life duties
Dangerous instability in the Argus array systems
Summary:
Lieutenant Reginald Barclay, a shy and awkward engineer with a tendency to be late and withdrawn, becomes the subject of frustration for Geordi and other senior officers. When they investigate his behavior, they discover Barclay has been spending excessive time in the holodeck, running elaborate fantasies that caricature his shipmates and allow him to feel confident and in control.

At the same time, the Enterprise is trying to diagnose intermittent failures in the Argus sensor array. As the crises escalate, it becomes clear that Barclay’s imagination and outside-the-box thinking are key to understanding a subtle systems issue. Geordi must learn to guide rather than ridicule him, helping Barclay step out of the holodeck and into a meaningful role on the real bridge crew.

StorySections.Text: Geordi and Wesley complain about Barclay’s unreliability and poor performance. After another late arrival, Riker recommends transferring Barclay off the Enterprise.

Picard pushes Geordi to try mentoring Barclay instead of giving up on him. The crew soon discovers that Barclay is using the holodeck to create exaggerated versions of them, where he finally feels confident.
As minor malfunctions spread through ship systems linked to the Argus array, Barclay’s behavior becomes more secretive. Troi counsels him about the difference between fantasy and real connection.

Barclay’s insights into his own holodeck program give him a breakthrough idea about how the Argus array’s subsystems are interacting. He traces the problem to a subtle matter-anti-matter imbalance propagated through the system’s buffers.

Working under pressure, Barclay and Geordi implement a fix that stabilizes the array and saves the mission. Barclay then deletes most of his inappropriate holodeck programs, keeping only one as a reminder of how far he has come.
Barclay reports to duty on time and with renewed confidence. The senior staff, though still occasionally bemused by him, now appreciates the value of his unconventional mind.

Title: The Most Toys
Antagonists: Kivas Fajo's obsessive desire to collect unique objects
Lethal Varon-T disruptor
Summary:
While transporting a volatile substance known as hytritium, Data apparently dies in a shuttle explosion. In reality, he has been abducted by Kivas Fajo, an unscrupulous Zibalian trader and collector who wants Data as the crown jewel of his private museum of rare artifacts.

Held in an opulent but confined environment, Data refuses to perform for Fajo’s amusement or accept a life of captivity. On the Enterprise, Geordi and Wesley slowly uncover anomalies in the shuttle records that suggest the explosion was staged. As the crew races to unravel the truth, Data is forced to confront how far he will go to stop Fajo’s cruelty.

StorySections.Text: Data departs in a small shuttle to deliver hytritium to Fajo’s ship. Moments later, the shuttle explodes, and the Enterprise crew mourns Data’s apparent death.
Data awakens in Fajo’s collection room, surrounded by rare objects. Fajo smugly explains that Data is now part of his private collection and will be treated as both guest and property.
Fajo tries to break Data’s resolve with threats and psychological games, but Data refuses to participate. Varria, Fajo’s assistant, hints at her own desire to escape his control.
On the Enterprise, small inconsistencies in the sensor logs and shuttle debris lead Geordi and Wesley to suspect sabotage. Picard orders a deeper investigation into Fajo’s dealings.

When Varria attempts to help Data escape, Fajo kills her with a banned Varon-T disruptor. Concluding that Fajo will continue to murder, Data picks up the weapon and prepares to fire—only to be transported away at the last second as the Enterprise recovers him.

Aboard the Enterprise, Picard confronts Fajo with evidence of his crimes. In the transporter room, the disruptor is found still armed, leaving open the question of whether Data would truly have pulled the trigger.

Title: Sarek
Antagonists: Sarek's Bendii Syndrome causing emotional outbursts
Uncontrolled telepathic spillover affecting the crew
Summary:
The Enterprise is assigned to transport the legendary Vulcan ambassador Sarek to his final, long-awaited negotiation with the reclusive Legarans. As preparations proceed, unexplained emotional outbursts and conflicts begin to erupt among the crew, seemingly at odds with their usual professionalism.

Picard gradually discovers that Sarek is secretly suffering from Bendii Syndrome, a degenerative neurological disorder that causes intense, uncontrolled emotions to radiate telepathically. Determined not to let his illness derail the crucial talks, Sarek agrees to a mind-meld with Picard, allowing the ambassador to focus while Picard absorbs the overwhelming tide of suppressed Vulcan emotion.

StorySections.Text: Picard and the crew eagerly prepare to welcome Sarek aboard, aware of his historic role in Federation diplomacy. Sarek’s staff insists that he is fully capable of completing one last mission.
Subtle signs of strain appear as Sarek seems uncharacteristically distracted. Meanwhile, crew members begin having unprovoked arguments and emotional outbursts in Ten Forward and engineering.
A violent bar fight breaks out among normally level-headed officers. Troi, Crusher, and Picard piece together that the disturbances may be related to an external telepathic influence.
Picard confronts Sarek’s aides and learns of Bendii Syndrome. Sarek initially denies the extent of his illness, desperate to complete the Legaran negotiations that would crown his career.

To allow Sarek to function, he and Picard perform a mind-meld. Sarek conducts the negotiations successfully while Picard, shaking and weeping, channels decades of repressed Vulcan emotions—grief, love, and regret.
After the talks, Sarek thanks Picard and quietly acknowledges the illness he can no longer hide. Picard is left profoundly moved by the glimpse into Sarek’s inner life.
