Title: Ménage à Troi
Antagonists: DaiMon Tog's abduction of Lwaxana, Deanna, and Riker
Ferengi attempts to exploit Betazoid telepathy
Summary:
During shore leave on Betazed following a trade conference, Deanna Troi, her mother Lwaxana, and Commander Riker become entangled with DaiMon Tog, a Ferengi captain infatuated with Lwaxana. When she rebuffs his advances, Tog kidnaps all three and departs, hoping to use Lwaxana’s telepathy to gain an advantage in business negotiations.

Aboard the Ferengi ship, Lwaxana feigns interest in Tog to shield Deanna and Riker, while the captives look for a chance to escape. Back on the Enterprise, Picard tracks their disappearance and ultimately stages a dramatic, mock-jealous outburst over subspace to pressure Tog into returning his "beloved" Lwaxana.

StorySections.Text: At a Betazed conference, Lwaxana flirts, Riker relaxes, and Deanna tries to keep the peace. DaiMon Tog mistakes Lwaxana’s charm for genuine interest.
After Lwaxana rebukes Tog, he abducts her, Deanna, and Riker, transporting them to his ship. He reveals his plan to use Lwaxana’s telepathy to gain commercial leverage.
On the Ferengi vessel, Lwaxana pretends to reciprocate Tog’s affections to protect Deanna. Riker tries to sabotage the ship from within while keeping their captors off balance.
The Enterprise discovers their disappearance and traces subspace clues to Tog’s ship. Picard, Troi, and the crew work to narrow down the Ferengi’s location.

Picard contacts Tog and performs a theatrically passionate declaration of love for Lwaxana, "claiming" her as his and intimidating Tog into releasing his prisoners rather than risk conflict with Starfleet.
Safely back aboard the Enterprise, Lwaxana basks in Picard’s faux-romantic performance while Deanna and Riker share a bemused appreciation of how her mother turned the situation to their advantage.

Title: Transfigurations
Antagonists: Zalkonian fear of evolutionary change
John Doe's unstable transformation
Summary:
The Enterprise rescues an amnesiac humanoid from a crashed escape pod. As Dr. Crusher treats him, the patient—dubbed "John Doe"—begins to display remarkable regenerative abilities and bursts of luminous energy. His presence has a subtle, positive effect on the crew, including a newfound ease and confidence in Geordi La Forge’s personal life.

When a Zalkonian warship arrives, its captain identifies John as a fugitive undergoing a dangerous transformation. John slowly recalls that he is part of a new stage in his species’ evolution, one that the Zalkonian leadership seeks to suppress. His transformation accelerates, forcing a confrontation over whether he will be returned to his people or allowed to ascend.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise discovers a damaged escape pod near an unexplored region. A badly injured occupant is beamed aboard and rushed to sickbay.
Crusher stabilizes the patient but cannot identify his species. The man awakens with no memory and is provisionally named John Doe. Strange bursts of energy accompany his healing.
Geordi notices positive changes in his own confidence and mood after interacting with John. Elsewhere, John heals an injured crewman with a touch, further deepening the mystery.

A Zalkonian ship commanded by Captain Sunad confronts the Enterprise, demanding John’s return. John’s memories resurface, revealing that he and others like him are evolving into non-corporeal beings—an evolution the Zalkonians fear.

As Sunad attempts to suffocate the Enterprise crew with a weapon that removes their ability to process oxygen, John completes his transformation, neutralizes the attack, and reveals his new energy-based form. He then departs, promising that others of his kind will one day guide the Zalkonians when they are ready.
With the threat lifted, Geordi reflects on his own small "transformations," while the crew contemplates the awe-inspiring possibilities of evolution on a cosmic scale.

Title: The Best of Both Worlds, Part I
Antagonists: The Borg collective targeting the Federation
Assimilation of Picard into Locutus of Borg
Summary:
After a devastated Federation colony is discovered along the outer rim, Starfleet concludes that the Borg have resumed their advance toward Federation space. The Enterprise is assigned to investigate and, if possible, slow the Borg incursion. Commander Shelby, a driven specialist in anti-Borg tactics, comes aboard and immediately clashes with Riker over strategy and command style.

When the Enterprise encounters a Borg cube, the ship is outmatched. The Borg demand that Captain Picard surrender and accompany them. Eventually, they abduct him and transform him into Locutus of Borg, a spokesperson designed to facilitate the assimilation of humanity. Riker is left with command of the Enterprise and a terrible choice as the Borg cube continues toward Earth.

StorySections.Text: An away team surveys a planet whose entire population has been carved out of the ground, leaving a massive crater—an unmistakable sign of Borg activity.

The Enterprise takes aboard Commander Shelby, who has been developing tactical responses to the Borg. She and Riker immediately clash over his apparent reluctance to pursue promotion and riskier strategies.
The Enterprise makes first contact with a Borg cube on route to sector 001. The Borg demand Picard’s surrender, stating that resistance is futile and that humanity will be assimilated.

In a brief ground assault on the cube’s interior, the crew attempts to disrupt the Borg but fails to retrieve Picard before he is taken. The Borg ship withstands Starfleet’s attacks and continues its course toward Earth.

The Borg reveal Picard as Locutus, partially assimilated and speaking for the collective. Riker, now acting captain, devises a last-ditch plan to use the Enterprise’s deflector as a weapon against the cube.
As the Borg cube approaches Earth, Riker orders Worf to fire the modified deflector at Locutus’s ship, ending the episode on a cliffhanger.

Title: The Best of Both Worlds, Part II
Antagonists: The Borg cube advancing toward Earth
Locutus of Borg leading the assault on the Federation
Summary:
With Picard assimilated as Locutus of Borg, the Enterprise’s desperate weapon fails to stop the Borg cube, which continues toward Earth and annihilates a Starfleet armada at Wolf 359. Riker, now in full command, must balance his duty to stop the Borg with the hope of somehow rescuing his former captain.

As Shelby leads aggressive tactics and the crew searches for weaknesses in the Borg’s collective systems, Guinan reminds Riker that he cannot think of Picard as his captain anymore if he hopes to win. Riker authorizes a risky mission to beam aboard the cube, where Data and Worf capture Locutus and use his link to the collective to send a shutdown command—forcing the Borg into regeneration and ultimately destroying the cube before it reaches Earth.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise’s modified deflector blast fails to stop the Borg ship. Locutus coolly warns that resistance remains futile as the cube turns toward Earth.
News of the massacre at Wolf 359 reaches the Enterprise, including the loss of Admiral Hanson’s task force. Riker struggles with the weight of command while Shelby pushes for bold counterattacks.
Guinan counsels Riker to let go of the idea of saving Picard if he is going to save humanity. Riker promotes Shelby to first officer and begins planning a surgical strike against the cube.

Data and Worf beam aboard the Borg vessel, fight their way to Locutus, and beam him back to the Enterprise. Analyses show that Picard’s personality is partially submerged but still present beneath Borg conditioning.

Tapping into Locutus’s connection, Data injects a command that turns the cube’s regeneration subroutines against it. The Borg enter an uncontrolled regeneration cycle, and the cube self-destructs short of Earth.
Picard, rescued but deeply scarred, convalesces in his ready room and then at his family vineyard. Riker quietly reflects on how close the Federation came to annihilation.

Title: Family
Antagonists: Picard's unresolved trauma from Borg assimilation
Worf's discommendation and its stain on his family
Wesley and Beverly's lingering grief over Jack Crusher
Summary:
While the Enterprise undergoes repairs in Earth orbit after the Borg attack, several officers confront unfinished business at home. Picard returns to his family’s vineyard in La Barre, France, for an uneasy reunion with his older brother Robert, sister-in-law Marie, and nephew René. Their old sibling rivalries flare as Robert challenges Picard to confront the emotional damage left by his assimilation.

Aboard the Enterprise, Worf’s adoptive parents, Sergey and Helena Rozhenko, visit the ship and struggle to comfort their son after his discommendation by the Klingon High Council. Meanwhile, Beverly retrieves a long-stored message Jack Crusher recorded for their infant son, forcing her and Wesley to decide whether they are ready to face that part of their past.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise docks at Earth Station McKinley for extensive repairs. Picard quietly requests leave, surprising Riker with his desire to return home to France.

Picard arrives at his family vineyard and receives a frosty welcome from his older brother Robert, who resents Jean-Luc’s life among the stars. On the Enterprise, Sergey and Helena Rozhenko arrive, loudly proud of their son despite his discommendation.
Robert and Picard trade barbs about tradition, duty, and the value of starflight versus roots. Wesley, encouraged by Beverly, considers watching the recording his father made for him as a baby.

An argument between the Picard brothers spills out into a muddy vineyard brawl, finally cracking Jean-Luc’s stoicism. He breaks down, admitting his horror at having been used as Locutus. Robert pushes him—brutally but lovingly—to accept that he survived and can heal.

Worf struggles with the embarrassment of his parents’ open affection, but their unwavering support helps him accept that he is not alone. Wesley sits down with Beverly to watch Jack’s message, hearing his father’s pride and hopes for the future.
Picard prepares to return to the Enterprise with a measure of peace restored, while René dreams aloud of leaving the vineyard one day to explore the stars, hinting at another generation’s future.

Title: Brothers
Antagonists: Data's homing program overriding his free will
Lore's manipulation and jealousy
Summary:
On the way to deliver a critically injured boy to a starbase, the Enterprise suddenly veers off course when Data falls under the influence of an irresistible homing program. Seizing control of the ship with chilling efficiency, Data locks out the crew and pilots the Enterprise to a remote planet. There, he discovers his creator, Dr. Noonien Soong, alive and summoning him for an important upgrade.

Soong reveals that he has built an emotion chip for Data, but the homing signal inadvertently brings Lore as well. Lore’s resentment and instability resurface, and he turns Soong’s gift and frailty to his own advantage, endangering both his "brother" and their aging father.

StorySections.Text: A prank between brothers leaves young Willie Potts gravely injured by a poisonous organism. The Enterprise races toward Starbase 416 as Dr. Crusher fights to stabilize him.

Data suddenly freezes in a corridor, then proceeds to the bridge and uses flawless mimicry of Picard’s voice and command codes to seize control. He locks out all crew input and diverts the ship, baffling Picard and his senior officers.

The Enterprise arrives at an uncharted planet, where Data beams down alone to meet Dr. Noonien Soong. Soong explains that a pre-programmed homing signal compelled Data’s actions, intended to summon him for a long-planned upgrade.

To everyone’s shock, Lore arrives, drawn by the same signal. He oscillates between feigned remorse and bitter accusation, blaming Soong for abandoning him and resenting Data for being "the perfect son."

Soong reveals an emotion chip meant for Data, hoping to help him grow closer to humanity. Lore tricks the weakened Soong, takes the chip for himself, and attacks Data before fleeing, leaving his father mortally wounded.
Data returns control of the Enterprise in time to save Willie. Reflecting on Soong’s death and Lore’s theft of the chip, he considers what it truly means to be brothers.

Title: Suddenly Human
Antagonists: Cultural conflict between the Talarians and the Federation over Jono's custody
Jono's trauma from witnessing his parents' deaths
Summary:
Responding to a distress call from a damaged Talarian vessel, the Enterprise rescues several injured youths, including a human boy who has been raised as a Talarian named Jono. Records reveal he is Jeremiah Rossa, a Federation admiral’s grandson long presumed dead after a border conflict. The discovery ignites a custody dispute between Starfleet and Jono’s Talarian foster father, Captain Endar.

Picard reluctantly assumes the role of mentor to Jono and finds that the boy identifies wholly as Talarian, clinging to his adopted culture and resenting any attempt to "reclaim" him. As buried trauma surfaces, Picard must decide whether to assert Federation claims or respect Jono’s chosen identity—even if that means returning him to the people who once attacked his home.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise answers a distress call from a Talarian training ship. Among the survivors is a human teenager who behaves like a Talarian warrior and reacts violently to human touch.
Beverly discovers that the boy is genetically human, and Starfleet records identify him as Jeremiah Rossa. Troi and Picard realize they are dealing with a child caught between two cultures.
Endar arrives, insisting that Jono is his legally adopted son under Talarian law. Picard, still uneasy about children, agrees to act as Jono’s guardian temporarily to help him adjust.
Picard tries to expose Jono to human customs, but the boy reacts with confusion and anger. Memories of his parents’ deaths and the Talarian attack begin to surface, deepening his inner conflict.

Overwhelmed by guilt at feeling disloyal to Endar, Jono attempts to kill Picard in his sleep—a Talarian response to unbearable dishonor. Rather than punish him harshly, Picard recognizes the depth of Jono’s psychological turmoil.
Picard decides to return Jono to Endar, arguing that the boy’s well-being must come before Federation claims. Jono takes a step toward healing by openly acknowledging both sides of his heritage.

Title: Remember Me
Antagonists: Collapsing warp-bubble universe trapping Beverly
Experimental warp-field modification gone wrong
Summary:
While the Enterprise visits Starbase 133, Beverly Crusher welcomes her aging mentor Dr. Dalen Quaice aboard. Shortly afterward, Quaice vanishes without a trace—and no one else remembers he ever existed. As more crew members disappear from records and memory, Beverly finds herself the only person who recalls the missing, even as reality itself seems to shrink around her.

Unbeknownst to her, a warp-field experiment Wesley is conducting has accidentally created a bubble universe centered on Beverly’s thoughts about loss. Trapped inside, she must reason her way to the truth while the real Enterprise crew, aided by the mysterious Traveler, struggles to reopen the gateway before her pocket reality collapses completely.

StorySections.Text: At Starbase 133, Beverly greets Dr. Quaice and discusses the loneliness of outliving friends and colleagues. Later, she goes to check on him and finds his quarters empty.
Beverly reports Quaice missing, but the computer and crew have no record he was ever aboard. As she insists otherwise, subtle changes in crew complement begin to appear.
More people vanish from Beverly’s reality, and she alone remembers them. The Enterprise seems less populated, but everyone else treats the reduced crew as perfectly normal.

Attempting to analyze the phenomenon, Beverly discovers that the universe she inhabits is literally contracting. She hypothesizes that she is trapped in some kind of warp bubble and that the Enterprise she knows is not the real one.

In the real universe, Wesley and the Traveler realize Beverly is inside a warp-created pocket reality formed around her thoughts. As her universe dwindles to a single corridor, a vortex appears in Engineering—the last exit.

Beverly leaps into the vortex and finds herself back on the actual Enterprise, surrounded by crew who have no idea what she just experienced. She quietly confirms the correct crew complement, reassured that she is truly home.

Title: Legacy
Antagonists: Civil war on Turkana IV between the Coalition and the Alliance
Ishara Yar's hidden agenda on behalf of the Coalition
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a distress call from the freighter Arcos, only to arrive as the ship explodes. The surviving crew members escape in a pod that crash-lands on Turkana IV, the lawless Federation colony that is the late Tasha Yar’s homeworld. Beaming down, Riker’s away team finds itself caught between two warring factions, the Coalition and the Alliance.

Coalition leader Hayne offers help in exchange for Federation technology, introducing Ishara Yar—Tasha’s younger sister—as liaison. Data and the crew, still mourning Tasha, are drawn to Ishara, who seems eager to leave her violent life behind. But as the rescue mission unfolds, it becomes clear that Ishara’s loyalties are more complicated than they appear.

StorySections.Text: The Arcos breaks apart in orbit above Turkana IV. The Enterprise detects an escape pod forced to land amid the chaos of a world that seceded from the Federation years earlier.
Riker leads an away team into the urban war zone and is quickly surrounded by Coalition fighters. Hayne offers cooperation if the Enterprise will help his faction against the rival Alliance.
Hayne introduces Ishara Yar, who claims to want a different life than the one she has known. Data, who still feels a bond to Tasha, is especially receptive to her.

Using an implant that allows the Coalition to track her, Ishara guides the Enterprise teams through Alliance territory to find the hostages. Meanwhile, subtle inconsistencies in her story begin to trouble the crew.

At the height of the rescue, Ishara attempts to use the operation to cripple the Alliance’s defenses, prioritizing her faction’s victory over the Federation’s neutrality. Picard exposes the deception and disables her before more damage is done.
With the hostages rescued, Ishara is returned to Turkana IV. Data acknowledges that, though she betrayed their trust, she remains part of Tasha’s legacy—and that loyalty cannot be forced.

Title: Reunion
Antagonists: Poisoning of Chancellor K'mpec and the destabilized Klingon succession
Duras's treachery and murder of K'Ehleyr
Summary:
The Enterprise is summoned by a Klingon battlecruiser carrying Chancellor K’mpec and Ambassador K’Ehleyr. K’mpec reveals to Picard that he has been fatally poisoned and demands that Picard serve as Arbiter of Succession to determine which of the two claimants—Gowron or Duras—used dishonorable means to secure power.

K’Ehleyr, now an ambassador, also brings Worf a shocking revelation: a young son, Alexander, whom she never told him about. As Picard delays the Klingon rites to buy time for an investigation, tensions escalate. When K’Ehleyr uncovers the truth about Duras’s past treachery, he murders her, forcing Worf to choose between Starfleet discipline and Klingon vengeance.

StorySections.Text: A Klingon ship approaches the Enterprise with shields up. Aboard is K’Ehleyr, Worf’s former lover, escorting a visibly weakened Chancellor K’mpec, who confides that he has been poisoned.
K’mpec insists that Picard become Arbiter of Succession, charged with exposing his killer among the two contenders, Gowron and Duras. Picard reluctantly accepts the dangerous political role.
K’Ehleyr introduces Worf to Alexander, their son, whose existence she concealed for fear of Klingon expectations. Worf, still discommended, struggles to see a place for the boy in Klingon society.

During a ceremony to confirm K’mpec’s death, a hidden bomb kills several Klingons, proving that one of the rivals is willing to use cowardly tactics. Picard stalls the succession while forensic work points toward Duras.

K’Ehleyr investigates Worf’s discommendation, deducing that Duras framed Worf’s father to hide his own family’s treason. Duras kills her to protect the secret, prompting Worf to challenge him under the Right of Vengeance and ultimately slay him in single combat.

Picard reprimands Worf for taking revenge while in Starfleet uniform but acknowledges Klingon law. Worf places Alexander in the care of Sergey and Helena Rozhenko, hoping to spare his son the burden of Klingon politics—for now.

Title: Future Imperfect
Antagonists: Illusory future created from Riker's memories and fears
Barash's desperate use of simulation technology to avoid loneliness
Summary:
After leading an away team to investigate a possible Romulan base near the Neutral Zone, Riker is overcome by gas and wakes up sixteen years in the future. He is told he has a teenage son named Jean-Luc, that he is now captain of the Enterprise, and that his memory has been damaged by a virus. At first, the scenario seems plausible, but inconsistencies in people’s behavior and gaps in his own memories raise Riker’s suspicions.

As the illusion unravels, Riker discovers that the "future" is a layered holosimulation built from his memories by a lonely alien boy named Barash, who has been living alone for years with only automated equipment for company. Riker must navigate nested deceptions, including an appearance by the Romulan Tomalak, before persuading Barash to trust the real Enterprise and accept rescue.

StorySections.Text: Riker’s birthday celebration is cut short when Picard orders him to lead an away team to a fog-filled outpost. The team is rendered unconscious by methane gas.

Riker awakens in sickbay, apparently sixteen years later, with Picard explaining that he has been in a coma. Troi, older and more formal, gently confirms the story, while a boy named Jean-Luc calls Riker "Dad."

As Riker resumes duties as captain, he notes oddities—Data’s behavior, missing details in his son’s life, and a suspiciously convenient memory loss. A proposed treaty signing with the Romulans feels wrong.

When Tomalak appears and events become increasingly artificial, Riker forces the scenario to break, revealing that he is inside a simulation built from his own memories. The "son" is actually Barash, alone on a hidden outpost.

Even after the first simulation collapses, a second illusion briefly overlays reality, testing Riker’s resolve. He finally sees through all of it and reaches out to Barash as himself, not as a fabricated future father.
The real Enterprise arrives, and Riker offers Barash a chance to leave the dead outpost and come aboard, promising that Starfleet will help him find a place and a future of his own.

Title: Final Mission
Antagonists: Harsh desert moon environment after the shuttle crash
Energy-based guardian protecting the water source
Summary:
On the eve of his departure for Starfleet Academy, Wesley Crusher accompanies Picard on a shuttle trip to mediate a mining dispute in the Pentarus system. Their pilot, the rough-edged transport captain Dirgo, insists his worn shuttle can handle a dangerous asteroid field—but a systems failure forces them to crash-land on a nearby desert moon.

With the Enterprise diverted to deal with a deadly radiation crisis elsewhere, Wesley, Picard, and Dirgo struggle to survive brutal heat and dwindling supplies. They discover a cave with a water source guarded by an energy field that lashes out when attacked. An attempt to break through mortally wounds Picard and kills Dirgo, leaving Wesley to keep his captain alive while finding a way past the guardian.

StorySections.Text: Wesley learns he has finally been accepted into Starfleet Academy. Picard invites him on a final mission—a diplomatic trip to settle a miners’ dispute—as a parting honor.

A distress call about a radiation-leaking barge forces the Enterprise to depart while Picard and Wesley travel with Dirgo. The aging shuttle suffers a critical failure and crash-lands on a barren moon.
With limited water and no immediate hope of rescue, the trio treks toward a mountain range where sensors detect a possible source of life-supporting resources.

They find a well inside a cavern, but an energy guardian reacts violently to phaser fire, injuring Picard and repelling Dirgo. A second reckless attempt costs Dirgo his life and leaves Picard gravely wounded.

Drawing on his training and understanding of field dynamics, Wesley reprograms his equipment to redirect the guardian’s energy and temporarily neutralize it, granting access to water until the Enterprise locates them.
Rescued at last, Wesley shares a quiet moment with Picard, who tells him he will be missed and expresses pride in the man Wesley is becoming as he leaves for the Academy.

Title: The Loss
Antagonists: Two-dimensional lifeforms dragging the Enterprise
Troi's sudden loss of empathic abilities and crisis of identity
Summary:
The Enterprise becomes trapped in a vast, invisible field that resists all attempts to break free. As the ship is inexorably pulled along, Troi collapses under intense pain and awakens to find that her empathic abilities have disappeared. At the same time, crew members like Janet Brooks seek Troi’s counsel for their grief, only to find her cynical and withdrawn.

As Data and the others determine that the Enterprise is caught in the wake of two-dimensional lifeforms migrating through space, Troi struggles with the loss of a faculty that has defined both her identity and her role aboard ship. She must rebuild a sense of self as a counselor without telepathy while helping the crew avert destruction by redirecting the migrating entities.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise encounters a strange region of space and begins to experience mild turbulence. Troi is suddenly overwhelmed by pain and collapses in her quarters.
In sickbay, Beverly discovers no physical damage, but Troi finds her empathic sense gone. She is devastated to realize that a core part of her identity has vanished without explanation.

As the ship becomes stuck in an invisible drag, Data and Geordi discover that the Enterprise is being pulled along by a vast field of two-dimensional lifeforms. Meanwhile, Troi lashes out at colleagues and patients, insisting she can no longer serve as counselor.

Guinan and Riker challenge Troi’s self-pity, pointing out that her training and compassion—not just her empathic powers—make her valuable. Troi reluctantly returns to duty, attempting to help Janet Brooks confront the loss of her husband.

By interpreting the behavior of the two-dimensional beings as migratory rather than hostile, the crew develops a plan to use a nearby cosmic string fragment to divert their course—and thus free the Enterprise—without destroying the lifeforms.
The plan works, and as the Enterprise escapes, Troi’s empathic abilities gradually return. Having confronted life without them, she has a renewed sense of who she is beyond her Betazoid gifts.

Title: Data's Day
Antagonists: Apparent death and disappearance of Ambassador T'Pel
Romulan subterfuge at the Neutral Zone
Summary:
In a letter to cyberneticist Bruce Maddox, Data narrates an ordinary day aboard the Enterprise that becomes anything but routine. He helps Chief O’Brien and botanist Keiko Ishikawa navigate pre-wedding jitters, tries to understand the nuances of human social rituals, and observes how his shipmates respond to the upcoming ceremony.

At the same time, the Enterprise transports a Vulcan ambassador, T’Pel, to a rendezvous at the Romulan Neutral Zone. When a transporter accident seemingly kills T’Pel, an investigation raises troubling questions. Data’s calm observation of events frames both the joyful chaos of the O’Briens’ wedding and the discovery that T’Pel is actually a Romulan spy who successfully defects to a warbird.

StorySections.Text: Data begins composing a detailed log to Commander Bruce Maddox, offering to describe a typical day in his existence aboard the Enterprise.

Keiko abruptly calls off her wedding to Miles O’Brien, leaving the chief heartbroken and Data confused. Troi and others help Data understand that emotional support, not logic, is what his friends need.

The Enterprise welcomes Ambassador T’Pel for a diplomatic mission to the Romulan Neutral Zone. Data juggles dance lessons with Dr. Crusher for the wedding reception and his bridge duties during the delicate transit.
During a transporter exchange with a Romulan warbird, T’Pel appears to die in a beam malfunction. Data assists in the investigation, detecting irregularities in the transporter logs.

Confronting the warbird, Picard learns that T’Pel is alive and revealed as a Romulan operative who has defected. Outgunned, the Enterprise withdraws. Later, Keiko and Miles reconcile and go through with their wedding, which Data dutifully participates in and records.
Data concludes his report to Maddox, noting that while he may not fully understand human emotions, he can observe their patterns and cherish his friends’ happiness.

Title: The Wounded
Antagonists: Captain Maxwell's rogue attacks on Cardassian ships
Cardassian military's secret rearmament along the border
Summary:
A fragile peace with the Cardassians is threatened when Captain Benjamin Maxwell of the USS Phoenix begins attacking Cardassian vessels without authorization. The Enterprise is ordered to intercept the Phoenix, with a Cardassian delegation led by Gul Macet observing Picard’s every move.

As tensions mount, Chief O’Brien must confront his own wartime trauma and prejudice, having served under Maxwell during the bloody conflict. When Picard finally catches up with the Phoenix, he must weigh Maxwell’s claims that the Cardassians are secretly rearming against the urgent need to prevent another war.

StorySections.Text: A Cardassian warship unexpectedly hails the Enterprise—under a flag of truce. Gul Macet arrives to inform Picard that a Federation starship has attacked his people.
Starfleet orders Picard to stop the USS Phoenix and prevent any further incidents. A visibly uncomfortable O’Brien recalls his previous service under Captain Maxwell during the war.
The Phoenix continues to outmaneuver Cardassian ships and destroys several vessels that Maxwell claims were carrying military supplies. O’Brien and Macet debate the scars left by the conflict.

Picard finally confronts Maxwell, who insists that the Cardassians are secretly rearming and using civilian transports as cover. Picard demands proof, but Maxwell has only intuition and fragmented evidence.

O’Brien reaches Maxwell through shared memories of their losses, persuading him to stand down. Picard escorts the Phoenix home and warns Gul Macet that the Federation will not ignore any future duplicity.

As the Cardassians depart, O’Brien acknowledges that while the war is over, the emotional wounds remain. Picard quietly acknowledges that Maxwell may have been more right than Starfleet is ready to admit.

Title: Devil's Due
Antagonists: Ardra's claim to own Ventax II by ancient contract
Technological tricks used to mimic demonic powers
Summary:
The Enterprise answers a distress call from Ventax II, a world in panic over the prophesied return of a being called Ardra. According to local legend, Ardra once promised a millennium of peace and prosperity in exchange for ownership of the planet’s people when the term expired. Now, as that deadline arrives, a glamorous woman with apparent supernatural powers appears, claiming to be Ardra and demanding the world’s surrender.

Picard is skeptical and suspects advanced technology instead of magic. As Ardra intimidates Ventaxian leaders and even transforms her appearance to resemble devils from multiple cultures, Picard invokes contractual law and turns the confrontation into a courtroom drama—using the Enterprise’s systems to expose her illusions and reveal her as a con artist.

StorySections.Text: Picard and the crew arrive at Ventax II to find the once-tranquil society in chaos as leaders prepare to submit to a prophecy of demonic repossession.
Ardra appears with thunderclaps and shape-shifting theatrics, demonstrating powers that include earthquakes, force fields, and teleportation. She claims the contract is due and the planet is hers.

Picard challenges Ardra’s claim, arguing that the Federation cannot recognize a contract built on supernatural coercion. She counters by seizing control of the Enterprise’s systems to prove her dominance.
Data, acting as an impartial arbiter, presides over a legal hearing. Behind the scenes, Geordi and others search for technological signatures that could explain Ardra’s "magic."

Picard uses the Enterprise’s control systems—quietly reclaimed by his crew—to duplicate Ardra’s illusions, demonstrating that her feats are purely technological. Data rules against Ardra, voiding her claim.
Ardra is taken into custody as a common criminal, and Ventax II is freed from its self-imposed fear. Picard reflects on how belief can make even rational societies vulnerable to exploitation.

Title: Clues
Antagonists: Paxan xenophobic species determined to remain hidden
Data's enforced deception of the crew
Summary:
During a routine survey mission, the Enterprise passes through a seemingly benign wormhole and the crew is briefly knocked unconscious. Upon awakening, Data states they were only out for 30 seconds—but small inconsistencies begin to surface: botany lab samples show a full day’s growth, Worf’s wrist is mysteriously broken and healed, and stellar positions do not align with the official log.

As Picard presses for answers, it becomes clear that Data is concealing the truth under direct orders that conflict with his usual honesty. Eventually, the ship encounters the Paxans, a xenophobic species that uses memory wipes to conceal its existence. The crew must decide whether to risk another mind erasure and Data’s continued secrecy to avoid provoking a powerful, isolationist civilization.

StorySections.Text: The crew enjoys a lighthearted day on the holodeck when the Enterprise encounters a mysterious wormhole, knocking everyone unconscious. Data alone remains unaffected.
Data reports that only seconds have passed, but Crusher’s lab and other minor details suggest otherwise. Picard grows suspicious of the discrepancies.
As more evidence accumulates—aging in plant samples, altered star positions, Worf’s injury—Picard confronts Data, who continues to evade direct answers, clearly bound by another obligation.

The Enterprise is pulled back into contact with the Paxans, who reveal themselves through a possessed Troi. They explain that they previously wiped the crew’s memories and ordered Data to maintain the deception.

Picard persuades the Paxans to try one more memory wipe and allow the Enterprise to leave, arguing that discovery was accidental and that the Federation has no wish to threaten them. Data agrees to resume his burden of secrecy if it means saving the ship.
Time is "reset" again. This time, the clues are successfully removed, and the Enterprise continues on its way—while Data quietly carries the knowledge of a day his friends will never remember.

Title: First Contact
Antagonists: Krola's fear-driven resistance to open contact
Societal panic over the revelation of extraterrestrial life
Summary:
On the warp-capable world of Malcor III, an undercover first contact mission goes wrong when Riker, disguised as a Malcorian, is injured and taken to a hospital. Medical scans reveal anatomical differences that expose him as an alien, throwing the secret Federation observation effort into crisis.

Picard and Troi approach Chancellor Durken and science minister Mirasta Yale openly, revealing the truth about the Federation and offering peaceful contact. While Mirasta is thrilled to learn humanity is not alone, Durken worries about the destabilizing effect on his world. Security official Krola, fearing cultural annihilation, attempts to sabotage the process by framing the aliens as dangerous invaders.

StorySections.Text: Riker, in Malcorian disguise, conducts reconnaissance when an accident sends him to a hospital. Doctors quickly notice his unusual physiology.
As hospital staff debate what Riker’s presence means, Picard beams directly into Chancellor Durken’s office, revealing himself and the Federation’s observation mission.
Picard offers friendship and technological guidance once Malcor III is ready. Mirasta Yale embraces the chance to explore the stars, while Durken voices fears about social upheaval.
Security official Krola, convinced that contact will destroy Malcorian identity, plots to frame the Federation by staging Riker’s "murder" as an alien attack.
Picard exposes Krola’s deception and rescues Riker. Durken, recognizing that his society is not yet ready for open contact, declines the Federation’s offer—for now.
Mirasta chooses to leave with the Enterprise, unable to return to a world that has rejected the stars. Picard promises that when Malcor III is ready, the Federation will be there.

Title: Galaxy's Child
Antagonists: Spaceborne lifeform's offspring draining the Enterprise
Misunderstanding between Geordi and the real Leah Brahms
Summary:
Geordi eagerly anticipates the visit of Dr. Leah Brahms, the real warp-drive designer whose holodeck avatar he once used to solve an engineering crisis. He imagines meeting a kindred spirit, but the actual Leah turns out to be guarded and critical, especially after discovering how Geordi used her likeness in a private simulation.

Meanwhile, the Enterprise investigates a massive spaceborne lifeform that feeds on stellar energy. When a defensive phaser burst inadvertently kills the adult creature, the crew realizes it was pregnant—and a newborn attaches itself to the Enterprise, draining the ship’s power as if the vessel were its mother.

StorySections.Text: Geordi prepares for Dr. Leah Brahms’s visit, rehearsing introductions and expecting a warm meeting based on his holodeck experience of her personality.
Leah arrives and quickly clashes with Geordi over modifications he has made to "her" engines. At the same time, the Enterprise encounters a massive, whale-like space creature.

A misinterpreted move by the creature leads the Enterprise to fire in self-defense, killing it. Sensors then detect a living embryo, and a newborn lifeform soon latches onto the ship, drawing energy from the warp systems.

As the "baby" continues to feed and threatens to drain the Enterprise, Geordi and Leah are forced to work closely together. She discovers the holodeck program and feels violated by how her image was used.

Geordi apologizes and acknowledges the distinction between fantasy and reality. Together, he and Leah devise a way to "wean" the creature by simulating a stellar food source, guiding it to a nearby nebula where it can feed safely.

With the crisis resolved, Leah and Geordi reach a tentative understanding. The spaceborn newborn swims off toward the nebula, and Geordi is left with a more mature view of hero worship and boundaries.

Title: Night Terrors
Antagonists: Tyken's Rift trapping the Enterprise
Crew-wide REM sleep deprivation causing hallucinations
Summary:
The Enterprise finds the USS Brattain adrift near a mysterious rift in space. Its crew are all dead after turning on one another in a fit of collective madness, with only a traumatized Betazoid survivor left catatonic. Soon after, the Enterprise becomes trapped in the same region, unable to generate enough energy to escape.

As days pass, the crew are unable to achieve REM sleep. Hallucinations, paranoia, and violent outbursts spread through the ship. Only Data, who does not sleep, remains fully functional. Troi, plagued by a recurring dream of floating in a void with two moons and a guiding voice, gradually realizes that another trapped species is trying to communicate the key to escaping the rift.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise locates the Brattain, apparently intact but completely unresponsive. An away team discovers the crew dead, many killed by their own shipmates.
Bringing the psychic survivor aboard triggers strange nightmares for Troi. Attempts to tow the Brattain fail when a strange energy phenomenon traps both ships.
As time passes, crewmembers become short-tempered and forgetful. Crusher discovers that no one has entered REM sleep since encountering the rift, explaining the growing instability.
Troi repeatedly dreams of herself drifting in a green void toward two moons, hearing a disembodied voice. Worf experiences a rare bout of intense fear, underscoring the crew’s fraying mental state.

Piecing together Troi’s visions and the rift’s properties, Data realizes that another ship is trapped on the other side, trying to tell them to create a controlled hydrogen explosion as a signal. Data executes the plan while the exhausted crew teeters on collapse.
The resulting detonation opens a pathway out of the rift, freeing both ships. Once normal sleep resumes, the Enterprise crew slowly recovers from their shared ordeal.

Title: Identity Crisis
Antagonists: Infectious organism rewriting away team members' DNA
Psychological terror of losing one's identity
Summary:
Geordi is visited by his former crewmate Lieutenant Susanna Leijten, who served with him on the USS Victory. Several officers from a past away mission to the planet Tarchannen III have mysteriously deserted Starfleet. Leijten fears that she and Geordi may be next, as both begin exhibiting strange physical symptoms.

Investigation reveals that an unknown organism encountered on Tarchannen III is gradually rewriting their DNA, transforming them into nocturnal, chameleon-like creatures compelled to return to the planet. As Geordi succumbs to the change and flees into the darkened terrain, the crew must find a way to reverse the process before his sense of self disappears entirely.

StorySections.Text: Leijten arrives on the Enterprise with disturbing news: officers who once explored Tarchannen III with her and Geordi have vanished, leaving behind clues of strange behavior.
As they review logs from the original mission, both Leijten and Geordi experience tremors and patches of discolored skin. Crusher detects unusual cellular changes in their DNA.
Data enhances holodeck recordings of the Tarchannen surface, revealing shadowy figures in the background—evidence of other transformed beings that had gone unnoticed at the time.
Leijten begins to transform but retains enough consciousness for Crusher to stabilize her. Geordi, however, escapes to Tarchannen III under the influence of an irresistible homing instinct.
Using Leijten’s partial cure, the crew tracks Geordi among the camouflaged creatures and administers treatment, slowly restoring his human form and memories.
Recovering aboard the Enterprise, Geordi and Leijten reflect on how close they came to losing their identities forever, and the unknown alien life still lurking on Tarchannen III.

Title: The Nth Degree
Antagonists: Uncontrolled expansion of Barclay's intellect and influence over the Enterprise
Unknown intentions of the Cytherians
Summary:
Investigating a powerful alien probe at the edge of Federation space, the Enterprise is exposed to an energy surge that strikes Lieutenant Reg Barclay. Soon afterward, Barclay’s intelligence begins to increase exponentially. He solves complex problems effortlessly, rewrites engineering protocols, and even outperforms Data in certain tasks.

As his transformation accelerates, Barclay links himself directly to the Enterprise computer and seizes control of the ship, redirecting it toward an uncharted region of space. The crew fears he has been taken over by a hostile force, but the truth—when they finally encounter the Cytherians—proves far more benign and expansive than they imagined.

StorySections.Text: During a mission to investigate a mysterious array, Barclay fumbles his lines in a community production of Cyrano de Bergerac, underscoring his usual social anxiety.
An alien probe disables a shuttle carrying Barclay and Geordi. Back on the Enterprise, Barclay begins showing striking intellectual improvements and confidence.
Barclay’s enhancements allow him to optimize ship systems far beyond normal efficiency, impressing and worrying his colleagues. Troi observes that his personality is also shifting.
After integrating himself into the main computer via a neural interface, Barclay commandeers the Enterprise, taking it on a high-warp journey without Picard’s consent.

The ship arrives at the center of the Cytherians’ sphere of influence, where a friendly being explains that their species prefers to bring explorers to them. The process that empowered Barclay was their way of guiding the Enterprise safely.
The Cytherians reverse Barclay’s enhancements, leaving him his normal self but with greater self-respect. The Enterprise departs with a wealth of new knowledge from its unique visit.

Title: Qpid
Antagonists: Q's meddling "lesson" about Picard's romantic life
Sir Guy of Gisbourne as the in-story antagonist
Summary:
As Picard prepares to deliver a lecture at an archaeology symposium aboard the Enterprise, he is surprised by the arrival of Vash, the roguish treasure hunter he met on Risa. Their unresolved feelings mix awkwardly with Starfleet protocol and the presence of Picard’s crew. Q suddenly appears, declaring that he owes Picard a favor and deciding—unasked—to help Picard with his "problems of the heart." 

To prove that Picard’s attachment to Vash conflicts with his controlled persona, Q transforms the senior staff into characters in a Robin Hood fantasy, casting Picard as the outlaw hero and Vash as Maid Marian. Facing the sadistic Sir Guy of Gisbourne, Picard must risk humiliation and injury to save Vash, while she contrives her own deal with Q.

StorySections.Text: Picard practices his archaeological presentation when Vash unexpectedly arrives, catching him off guard in front of his crew and stirring memories of their previous adventure.
Q appears in Picard’s quarters, claiming he wants to repay his debt for Picard’s help with the Continuum. Picard wants no part of Q’s "assistance," especially in matters of love.
During a reception, Q snaps his fingers and transports Picard and his senior staff into a Medieval Sherwood Forest scenario, complete with costumes and weapons. Vash is imprisoned as Maid Marian.
Picard tries to mount a rescue with his bemused "Merry Men" crew, while Vash plays along with Sir Guy to avoid execution and look for an angle to escape.

Picard ultimately surrenders himself to save Vash from death, demonstrating that he is willing to risk everything for her. Q, satisfied that Picard has proven his devotion and still amused by chaos, ends the game.
Back on the Enterprise, Vash decides to leave with Q to explore the cosmos by his unconventional means, while Picard and his crew are left to contemplate what that choice says about both of them.

Title: The Drumhead
Antagonists: Admiral Satie's escalating witch hunt for traitors
Paranoia and erosion of civil liberties aboard the Enterprise
Summary:
After a suspected act of sabotage damages the Enterprise’s warp core during the visit of a Klingon exchange officer, Starfleet sends retired Admiral Norah Satie—famed for exposing conspiracies—to investigate. What begins as a focused inquiry into J’Dan, a Klingon with Romulan ties, soon widens into a sweeping hunt for disloyalty throughout the crew.

Ensign Simon Tarses becomes the focus of suspicion when it is revealed that he lied about his part-Romulan heritage on his Starfleet application. As Satie’s hearings grow more accusatory and intrusive, Picard recognizes that the true threat is no longer sabotage, but the abandonment of Federation principles in the name of security.

StorySections.Text: A warp-core coolant leak and security breach linked to Klingon exchange officer J’Dan trigger a formal investigation, drawing Starfleet’s attention.
Admiral Satie arrives with her aides, including the empathic Betazoid Inquisitor. She quickly elicits a confession from J’Dan about passing information to the Romulans.

Instead of ending the case, Satie broadens the inquiry, questioning crew members about their backgrounds and loyalties. Tarses, a young medical technician, comes under scrutiny for misrepresenting his ancestry.

Public hearings turn into a spectacle as Satie attacks Tarses’s character based on speculation rather than proof. Worf, initially supportive of the hard line on security, begins to see echoes of past injustices.

Picard challenges Satie in open session, quoting her own father’s words about vigilance against abuses of power. As she lashes out at Picard and even the Federation itself, Starfleet observers recognize that Satie has gone too far and terminate the proceedings.
Satie leaves the Enterprise in disgrace. Picard and Worf reflect on how fear can erode civil liberties if not checked by courage and principle.

Title: Half a Life
Antagonists: Kaelon II's cultural law requiring ritual suicide at age 60
Social pressure on Timicin to conform to the Resolution
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts Dr. Timicin of Kaelon II, who is testing a radical stellar experiment to save his dying sun. Lwaxana Troi, aboard as a diplomatic guest, is immediately drawn to the reserved scientist, and the two form an unexpected, tender relationship. When Timicin’s test fails, he faces both professional disappointment and a looming personal deadline—the Kaelon tradition known as the Resolution, in which all citizens must end their lives at age sixty.

Lwaxana is horrified by the custom and urges Timicin to reject it, offering asylum and a chance to continue his work. Timicin must decide whether to defy the deeply ingrained beliefs of his world, bringing shame on his family, or return home to die as expected, leaving behind both his research and his new love.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise arrives at a star near Kaelon II so Dr. Timicin can test a procedure to re-ignite his people’s dying sun. Lwaxana arrives, complaining about the solemnity of the mission.
Timicin’s experiment shows promise but ultimately destabilizes the test star. As he grapples with failure, Lwaxana cuts through his formality with candid flirtation and empathy.

Lwaxana learns that Timicin is approaching the age of the Resolution, when all Kaelons voluntarily end their lives in a ceremonial gathering. She is appalled and questions how a civilized world can require such a practice.

Encouraged by Lwaxana and Picard, Timicin considers seeking Federation asylum to continue his research and live beyond sixty. Kaelon authorities respond with outrage, threatening diplomatic consequences.
Timicin’s daughter appeals to him, torn between love and cultural expectation. Ultimately, Timicin decides to honor the Resolution, believing he cannot shatter the fabric of his society overnight.
Lwaxana chooses to accompany Timicin back to Kaelon II so he will not face his final ceremony alone, showing respect for his choice even as she mourns it.

Title: The Host
Antagonists: Political tensions between the moons of Peliar Zel
Medical and ethical complications of the Trill symbiont transfer
Summary:
Dr. Beverly Crusher begins a romantic relationship with Odan, a charming Trill ambassador mediating a dispute between the moons of Peliar Zel. When Odan is gravely injured, Beverly discovers that he is not a single individual but a joined being: a humanoid host body carrying a long-lived symbiont.

With Odan’s host dying and the negotiations at a critical stage, the symbiont is temporarily implanted into Riker so the mission can continue. Beverly struggles to reconcile her feelings as Odan inhabits different bodies, and the situation becomes even more complex when a new, permanent host arrives—a woman—forcing Beverly to confront the limits of her love and identity.

StorySections.Text: Beverly and Odan share an intimate evening, clearly drawn to one another. Their budding romance unfolds against the backdrop of an upcoming peace mission.
En route to Peliar Zel, Odan is injured when his shuttle is attacked. Emergency surgery reveals an unfamiliar symbiotic lifeform within his abdomen.
To preserve Odan’s diplomatic mission, the Trill symbiont is transferred into Riker, who agrees to act as a temporary host. Odan’s personality and memories now speak through Riker’s body.
Beverly is shaken by the idea of continuing a relationship with Odan in Riker’s body. She confides in Troi as she wrestles with the distinction between physical attraction and emotional connection.
A permanent Trill host arrives—a woman—just as the negotiations are completed. Odan is successfully moved again, and Beverly realizes that her feelings cannot transcend every change in physical form.
Beverly and the newly embodied Odan part ways respectfully, acknowledging that while their connection was real, it cannot continue in this new configuration.

Title: The Mind's Eye
Antagonists: Romulan brainwashing of Geordi La Forge
Covert plot to frame the Federation for arming Klingon rebels
Summary:
En route to Risa for shore leave, Geordi La Forge is intercepted by a Romulan warbird and subjected to intense brainwashing designed to turn him into an unwitting assassin. False memories are implanted so he believes he simply enjoyed a pleasant vacation, and he returns to the Enterprise unaware that he has been conditioned.

The Enterprise is assigned to mediate tensions between the Klingon governor Vagh and the Federation over alleged Federation weapons being used by rebels. As Picard works to prove Starfleet’s innocence, Geordi’s programming compels him to sabotage evidence and eventually attempt to assassinate Vagh—part of a Romulan scheme to damage the fragile Federation–Klingon alliance.

StorySections.Text: Geordi sets course for a much-needed vacation on Risa. His shuttle is suddenly intercepted by a Romulan ship under cloak, and he is taken prisoner.
Through visual conditioning and forced simulations, Romulan operatives reshape Geordi’s perceptions, training him to follow their commands without conscious awareness.
Back aboard the Enterprise, Geordi recalls an idyllic stay on Risa. Meanwhile, Picard hosts Ambassador Kell and Governor Vagh, who accuse the Federation of secretly supplying Klingon insurgents.
Geordi unknowingly sabotages a weapons demonstration and plants false evidence that seems to implicate Starfleet. Subtle inconsistencies in his behavior catch the attention of Data and Troi.

During a formal gathering, Geordi’s conditioning activates, and he attempts to assassinate Vagh with a phaser rifle. The crew stops him in time and uncovers Ambassador Kell’s collusion with the Romulans.
As Kell is taken into custody, Geordi begins the long process of deprogramming. Picard warns that the Romulans’ failure will not end their efforts to destabilize the Klingon–Federation alliance.

Title: In Theory
Antagonists: Unstable dark-matter nebula causing spatial distortions
Data's limitations in understanding romantic relationships
Summary:
As the Enterprise maps a dark-matter nebula that causes strange spatial distortions in the ship, Data’s friend and crewmate Jenna D’Sora ends a troubled relationship and unexpectedly turns to him for comfort. Encouraged by Troi and others to explore the possibility, Data decides to enter a romantic relationship with Jenna, approaching it as an experiment.

Data programs a series of "boyfriend" subroutines and tries to model ideal partner behavior, but his literal interpretations and lack of genuine emotion create awkward and sometimes hurtful moments. All the while, dangerous pockets of altered space threaten the ship, culminating in a hazardous shuttle navigation that Picard must pilot himself.

StorySections.Text: Jenna breaks up with her current partner and finds herself spending more time with Data, who offers practical but oddly comforting support.
As the Enterprise enters a dark-matter nebula, minor anomalies appear—objects shifting position, decks misaligning. Jenna confesses romantic feelings for Data.
Data consults his friends about dating and then activates new subroutines to become Jenna’s boyfriend, adjusting his behavior according to what he believes a partner should do.

The relationship produces both sweet gestures and misfires, as Data’s attempts at affection lack spontaneity. Meanwhile, the spatial distortions worsen, killing a crew member when the floor itself shifts.

Picard pilots a shuttle through the nebula to chart safe paths, allowing the Enterprise to escape. Jenna realizes that Data cannot reciprocate her feelings in a truly emotional sense and ends the relationship.
Data calmly archives the "romantic relationship with Jenna D’Sora" subroutine and notes that he will miss the experience, even if he cannot feel loss in a human way.

Title: Redemption, Part I
Antagonists: House of Duras challenging Gowron's claim to leadership
Impending Klingon civil war, possibly fueled by Romulans
Summary:
As the Klingon Empire approaches a leadership transition, Picard travels to Qo'noS to oversee the installation of Gowron as Chancellor, fulfilling his duties as Arbiter of Succession. However, the powerful House of Duras presents Toral, a young son of the late Duras, as an alternative candidate, with his aunts Lursa and B’Etor maneuvering behind the scenes.

Worf sees Gowron’s rise as an opportunity to restore his family’s honor, which was tarnished by a political cover-up. Picard refuses to bend Klingon law to suit either side, but his ruling that Toral is unfit to lead pushes the Empire toward civil war. As fleets begin to choose sides, Worf makes a fateful choice about where his loyalty lies.

StorySections.Text: Picard is summoned by Gowron, who warns that the House of Duras is plotting to steal the chancellorship and plunge the Empire into chaos.
On Qo'noS, Picard convenes the High Council to formally confirm Gowron. Lursa and B’Etor arrive with Toral, arguing that Klingon tradition allows even a young heir to claim leadership.
Worf petitions Gowron to restore his family’s honor, presenting evidence that the Duras line, not the House of Mogh, was responsible for past treachery. Gowron hesitates, wary of political fallout.

Picard rules that Toral lacks the experience to become Chancellor, but the House of Duras rejects the decision and begins rallying support. Klingon commanders split their loyalties as tensions mount toward open conflict.
The Enterprise observes Duras-aligned ships receiving covert aid from an unknown source. In the shadows, a Romulan commander revealed to resemble Tasha Yar—Sela—watches events unfold.
Realizing he cannot remain neutral, Worf resigns from Starfleet and joins Gowron’s forces, taking his place aboard a Klingon ship as the Empire stands on the brink of civil war.

Title: Redemption II
Antagonists: House of Duras fleet backed by Romulans
Sela's covert plot to use the civil war against the Federation
Summary:
The Klingon civil war intensifies as Gowron’s forces battle the powerful House of Duras, whose fleets are secretly supplied by the Romulans. Picard, determined to keep the Federation neutral while preventing a Romulan takeover of the Empire, organizes a massive Starfleet blockade along the Romulan border using a tachyon detection grid.

Data is given independent command of the USS Sutherland and must earn the respect of a skeptical crew, while Worf serves aboard a Klingon ship, torn between his Starfleet training and warrior heritage. When Sela, a Romulan commander who is the daughter of an alternate-timeline Tasha Yar, tries to outmaneuver the blockade, Data’s unorthodox tactics expose the supply ships. Cut off from Romulan aid, the Duras cause collapses, Gowron secures the chancellorship, and Worf’s family honor is finally restored.

StorySections.Text: Worf, having resigned from Starfleet, serves aboard Gowron’s flagship as the Klingon civil war rages. Picard prepares a Starfleet task force to contain Romulan involvement without openly entering the conflict.
Picard briefs his captains on the tachyon blockade along the Romulan border. Data receives his first command aboard the USS Sutherland, facing doubts from his new first officer.

On Qo'noS, Lursa and B’Etor maneuver to maintain support for young Toral as figurehead. In the shadows, Sela outlines a plan to use the Duras fleet and Romulan supplies to win the war and weaken both the Klingons and the Federation.
As the blockade activates, Sela deploys cloaked freighters. Data counters by improvising a sensor net that reveals a hidden convoy, despite orders that favor a more conservative tactic.

With the Romulan supply line exposed, the House of Duras loses its strategic advantage. Gowron’s forces gain the upper hand, and the Duras sisters flee. Worf confronts Gowron, who finally restores the honor of the House of Mogh.
Worf returns to the Enterprise and requests reinstatement in Starfleet. Picard welcomes him back, noting that Worf has balanced duty to both his people and his principles.

Title: Darmok
Antagonists: Energy creature on El-Adrel IV
Language barrier posed by the Children of Tama's metaphor-based speech
Summary:
The Enterprise meets the Children of Tama, a species whose language defies the universal translator. Their captain, Dathon, suddenly transports himself and Picard to the surface of El-Adrel IV, isolating them from their crews. On the planet, a dangerous, invisible energy creature stalks them while Picard struggles to decode Dathon’s speech, which consists entirely of references to mythic figures and historical events.

As the Enterprise crew attempts to retrieve their captain without violating the alien ship’s shields, Picard gradually realizes that Dathon is using a shared trial by combat as a metaphor to build understanding. The two captains fight side by side against the creature, forging a brief but profound connection that proves communication is possible even when words fail.

StorySections.Text: The Children of Tama hail the Enterprise, but their seemingly nonsensical phrases—"Darmok and Jalad at Tanagra"—baffle the universal translator and the crew.

Without warning, Dathon and Picard are transported to El-Adrel IV, while the Enterprise and the Tamarian ship remain locked in a standoff. Picard finds himself unable to make literal sense of Dathon’s language.

Dathon shares fire and tools, repeating phrases tied to his people’s legends. On the Enterprise, Troi and Data begin to suspect that Tamarian speech is entirely metaphorical, built around shared cultural stories.

An energy creature attacks. Dathon insists on facing it with Picard as "Darmok and Jalad" faced a common foe. The battle leaves Dathon mortally wounded but deepens Picard’s comprehension of the metaphors.

Back on the ship, Picard uses newly learned Tamarian figures of speech to explain Dathon’s sacrifice to his crew. The Tamarian first officer recognizes that their captain succeeded in establishing communication through shared experience.
Picard returns Dathon’s log and ceremonial knife, honoring him as a fellow captain who risked everything to bridge a cultural divide.

Summary:

Guinan senses there is more to Ro’s story and gradually earns her trust. Ro reveals that Kennelly’s mission is a setup: the Cardassians are using Starfleet to lure the Bajorans into a trap. Admiral Kennelly briefs Picard on a mission to stop Bajoran terrorists allegedly responsible for attacking a Federation colony. Ro’s knowledge of Bajorans is presented as essential, despite her checkered record.

Guinan befriends Ro, discovering that she feels betrayed by Starfleet and haunted by a mission gone wrong. The Enterprise locates Orta’s settlement and finds Bajoran refugees living in desperate conditions.
Ro learns from her contacts that the Cardassians orchestrated the recent attacks as a pretext. Kennelly’s orders would effectively deliver the Bajorans into Cardassian hands.

Picard confronts Kennelly’s duplicity by exposing the trap. The plan collapses when the Cardassians’ scheme is revealed, and Kennelly is recalled to face charges. Ro, having chosen to side with Picard and the truth, is offered a place on the Enterprise.
Ro accepts Picard’s offer, beginning a new chapter in Starfleet service as both she and Picard acknowledge that trust must be earned, not imposed.

Title: Disaster

Summary:

Picard is trapped in a turbolift with three schoolchildren and must help them confront their fear while coping with his own discomfort around children. Troi, as the senior officer on the darkened bridge, is thrust into command despite her lack of technical expertise. Worf must deliver Keiko O’Brien’s baby in Ten Forward, and Crusher and Geordi contend with a potentially explosive plasma leak in a sealed cargo bay. Across the ship, ordinary officers are pushed into extraordinary leadership.

StorySections.Text: A routine day aboard the Enterprise is shattered when a quantum filament strikes the ship, plunging corridors into darkness and injuring crew across multiple decks.
Picard and three children are trapped in a damaged turbolift. On the bridge, Troi, O’Brien, and Ensign Ro struggle to assess the situation with most systems offline.
In Ten Forward, Worf copes with injuries and panicked civilians as Keiko goes into labor. Crusher and Geordi discover a dangerous warp plasma leak in a cargo bay that could destroy the ship.

Troi must overrule Ro’s pessimistic recommendation to separate the saucer, relying on intuition and limited data. Picard coaches the frightened children to take on roles in a "crew" to help them climb out.

Worf successfully delivers Keiko’s baby. Crusher and Geordi vent the plasma into space just in time. Data sacrifices his head to restore control on the bridge, and the command crew gradually re-establish shipwide control.
With systems back online, the crew reflects on unexpected acts of heroism. Picard reluctantly agrees to be honored by his young "crew," and Troi contemplates a deeper understanding of command.

Title: The Game
Antagonists: Addictive neural game spreading through the crew
Ktarian plot to enslave Starfleet personnel via mind control
Summary:
Riker returns from shore leave on Risa with a seemingly harmless new game that projects into the player’s vision and stimulates the brain’s pleasure centers. The game quickly spreads through the Enterprise crew, who become obsessed with playing it. Only Wesley Crusher, back on break from Starfleet Academy, and young engineer Robin Lefler remain unaffected long enough to notice something is wrong.

As Data is disabled and senior officers insist Wesley try the game, he and Lefler race to uncover its effects. They discover that the device bypasses critical thought and imprints suggestible states in players. Meanwhile, the Ktarian Etana Jol coordinates the scheme, planning to use a fully compromised Enterprise to infect other Starfleet ships.

StorySections.Text: On Risa, Riker is introduced to a new game by the alluring Etana Jol. He finds it intensely pleasurable and is given a unit to take back to the Enterprise.
Riker shares the game with Troi and others, and within hours its popularity soars. Wesley returns to visit his mother and friends, noticing odd changes in their behavior.
Wesley partners with Ensign Robin Lefler to investigate. They test the game’s neural effects and discover its strong addictive and suggestive properties.
Data is sabotaged so he cannot interfere. Senior officers, now fully under the game’s influence, pressure Wesley to play while Etana prepares to steer the Enterprise to a rendezvous with other ships.

Wesley and Lefler set up a countermeasure, using Data’s positronic brain to deliver a visual stimulus that breaks the game’s hold. At the last moment, Data reactivates and frees the crew before the Ktarian plan succeeds.
With the crew restored, Etana Jol flees. Wesley departs for the Academy again, having proven his ability to recognize and resist subtle threats.

Title: Unification I
Antagonists: Romulan attempts to exploit Vulcan–Romulan reunification sentiment
Sela's hidden agenda on Romulus
Summary:
Starfleet receives shocking intelligence that Ambassador Spock has apparently traveled to Romulus without authorization, raising fears that he has defected. Picard is ordered to investigate. He first visits a dying Sarek on Vulcan, learning that Spock has long been pursuing the dream of Vulcan–Romulan reunification, a cause fraught with political risk.

Using a cloaked Klingon ship, Picard and Data infiltrate Romulus, assuming the identities of merchants with the help of Senator Pardek, a longtime contact of Spock’s. Meanwhile, Riker investigates the theft of surplus Vulcan ships, suspecting a connection to Spock’s mission. On Romulus, Picard finally encounters Spock, only to discover that Romulan forces, led by Sela, may be manipulating the reunification movement for their own ends.

StorySections.Text: Starfleet intelligence presents grainy images of Spock on Romulus, suggesting an unprecedented defection. Picard is tasked with uncovering the truth.
Picard travels to Vulcan and visits Sarek, who is frail and suffering from Bendii Syndrome. Despite his weakened state, Sarek provides insight into Spock’s long-standing interest in reunification.

Aboard a Klingon Bird-of-Prey, Picard and Data endure a tense journey under cloak toward Romulus. Riker begins tracking down stolen Vulcan ships, following clues in a scrapyard and a bar frequented by traders.

On Romulus, Picard and Data adopt disguises to blend in among Romulan citizens. Senator Pardek arranges a secret meeting with Spock, who reveals his belief that Romulan society contains a faction open to reunification.

As Spock explains his work, Sela suddenly appears, capturing Picard and Data. She reveals that the Romulan government has its own plans to use the rhetoric of reunification as cover for a potential invasion of Vulcan.
The episode ends on a cliffhanger, with Picard, Data, and Spock in Romulan custody as Sela outlines her scheme.

With Data’s help, the captives escape and set out to sabotage Sela’s propaganda broadcast. Title: A Matter of Time

Planetary ecological crisis on Penthara IV
Summary:
The Enterprise is on a mission to help Penthara IV recover from a catastrophic asteroid impact when a small time pod appears. Its occupant, Berlinghoff Rasmussen, claims to be a historian from the 26th century who has come specifically to observe this mission, hinting that it will become historically significant.

While Rasmussen’s presence unnerves Picard—especially when the captain must decide whether to risk additional atmospheric interventions—crew members indulge the visitor’s questions. Data and others grow suspicious of Rasmussen’s evasiveness and odd interest in technology. When the crisis reaches its peak, Picard must act without the certainty Rasmussen refuses to provide, only to discover that the "historian" is not what he seems.

StorySections.Text: A strange capsule appears in space and docks with the Enterprise. Berlinghoff Rasmussen steps out, breezily introducing himself as a time-traveling historian.

Rasmussen claims temporal protocols prevent him from revealing future events, even as he quizzes the crew about their lives and technology. Penthara IV’s crisis demands immediate scientific attention.
Geordi and Data propose drilling into the planet’s crust to release trapped heat and counteract a looming ice age—an intervention with unknown side effects. Picard considers the risks.

Picard confronts Rasmussen privately, asking whether the chosen course will save or doom the planet. Rasmussen refuses to answer, citing the integrity of the timeline, forcing Picard to rely on his own judgment.

The plan works, stabilizing Penthara IV’s atmosphere. Meanwhile, Data discovers that Rasmussen is actually from the 22nd century and has been stealing technology. Rasmussen is arrested, and the stolen devices are returned to the timeline by sending the pod back empty.
Rasmussen is left to face justice in the 24th century, while Picard reflects that leaders must accept responsibility for decisions made without the comfort of certainty.

Title: New Ground
Antagonists: Runaway soliton wave threatening a colony
Worf's struggle to accept fatherhood and Alexander's behavior
Summary:
The Enterprise assists in testing a revolutionary new form of warp propulsion—the soliton wave—designed to carry a test ship without its own warp drive. At the same time, Worf receives an unexpected visit from his foster mother Helena, who brings his young son Alexander aboard and announces that she can no longer care for him full-time.

As Worf wrestles with the responsibility of raising a child he barely knows, Alexander acts out, clashing with both Klingon expectations and Starfleet routines. When the soliton wave test goes disastrously wrong and the wave grows dangerously out of control, heading toward a populated colony, Worf and Alexander must confront their relationship amid a high-stakes rescue.

StorySections.Text: Worf eagerly follows preparations for the soliton wave experiment, while Helena Rozhenko arrives with Alexander, catching Worf off guard with news of her plan to leave the boy in his care.
Dr. Ja'Dar explains the potential of soliton propulsion to replace conventional warp drive. Worf struggles to connect with Alexander, who resents being uprooted yet again.
Alexander’s misbehavior at school and in the ship’s corridors leads Worf to consider sending him to a strict Klingon school, believing it will teach discipline.

The soliton wave destabilizes and accelerates toward Lemma II, threatening catastrophic destruction. The Enterprise races to intercept while Worf and Alexander are caught in a fire in one of the affected cargo bays.

Worf rescues Alexander from the blaze, and Geordi leads a risky plan to disperse the wave with concentrated phaser fire. The colony is saved as Worf realizes he cannot simply send his son away to be someone else’s responsibility.
Worf tells Alexander he will remain on the Enterprise and that they will face their "new ground" together as father and son.

Title: Hero Worship
Antagonists: Gravitic stresses of the Black Cluster
Timothy's trauma and survivor's guilt
Summary:
The Enterprise discovers the wreckage of the research vessel Vico inside a dangerous region of space known as a Black Cluster. The only survivor is a young boy named Timothy, traumatized and convinced that he somehow caused the disaster. As the Enterprise investigates what destroyed the Vico, Timothy latches onto Data, deciding that being an emotionless "android" is the only way to escape his pain.

While the ship itself begins to experience violent gravitic stresses, Data and Troi work gently to help Timothy process his grief. Evidence from the Vico suggests that its shields, not an attack, triggered a chain reaction with the Black Cluster’s unique properties. To save the Enterprise, Picard must gamble on the counterintuitive solution of lowering the shields—just as Timothy begins to accept that what happened was not his fault.

StorySections.Text: An away team boards the shattered Vico and finds Timothy, the only survivor, hiding in the wreckage as the ship threatens to collapse around them.
Brought aboard the Enterprise, Timothy withdraws into silence until he fixates on Data’s apparent lack of emotion. He begins copying Data’s mannerisms, declaring that he too is an android.

Troi realizes that Timothy’s imitation of Data is a coping mechanism to avoid grief. Meanwhile, Geordi and Data uncover oddities in the Vico’s logs that suggest shield interaction with the Black Cluster.
As the Enterprise encounters the same gravitic surges, Timothy’s fragmented memories begin to return. He confesses that he believed his actions caused the catastrophe.

Data helps Timothy understand that the Vico was destroyed by an unforgiving natural phenomenon, not his behavior. Picard orders the shields dropped, allowing the ship to slip safely through the cluster’s distortions.
With the crisis past, Timothy gradually lets go of his android persona, beginning to grieve as a child again while maintaining a fond bond with Data.

Title: Violations
Antagonists: Jev's telepathic assaults using invasive memory probes
Abuse of empathic abilities under the guise of therapy
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts a delegation of Ullians, telepathic historians who specialize in helping people recover buried memories. Their leader, Tarmin, demonstrates the procedure, impressing the crew with its therapeutic potential. Soon afterward, however, Troi collapses and slips into a coma after a disturbing nightmare based on a twisted version of her own memories.

As Riker and later Crusher suffer similar attacks, suspicion falls on the Ullians. Data and Picard investigate patterns in past incidents along the Ullians’ route and discover a history of unexplained comas. The evidence points not to Tarmin but to his son Jev, who has been using his abilities to invade and violate minds for personal gratification.

StorySections.Text: Tarmin assists a crew member in reliving a pleasant childhood memory, showcasing the Ullians’ skill at uncovering forgotten experiences.
Troi is found unconscious after a frightening dream in which a fond memory of Riker becomes warped into an assault. Medical scans reveal no physical cause.
Riker and then Crusher experience similar psychic attacks, each centered on altered versions of their own past. The ship’s doctors can only stabilize them in stasis-like comas.
Data and Picard trace a trail of unexplained comas at worlds recently visited by the Ullians. Jev attempts to shift blame onto his father by volunteering to help with Troi’s memories.
Troi begins to piece together the truth from within her altered memories, recognizing Jev as the intruder. Confronted with the pattern of abuse, Jev is exposed and taken into custody.
As the victims awaken, Picard reflects with Tarmin on the horror of abilities meant for healing being turned into instruments of violation.
