Title: The Masterpiece Society
Antagonists: Approaching stellar core fragment threatening Moab IV
Rigidity of the genetically engineered society
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a distress call from a previously unknown human colony on Moab IV, a "masterpiece" society genetically engineered for perfect balance. Led by Aaron Conor, the colony lives under a protective dome whose structural integrity is threatened by a nearby stellar core fragment. To save the colonists, the Enterprise must use its tractor beam in close proximity, risking damage to both ship and settlement.

As Troi and Crusher interact with the colonists, they see the benefits and costs of a society built on genetic selection, including the exclusion of people like Geordi who were born with disabilities. Hannah Bates, a brilliant scientist, becomes fascinated by life beyond the dome. The rescue succeeds, but the presence of off-worlders destabilizes the colony’s carefully planned equilibrium when several colonists choose to leave.

StorySections.Text: A focused distress signal leads the Enterprise to Moab IV, where sensors detect an artificial biosphere and a society that has deliberately remained isolated.
Troi and Picard meet Aaron Conor, who explains that every colonist was genetically designed for specific roles, creating a harmonious but tightly controlled community.
Hannah Bates collaborates with Geordi on a plan to use the Enterprise’s tractor beam to alter the core fragment’s path. She is intrigued by Geordi’s success despite his VISOR and unplanned birth.
The tractor beam maneuver strains both the Enterprise and the colony’s shield, but coordinated adjustments avert disaster. Meanwhile, Troi and Conor develop a mutual attraction.

With the immediate danger past, some colonists—including Hannah—decide they want to leave and experience broader Federation life. Conor realizes that contact with the Enterprise has permanently changed his society.
Picard reflects that saving the colony may have doomed its original design, raising questions about the unintended consequences of intervention—even benevolent ones.

Title: Conundrum
Antagonists: Keiran MacDuff's falsified identities and orders
Manufactured war against the Lysians
Summary:
A mysterious alien probe scans the Enterprise and wipes the crew’s long-term memories, leaving them aware of how to operate the ship but unsure of who they are. Ship records have been altered to show that they are at war with a species called the Lysians, and that a previously unknown officer, Commander Keiran MacDuff, is the ship’s executive officer.

While the crew tries to reconstruct their identities and relationships, MacDuff subtly pushes them toward carrying out a preprogrammed mission: destroying the Lysian command center. As moral qualms arise about attacking a seemingly defenseless target, Data and others uncover inconsistencies that suggest the war may be fabricated—and MacDuff may not be what he appears.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise investigates a strange energy field. A surge of light sweeps through the ship, and the crew awaken at their posts with no memory of who they are.

Using the computer, the officers piece together their apparent roles. MacDuff’s record portrays him as first officer, while the database insists the Federation is locked in a brutal war with the Lysians.
Riker and Troi tentatively explore hints of a past relationship; Worf, assuming a more aggressive posture, is inclined toward decisive military action.

As the Enterprise nears the Lysian command station, scans show minimal defenses and no evidence of a warlike civilization. Picard hesitates to open fire on a target that appears incapable of resisting.

When Picard refuses to give the order, MacDuff attempts to seize control and force the attack. In the struggle, his non-human physiology is revealed, exposing him as a Sataran agent who manipulated the crew to destroy his people’s enemy.
With MacDuff incapacitated, Picard calls off the attack. The crew sets course to return the alien operative for judgment as they begin the slow process of fully restoring their memories.

Title: Power Play
Antagonists: Disembodied prison entities from the moon of Mab-Bu VI
Hostage crisis in Ten Forward
Summary:
While investigating a distress signal near an M-class moon of Mab-Bu VI, a shuttle carrying Troi, Data, and O’Brien is forced down in a violent storm. During the crash and subsequent rescue, each of them is briefly immobilized by strange energy. Back on the Enterprise, it becomes apparent that alien entities have possessed their bodies—using them to seize control of key shipboard areas.

The possessed trio storms Ten Forward, taking dozens of crew members hostage and demanding transport off the planet. They claim to be the spirits of lost Starfleet officers, but Picard and the others slowly uncover the truth: the entities are actually criminal minds imprisoned on the moon. A battle of wits and tactics ensues as the non-possessed crew attempts to outmaneuver their own commandeered comrades.

StorySections.Text: Responding to a centuries-old distress call, Troi, Data, and O’Brien descend in a shuttle to the moon’s surface, where a plasma storm causes them to crash.
After a tense rescue, the three crewmembers recover—only to exhibit subtly altered behavior and cold, efficient coordination.
The possessed officers seize Ten Forward, injuring security personnel and holding civilians at phaser point. They demand that the Enterprise transport their essences off the moon’s surface.
Picard stalls for time while Data, under alien control, attempts to override ship systems. Troi’s possessed persona reveals knowledge of an old starship disaster tied to the moon.

Realizing the entities are actually condemned criminals, not heroic Starfleet dead, the crew reconfigures transporter technology to draw the disembodied prisoners out of their hosts and back into confinement.
With control restored, Troi, Data, and O’Brien recover in sickbay, troubled by the memory of having their bodies used against their will.

Title: Ethics
Antagonists: Worf's spinal paralysis and desire for ritual suicide
Dr. Russell's risky experimental procedure
Summary:
Worf is gravely injured when a falling cargo container crushes his spine, leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. Faced with the prospect of living with a disability he sees as dishonorable, Worf requests Riker’s help in carrying out a Klingon ritual suicide. Riker and Picard struggle to reconcile respect for Klingon tradition with their own ethical standards.

Enter Dr. Toby Russell, a visiting neurospecialist who proposes an untested technique using a "genatronic replicator" to grow a new spinal cord for Worf. Crusher is appalled by Russell’s cavalier attitude toward experimental medicine, especially after another patient dies in a separate trial. Ultimately, Worf chooses the high-risk surgery over immediate death, gambling his future on a procedure that could either restore his mobility or kill him.

StorySections.Text: A routine cargo operation goes catastrophically wrong, and Worf is crushed by a falling container, rushed to sickbay in critical condition.
Crusher informs Worf that current medical science cannot repair his spinal injury. Worf reacts with stoic resignation, contemplating Klingon concepts of honor and usefulness.
Dr. Toby Russell arrives and proposes her experimental genatronic replicator technique, which has never been used on a humanoid. Crusher condemns Russell’s history of high-risk, low-consent trials.

Worf asks Riker to assist him in performing the Hegh'bat ritual, a ceremonial suicide. Riker refuses to participate in what he sees as needless self-destruction, challenging Worf’s assumptions about honor.
Despite Crusher’s objections, Worf consents to Russell’s procedure. The surgery nearly fails, but Worf’s redundant Klingon physiology allows his body to recover, slowly regaining motor function.
As Worf begins rehabilitation with Alexander by his side, Crusher warns Russell that her methods remain unacceptable, while Worf quietly accepts that he has been granted a second chance.

Title: The Outcast
Antagonists: J'naii society's enforced androgyny
Psychotectic therapy used to "cure" gender identity
Summary:
The Enterprise assists the J'naii, an androgynous species, in locating a missing shuttlecraft in a region of space with hidden gravitational pockets. While working with Soren, a J'naii pilot and scientist, Riker learns that she secretly identifies as female—a forbidden concept in her culture, where gender expression is considered deviant.

As they collaborate to rescue the lost crew, Riker and Soren develop a deep emotional connection. When Soren openly speaks about her identity, she is arrested and scheduled for "psychotectic" treatments meant to erase her gendered feelings. Riker, with Worf’s help, attempts a daring rescue, but faces the harsh reality of a society determined to enforce conformity.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise meets a J'naii delegation to investigate a missing shuttle hidden within a treacherous null space pocket.
Riker and Soren work together in a shuttle to map the gravitational anomalies. Their banter reveals Soren’s curiosity about human concepts of gender and romance.
Soren confides in Riker that she has always felt "female" and is attracted to him, a confession that could mean severe punishment if discovered by her people.
After successfully rescuing the missing J'naii crew, Soren publicly challenges the taboo against gender. She is immediately detained for violating cultural norms.

Riker and Worf mount a covert rescue attempt, but arrive too late. Soren has already undergone psychotectic treatment and now expresses acceptance of J'naii doctrine, with no apparent memory of her earlier feelings.
Riker returns to the Enterprise, quietly devastated. Troi offers support as he grapples with the loss of Soren to a system he could not change.

Title: Cause and Effect
Antagonists: Temporal causality loop destroying the Enterprise
Collision with the USS Bozeman emerging from a time rift
Summary:
The episode opens with a shocking sequence: the Enterprise collides with another starship and explodes. Moments later, time resets to an earlier point in the day, with the crew experiencing odd feelings of déjà vu and subtle repetitions of events. As the loop repeats, Crusher begins hearing echoing voices and noticing patterns that suggest they have lived through these moments before.

Data’s positronic brain retains fragments of information across iterations, allowing him to encode a simple numerical clue to himself. As the Enterprise again heads toward a collision with the USS Bozeman emerging from a temporal rift, the crew must interpret the cryptic message in time to break the cycle and avoid yet another destruction.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise attempts to maneuver away from an oncoming ship, but a collision with the USS Bozeman triggers a warp core breach that destroys the Enterprise.
Time resets to a poker game, with Crusher, Riker, Data, and Worf experiencing a vague sense that they have played these exact hands before.
Crusher hears ghostly voices in her quarters and records them, later discovering that they are layered echoes of the crew speaking the same lines over and over.
Data proposes using his positronic matrix to transmit a brief message through the loop. As the crisis approaches again, he receives the number "3" as a crucial hint.

Interpreting the "3" as a cue to follow Riker’s suggestion rather than his own, Data adjusts the ship’s responses, avoiding the collision and breaking the loop. The Enterprise encounters the long-lost Bozeman, whose crew has been trapped in time for decades.
Picard informs Captain Bateson of how long the Bozeman has been missing, and the two ships begin the process of reintegrating Bateson’s crew into the present century.

Title: The First Duty
Antagonists: Nova Squadron's cover-up of a deadly accident
Peer pressure to sacrifice truth for reputation
Summary:
The Enterprise returns to Earth as Picard prepares to deliver the commencement address at Starfleet Academy. Just before the ceremony, a flight-training accident involving Nova Squadron kills cadet Joshua Albert, and Wesley Crusher, now a member of the elite team, is injured. An investigation begins into whether pilot error or misconduct caused the crash.

As evidence mounts that the official story does not match sensor data, Picard becomes convinced that Wesley and his squadmates—led by charismatic cadet Nick Locarno—are hiding the truth. Under intense pressure to protect the team’s reputation and future careers, Wesley must choose between loyalty to his friends and the fundamental Starfleet principle that truth is the first duty of every officer.

StorySections.Text: News of the Nova Squadron accident reaches the Enterprise, prompting a somber detour to Earth and Starfleet Academy.
Picard, Crusher, and others attend the preliminary inquiry, where Nova Squadron insists that a random engine failure caused the loss of control.

Picard notices inconsistencies in the sensor logs and confers with Boothby, the Academy groundskeeper, who knows the cadets well. Suspicions grow that the team attempted a banned Kolvoord Starburst maneuver.

Locarno urges the squad to stick to their story, arguing that admitting the truth will ruin all their futures. Wesley struggles with guilt and the realization that their silence dishonors Joshua’s memory.

During the formal hearing, Wesley breaks ranks and admits they attempted the illegal maneuver and then lied about it. The truth clears Joshua of implied incompetence but leads to severe disciplinary action.
Locarno is expelled from the Academy, and Wesley is held back a year with a disciplinary record. Picard acknowledges Wesley’s courage in finally telling the truth, even at great personal cost.

Title: Cost of Living
Antagonists: Microscopic lifeforms consuming the Enterprise's systems
Rigid expectations surrounding Lwaxana's arranged marriage
Summary:
Lwaxana Troi arrives on the Enterprise to prepare for an arranged marriage to Minister Campio, a proper and protocol-obsessed dignitary. Her flamboyant personality clashes with the stiff requirements of the ceremony, and she quickly grows bored with the constraints placed upon her. Meanwhile, Worf struggles with Alexander’s misbehavior and rigidly insists on strict discipline.

Lwaxana bonds with Alexander and introduces him to a chaotic holodeck environment called the Parallax Colony, where free-spirited residents defy convention. At the same time, a swarm of microscopic lifeforms inadvertently brought aboard begins consuming the ship’s systems, causing bizarre malfunctions. As Campio arrives and the ship nears crisis, Lwaxana must decide whether to follow through with a loveless marriage, and Worf must reassess his approach to parenting.

StorySections.Text: Lwaxana beams aboard with extravagant luggage and grand plans for her upcoming wedding, immediately unsettling Worf and delighting Alexander.
Campio’s representative details an overwhelming list of ceremonial requirements. Lwaxana chafes under the rigid expectations, turning instead to Alexander for fun and companionship.
On the holodeck, Lwaxana introduces Alexander to the Parallax Colony, whose surreal inhabitants sing, juggle, and revel in nonsense. Worf is dismayed by the lack of structure.

Tiny lifeforms in the ship’s water supply begin to replicate, degrading systems and nearly causing a catastrophic failure of environmental controls. Geordi and Data race to identify and remove the organisms.
During the wedding ceremony, system breakdowns mirror the personal chaos as Lwaxana arrives in unconventional attire and ultimately calls off the marriage, choosing freedom over obligation.
With the organisms flushed from the system, Worf and Alexander reach a compromise about rules and play, while Lwaxana departs having once again upended expectations.

Title: The Perfect Mate
Antagonists: Political pressures of the Krios–Valt trade agreement
Ethical dilemma of an empathic metamorph raised to be a "gift" bride
Summary:
The Enterprise transports sealed stasis cargo for a delicate diplomatic mission between the warring worlds of Krios and Valt. When Ferengi interference damages one of the stasis pods, its occupant is revealed: Kamala, an empathic metamorph whose physiology and upbringing make her the "perfect mate"—psychically attuned to become what her chosen partner most desires. She is destined to be given as a bride to the Valtan leader Alrik as part of a crucial peace treaty.

Picard is appalled by the implications of Kamala’s role and the lack of agency in her arranged marriage, while Kamala herself, awakened early, forms an intense, genuine bond with him as he becomes her primary companion and teacher. As the state ceremony approaches, Picard must decide whether to honor his duty and deliver Kamala to a political marriage or acknowledge the mutual feelings that have developed—knowing that his choice will shape her identity for life.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise receives an unusual diplomatic assignment: escorting Ambassador Briam and mysterious stasis containers that are vital to a fragile Krios–Valt peace agreement.
Ferengi stowaways tamper with the sealed cargo, accidentally awakening Kamala. Her presence immediately causes heightened attention from the male crew members who sense her allure.
Briam explains that Kamala is a rare empathic metamorph intended as a peace offering bride. Picard balks at the idea of a sentient being raised to be a political commodity.

To minimize disruption, Kamala is confined and placed under Picard’s supervision. Their conversations reveal her intelligence and curiosity, and her instincts begin tailoring her personality to his understated desires.

Kamala and Picard share a powerful connection as she completes her bonding cycle, effectively imprinting on him emotionally. Despite their obvious mutual feelings, Picard insists she fulfill the treaty by marrying Alrik.
After the wedding, Kamala tells Picard that, though she will perform her duties as queen, it is his values and temperament that have shaped who she has finally become.

Title: Imaginary Friend
Antagonists: Energy-based alien manifesting as Isabella
Misunderstanding between non-corporeal life and human children
Summary:
Young Clara Sutter, adjusting to life aboard the Enterprise, spends much of her time with her imaginary friend "Isabella." When the ship passes through a mysterious energy field, a strand of energy enters the vessel and takes on the form of Isabella, becoming visible and tangible to others. At first, the now-real Isabella seems like a harmless playmate, but her mood turns hostile when she perceives that adults are constantly limiting Clara’s freedom.

Guinan and Troi try to help Clara navigate her relationships with her father and peers, unaware that the alien Isabella is judging the ship’s adults as cruel jailers of their children. As the energy entity summons others of its kind and begins to threaten the Enterprise, Picard must find a way to explain human child-rearing to a being that sees only punishment and restraint.

StorySections.Text: Clara plays in the arboretum with her imaginary friend Isabella while her father juggles engineering duties and single parenthood.
The Enterprise enters a filamentary nebula, encountering unusual energy strands. One slips into the ship and approaches Clara, silently observing her loneliness.
Clara is delighted when Isabella appears as a real girl who can interact with the environment. Adults try to indulge the friendship while encouraging Clara to bond with other children.
Isabella becomes resentful of rules and restrictions, urging Clara to disobey. When confronted, Isabella reveals frightening powers, injuring crew and accessing restricted areas.

Energy tendrils begin draining power from the ship as more entities gather. Picard and Troi address Isabella directly, explaining that guidance and rules are acts of care, not malice, persuading the aliens to withdraw.
The energy forms depart, and Clara tentatively reaches out to real playmates, having learned that her feelings of frustration are understood, even if boundaries remain.

Title: I, Borg
Antagonists: The Borg Collective as an existential threat
Moral dilemma of using Hugh as a biological/software weapon
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a distress signal from a crashed Borg scout ship and discovers a single surviving drone. Beverly insists on rescuing the injured Borg despite Picard’s trauma from his assimilation as Locutus. Once aboard, the isolated drone begins to develop an individual identity and is given the name Hugh by the crew.

Guinan and Geordi, initially hostile, find themselves empathizing with Hugh as he expresses confusion, curiosity, and even friendship. Picard and his staff devise a plan to implant a self-terminating geometric paradox into Hugh’s programming, intending it to spread through the Collective and cripple the Borg forever. However, as Hugh’s sense of self grows, the crew must confront whether they can still justify turning him into a genocidal weapon.

StorySections.Text: An away team investigates wreckage on a barren moon and finds a lone, injured Borg drone, separated from its Collective link.
Crusher brings the drone aboard despite Picard’s unease. Initial attempts at communication reveal standard Borg responses, but also hints of confusion.
Geordi is assigned to work with the Borg and gradually draws out individual pronouns and preferences, nicknaming him "Hugh." Guinan remains skeptical and angry.
Picard and the senior staff discuss using Hugh as a carrier for a fractal paradox that could cascade through the Collective, potentially destroying it. Ethical disagreements fracture the group.

Guinan confronts Hugh and is surprised by his awareness and apparent remorse. When Picard, posing as Locutus, interrogates Hugh, the drone’s loyalty to his new friends forces Picard to reevaluate the plan.

Ultimately, Picard decides they cannot sacrifice Hugh’s emerging individuality. Hugh chooses to rejoin the Borg to prevent them from seeking out his friends, carrying with him the seed of individual thought instead of a weapon.

Title: The Next Phase

Romulan sabotage aboard a damaged warbird
Summary:
Responding to a Romulan distress call, the Enterprise sends an away team to a heavily damaged Warbird. During an emergency transport, a malfunction apparently kills Geordi and Ro. Memorial services are planned as the crew mourns their loss, but Geordi and Ro awaken in a strange state: able to see and hear everyone, yet unable to interact or be perceived.

Assuming they are ghosts at first, the pair soon discovers that they have been shifted into a phased, nearly out-of-sync state due to experimental Romulan cloaking technology. As they explore the ship unnoticed, they uncover a Romulan plot to sabotage the Enterprise using a phased explosive. Geordi and Ro must find a way to communicate across the phase barrier before the device detonates.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise answers a distress call from a crippled Romulan Warbird. An away team beams over to assist, while a strange feedback surge ripples through the transporter systems.

Ro concludes they are dead and experiencing some form of afterlife, while Geordi insists on a technical explanation. They discover they can pass through walls and observe a phased Romulan operative.

Investigating, they learn that a phased device has been planted aboard the Enterprise. Efforts to manipulate controls fail, but small interactions—like passing through objects—produce subtle sensor anomalies.

Geordi and Ro disrupt systems enough for Data to detect unusual phase variances. Data modifies the transporter to "recapture" them and the explosive, returning them to normal space just in time to jettison the device.
At their own memorial reception, Geordi and Ro enjoy the awkwardness of attending "their" funeral before rejoining the crew in earnest, with Ro reconsidering her beliefs about the afterlife.

Title: The Inner Light
Antagonists: Imminent ecological collapse of the planet Kataan
Passage of time and loss preserved only in memory
Summary:
A mysterious alien probe approaches the Enterprise and suddenly emits a beam that strikes Picard. From the crew’s perspective, he collapses on the bridge for only minutes—but in his mind, Picard awakens on the surface of a pre-industrial world called Kataan, where he is known as "Kamin." As he insists he is a starship captain from another life, the villagers, including his wife Eline and friend Batai, gently encourage him to accept his new reality.

Over what feels like decades, Picard lives out an entire second lifetime as Kamin, raising children, mastering the flute, and witnessing Kataan’s slow, irreversible environmental decline. Meanwhile, in real time, the Enterprise crew struggles to break the probe’s hold without harming him. When the truth is finally revealed, Picard learns that the entire experience was a carefully crafted recording: the last memories of a dead world preserved by the probe so that someone would remember that Kataan once existed.

StorySections.Text: On the bridge, the Enterprise detects a simple, seemingly inert probe. A sudden energy beam strikes Picard, rendering him unconscious as the crew rushes to his side.
Picard awakens in a small house with Eline, who insists he is Kamin, a resident of the drought-stricken world of Kataan. He searches for evidence of his starship life but finds none.
Years pass in Kamin’s life. He gradually accepts his role as husband and community member, working with Batai and others to manage dwindling water supplies, even as he clings to dreams of the stars.
Kataan’s climate grows harsher. Kamin and Eline raise their children, including daughter Meribor, who continues his scientific curiosity about the planet’s fate.

An aging Kamin watches his grandchildren play as the sun’s intensity increases. A rocket launch carrying the cultural probe is prepared. As the sky brightens in a final flare, Kamin realizes that the probe will carry their memories into space.

Picard wakes on the Enterprise, stunned to learn only minutes have passed. The recovered probe yields a flute from Kamin’s life, which Picard treasures as a tangible link to the family and world he remembers so vividly.

Title: Time's Arrow, Part I
Antagonists: Devidian energy-feeding aliens traveling through time
Temporal paradox surrounding Data's discovered head
Summary:
Starfleet summons the Enterprise to Earth after a startling discovery in a 19th-century cavern: the severed head of an android identical to Data, buried for five hundred years. Analysis confirms that the head is indeed Data’s, coated in centuries of mineral deposits. This revelation forces the crew to confront the possibility of Data’s inevitable death in Earth’s past.

Investigating unusual temporal emissions, the Enterprise tracks them to a planet where snake-like Devidian aliens are feeding on displaced human life energy, apparently time-shifting victims from 19th-century Earth. When Data is suddenly transported to 1890s San Francisco, he must adapt to the era’s technology and culture, cross paths with a younger Guinan and the writer Samuel Clemens, and prepare for the arrival of his crewmates—while knowing his own head is destined to be left behind.

StorySections.Text: On Earth, an archaeological team reveals a cavern filled with artifacts from 19th-century San Francisco—and the unmistakable, long-buried head of Data.
The Enterprise crew examines the head and confirms that it matches Data down to the micron, though aged by centuries. Picard struggles with the paradox of knowing his officer’s apparent fate.

Temporal energy signatures lead the ship to Devidia II, where snake-like Devidian entities feed on time-displaced human life forces. An away team detects a temporal portal linked to 19th-century Earth.
A misstep sends Data through the portal alone, landing him in 1890s San Francisco. He quickly improvises a power source for his systems and poses as an eccentric inventor to blend in.

Data meets a younger Guinan and begins to investigate the Devidians’ feeding ground in the city. Picard assembles a team to follow, even as the mystery deepens with the appearance of Samuel Clemens, who becomes suspicious of their futuristic origins.
The episode concludes with Picard and several officers stepping through the temporal portal toward 19th-century San Francisco, leaving the Enterprise and Data’s ancient head behind.

Title: Time's Arrow, Part II
Antagonists: Devidian energy-feeding aliens in 19th-century San Francisco
Temporal paradox threatening Data's existence
Summary:
In 1890s San Francisco, Data continues his investigation of the Devidian aliens, who are covertly draining life energy from the city’s poor and sick. Posing as an inventor, he constructs equipment to track the temporal rift the Devidians use. He soon encounters a younger Guinan, who recognizes his importance despite not yet knowing their future friendship. Samuel Clemens (Mark Twain) becomes suspicious of the strange newcomers and begins snooping into their activities.

When Picard, Riker, Crusher, Troi, and Geordi follow Data through the temporal portal, they must blend into the era while locating the Devidians’ feeding site in the city’s tunnels. Picard stays behind with the injured Guinan, risking stranding himself in the past, while the others return to the future to stop the aliens. Ultimately, the crew severs the Devidians’ connection to the 19th century, preserving history and resolving the mystery of Data’s centuries-old head.

StorySections.Text: In 19th-century San Francisco, Data navigates cobblestone streets and turn-of-the-century technology as he searches for traces of Devidian activity.
Data meets Guinan at a literary salon, establishing the beginnings of a friendship out of time. Samuel Clemens eavesdrops, intrigued by their odd conversation.
Picard and his away team arrive via the temporal portal, forced to acquire period clothing and money while staying ahead of police suspicion and Clemens’s curiosity.

The group locates the Devidians’ underground lair, witnessing how the aliens siphon life energy from victims. A skirmish injures Guinan, and Picard chooses to remain with her as the others re-enter the portal.

In the future, the Enterprise detects a temporal disturbance as the away team reappears with Clemens but no Picard. Data’s ancient head is reattached, completing the time loop and allowing him to help shut down the Devidian conduit.
Back in his own time, Clemens returns to the 19th century with a broadened perspective, while Picard and Guinan quietly acknowledge that their bond now spans centuries in both directions.

Title: Realm of Fear
Antagonists: Barclay's transporter phobia and anxiety
Misinterpreted lifeforms trapped in the transporter stream
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a starship in distress and must use the transporter repeatedly in a hazardous plasma field. Lieutenant Reginald Barclay, who suffers from intense transporter phobia, is assigned to an away team despite his fears. During transport, he experiences terrifying visions of worm-like creatures reaching for him inside the matter stream.

As Barclay’s anxiety mounts, he becomes convinced that something is wrong with the transporter, even as medical scans suggest nothing unusual. With help from Troi, Geordi, and Data, he investigates the phenomenon and discovers that the "creatures" are actually crew members from the missing ship, trapped as patterns within the plasma field. Overcoming his fear, Barclay deliberately re-enters the transporter to rescue them.

StorySections.Text: Barclay practices transporter use on the holodeck but panics at the last moment, revealing the depth of his long-standing fear.
The Enterprise finds the USS Yosemite adrift in a plasma stream. Away missions will require multiple transports through dangerous interference, triggering Barclay’s worst anxieties.
During transport, Barclay sees grotesque shapes in the beam, but his report is dismissed as a panic reaction. Troi counsels him on confronting rather than avoiding his fears.
Subtle anomalies in the transporter logs support Barclay’s claim. Data and Geordi realize that coherent patterns—possibly lifeforms—exist within the plasma field, distorted by the transport cycle.

Barclay volunteers for another transport, allowing one of the beings to latch onto him. Back in the transporter room, the system is modified to separate the patterns, successfully restoring missing Yosemite crew members.
With the crisis resolved, Barclay receives recognition for his bravery and begins to see his phobia as a challenge he can manage, rather than an insurmountable flaw.

Title: Man of the People
Antagonists: Ves Alkar's psychic dumping of negative emotions into others
Political pressure to ignore Troi's deteriorating condition
Summary:
The Enterprise transports mediator Ves Alkar to settle a deadly planetary conflict. Shortly after he arrives, his elderly "mother" Liva dies under mysterious circumstances and Alkar requests that Troi assist him in his grief ritual. Following the ceremony, Troi’s behavior changes dramatically: she becomes aggressive, sexually provocative, and increasingly unstable while also aging at a rapid rate.

Crusher and Picard discover that Alkar is a telepath who shunts the negative emotions generated by his intense diplomatic work into unwitting receptacles, allowing him to remain calm and effective at the cost of their lives. Troi has become his newest victim. Picard must stop Alkar’s mission long enough to confront him, while Crusher races to reverse the psychic link before Troi’s body fails completely.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise welcomes Ves Alkar and his elderly companion Liva, hoping his renowned mediation skills will end a brutal war.
Liva dies after a psychic outburst directed at Troi. Alkar urges Troi to help him channel his grief through a traditional ceremony that secretly establishes a psychic conduit.
Troi’s personality begins to shift—she lashes out at colleagues, seeks out risky encounters, and shows physical signs of accelerated aging.
Crusher discovers abnormal neurotransmitter activity in Troi’s brain and suspects an external influence. Investigation of Alkar’s past reveals a pattern of companions who aged rapidly and died.
Picard halts the negotiations and forces Alkar to break his link with Troi by redirecting it into a deceased body. Freed from the psychic burden, Troi is returned to her normal age and health.
Recovering in sickbay, Troi grapples with fragmented memories of her distorted behavior, while the crew reflects on the costs some are willing to impose on others in the name of peace.

Title: Relics
Antagonists: Unstable Dyson sphere star
Scotty's struggle to adapt to the 24th century
Summary:
The Enterprise discovers the wreck of the USS Jenolan, which crashed onto the surface of a colossal Dyson sphere built around a star. Onboard, they find that Montgomery "Scotty" Scott—legendary chief engineer of the original Enterprise—has survived for 75 years by placing himself in a continuous transporter pattern loop. Revived in the 24th century, Scotty is both awed and disoriented by advances in technology and Starfleet culture.

As the Enterprise investigates the interior of the long-abandoned Dyson sphere, a gravitational surge traps the ship inside. Feeling useless and obsolete, Scotty clashes with Geordi until the two engineers learn to appreciate each other’s strengths. Together, they reactivate the Jenolan and use it to hold open the sphere’s portal, allowing the Enterprise to escape before the unstable star can destroy them.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise locates a distress signal originating from the hull of a Dyson sphere—an impossible megastructure enclosing an entire star.
Aboard the derelict Jenolan, Geordi and Riker discover a continuously cycling transporter pattern, which resolves into the long-lost figure of Montgomery Scott.
Scotty attempts to help in Engineering but finds that his once-cutting-edge skills seem outdated. A visit to a holodeck recreation of the original Enterprise bridge underscores his sense of loss.
A sudden gravitational surge pulls the Enterprise into the Dyson sphere. Trapped inside and losing power, the crew must locate and reopen the sphere’s exit aperture.

Scotty and Geordi take the repaired Jenolan to the aperture’s control point and wedge the small ship in the opening, physically holding it ajar long enough for the Enterprise to pass through to safety.
As Scotty departs in the Jenolan to explore the galaxy at his own pace, Picard bids farewell with a shared drink of Aldebaran whisky and a toast to the Enterprise—"both of them."

Title: Schisms
Antagonists: Interdimensional aliens abducting crew for experiments
Subspace rift destabilizing the Enterprise
Summary:
Crew members aboard the Enterprise begin experiencing unexplained fatigue, memory gaps, and subtle injuries. Riker falls asleep during a recording session of Data’s poetry, wakes feeling unrested, and later discovers minor physical anomalies. Crusher finds similar symptoms in other officers, including strange cellular disruptions that do not match any known medical condition.

As the affected crew reconstruct fragmented memories in the holodeck, they piece together a shared vision of a cold, metallic lab where they were restrained and experimented upon. Geordi discovers a subspace rift near the ship, and the crew realizes that interdimensional aliens have been abducting personnel into their own realm. To stop the incursions, Riker volunteers to be taken again, allowing the crew to track and sever the connection.

StorySections.Text: Data presents his latest poem in Ten Forward. Riker, unusually drowsy, nods off in the middle of the performance, to everyone’s bemusement.
Crusher treats multiple crew members for insomnia and odd aches. Riker’s schedule shows missing time he cannot account for.
Using the holodeck, Riker, Ensign Rager, and others reconstruct recurring fragments of a strange chamber with sloping tables and ominous instruments.
Sensor scans reveal a subspace rift draining energy near the ship. Worf discovers that tools and devices have been subtly moved, suggesting incursions from another dimension.

Riker allows himself to be abducted once more, carrying a homing device. The crew tracks his signature, opens a controlled portal, and retrieves him while detonating a beacon that collapses the subspace corridor.
With the rift sealed, the crew remains unsettled by the knowledge that they were used as test subjects by beings they still barely understand.

Title: True Q
Antagonists: Ethical burden of omnipotent power
Q Continuum's judgment over Amanda's fate
Summary:
A promising young intern, Amanda Rogers, joins the Enterprise’s medical staff. Soon, inexplicable phenomena follow her: containers stop mid-fall, disasters are averted by impossible coincidences, and she unconsciously saves a crew member’s life. Q arrives to reveal the truth—Amanda is actually a Q, born to Continuum members who chose to live as humans and were later killed for their nonconformity.

As Amanda’s powers manifest more fully, she faces a choice: join the Q Continuum and embrace near-omnipotence, or remain human and accept the responsibilities and limitations that entails. When she instinctively saves an entire colony from annihilation, the Continuum uses the act as a test case, arguing that such power will inevitably be abused. With Picard’s guidance, Amanda must decide which path aligns with her conscience.

StorySections.Text: Amanda impresses Crusher with her enthusiasm and skill, but a minor accident in a cargo bay mysteriously resolves itself around her.
Q appears aboard the Enterprise, announcing that Amanda is one of his kind and that he has been sent to evaluate her suitability for the Continuum.
Amanda experiments with her abilities, joyfully reshaping matter and space while Picard and Crusher warn her about the ethical implications of playing god.
A catastrophic planetary core failure threatens a colony. Amanda reflexively stops the disaster, saving thousands of lives but revealing the scale of her power.

Q argues that the Continuum will not allow a being with such power to remain among humans. Amanda ultimately chooses to join the Q, hoping to use her abilities responsibly and honoring her human upbringing.
With a final goodbye to Crusher and Picard, Amanda vanishes in a flash of light, leaving the crew to ponder what kind of Q she will become.

Title: Rascals
Antagonists: Ferengi raiders seizing control of the Enterprise
De-aged officers struggling with loss of authority
Summary:
A shuttle accident involving Picard, Guinan, Ro, and Keiko passes them through a strange energy field that de-ages their physical bodies to those of pre-teens while leaving their minds intact. Medical scans show their DNA has reverted to earlier patterns, and there is no immediate way to reverse the transformation. Picard struggles with being physically treated as a child, particularly when Starfleet orders temporarily relieve him of command.

Before the crew can fully adjust, a group of Ferengi hijacks the Enterprise, exploiting the apparent absence of senior leadership and forcing most adults into labor. The de-aged officers, overlooked as children, organize a covert resistance with actual shipboard kids. Using their access and ingenuity, they sabotage the Ferengi takeover and help Data and Riker retake the ship.

StorySections.Text: A shuttle returning from vacation encounters a mysterious energy phenomenon. An emergency transport back to the Enterprise ends with four of its occupants physically transformed into children.
Crusher confirms that the de-aged Picard, Guinan, Ro, and Keiko have intact adult memories but child physiology. Starfleet regulations require a reassessment of Picard’s command status.
As Picard awkwardly navigates interactions with his crew and with a visiting school group, Ferengi raiders ambush and seize the Enterprise, beaming over with mercenary support.
The Ferengi confine most adults while planning to sell the ship and crew. The "children" move relatively freely, enlisting the help of real kids like Alexander to coordinate a counterattack.
By sabotaging systems and creating diversions, the de-aged officers help Data and Riker disable the Ferengi. Control of the Enterprise is restored, and research into reversing the de-aging continues.
As the affected officers begin returning to their proper ages, Picard shares a moment with Riker about perspective, having briefly experienced childhood with decades of adult insight.

Title: A Fistful of Datas
Antagonists: Holodeck malfunction merging Data's systems with the program
Outlaw archetypes gaining Data's strength and intellect
Summary:
During a quiet period, the Enterprise runs systems tests that allow the main computer to use Data’s positronic brain as a backup processing node. At the same time, Worf reluctantly joins Alexander in a holodeck Western adventure set in the frontier town of Deadwood. A glitch caused by the test results in holodeck characters taking on Data’s appearance and abilities, while Data in the real world briefly absorbs Western personas.

As the simulation grows more dangerous—with holographic guns gaining the power to injure and outlaw "Datas" displaying superhuman speed—Worf must navigate the scenario by its own narrative rules. Troi joins as a fellow gunslinger, and together they outwit the program long enough for Geordi to restore proper separation between Data and the computer.

StorySections.Text: Alexander persuades a reluctant Worf to participate in a holodeck Western, while Geordi and Data prepare to run an experiment linking Data’s brain to the ship’s computer.
Inside the holodeck, Worf plays the role of lawman in a stylized Old West town. Outside, the systems test begins without incident—at first.
A power fluctuation causes the program’s characters to assume Data’s likeness. The stakes rise when phaser safety protocols fail and holodeck weapons become potentially lethal.
Troi joins the simulation as a sharp-shooting ally. Together with Worf and Alexander, she hatches a plan to survive the climactic showdown with the gang of Data-faced outlaws.
Worf uses his knowledge of Western tropes to rig the final shootout in his favor. Geordi and Data reestablish normal computer operations, ending the cross-contamination.
Back in uniform, Worf grudgingly admits he enjoyed his time as a frontier lawman, to Alexander’s delight.

Title: The Quality of Life
Antagonists: Question of whether Exocomps are tools or sentient beings
Dangerous mining platform accident
Summary:
The Enterprise visits an experimental mining station where Dr. Farallon is testing a new particle-fountain technology. Central to her work are Exocomps, small robotic devices designed to analyze and repair complex engineering problems autonomously. When one apparently refuses to enter a hazardous area and instead modifies itself to survive, Data begins to suspect that Exocomps may have developed self-preservation and, by extension, sentience.

As the station suffers a critical malfunction, Picard and Geordi become trapped in a dangerous area. Farallon wants to send Exocomps on a likely suicidal repair mission, but Data argues that, as possible living beings, they cannot be sacrificed without consent. Preventing the mission forces Picard to decide whether to treat the Exocomps as equipment or as a new form of life deserving of rights.

StorySections.Text: On the mining station, an Exocomp successfully completes a complex repair, impressing the Enterprise crew with its flexibility and apparent problem-solving ability.
A test goes awry, and an Exocomp appears to malfunction by refusing an assignment. Data notes that it altered its own circuitry just before a hidden hazard appeared.
Data designs experiments to test whether Exocomps can learn, improvise, and value their own continued existence. The results suggest emergent intelligence.
A catastrophic failure on the station traps Picard and Geordi. Farallon proposes using Exocomps in a high-risk repair that will almost certainly destroy them but might save the trapped officers.

Data blocks the transporter until Picard acknowledges the Exocomps’ potential personhood. When given a choice, the Exocomps participate and creatively minimize the risk, saving everyone while preserving one of their own.
Picard recognizes the Exocomps as a new lifeform, and Farallon reluctantly agrees to treat them as partners rather than mere tools.

Title: Chain of Command, Part I
Antagonists: Cardassian military buildup along the border
Clash of command styles between Jellico and the Enterprise crew
Summary:
Picard is abruptly relieved of command and reassigned to lead a covert mission with Worf and Crusher to infiltrate a Cardassian installation on Celtris III suspected of developing a metagenic weapon. In his place, Starfleet installs Captain Edward Jellico, a no-nonsense officer with a rigid command style who immediately imposes changes on the Enterprise’s routines, rank structure, and diplomacy strategy.

While Picard’s team undertakes grueling training for their dangerous insertion, tensions rise aboard the Enterprise as Jellico clashes with Riker and others over his authoritarian methods and willingness to escalate with the Cardassians. The mission on Celtris III turns out to be a trap, and Picard is captured as the episode ends, leaving Jellico in command during an escalating border crisis.

StorySections.Text: Admiral Nechayev informs Picard that he is to be replaced as captain of the Enterprise and reassigned to a classified operation involving Cardassian space.
Captain Jellico arrives, immediately reconfiguring shift schedules, insisting on four duty rotations, and reshaping the ship to his preferences, unsettling the crew.
Picard, Worf, and Crusher undergo harsh special-operations training, preparing for a hazardous insertion onto Celtris III. Picard’s scientific knowledge of theta-band emissions is key to the mission.
Diplomatic meetings with Gul Lemec expose Cardassian posturing along the border. Jellico’s brusque approach contrasts sharply with Picard’s style, causing friction with Riker.

On Celtris III, Picard’s team infiltrates underground tunnels, only to discover that the supposed metagenic facility is a decoy. Cardassian troops ambush them; Worf and Crusher escape, but Picard is seized.
Back on the Enterprise, Jellico prepares for possible war as news of Picard’s capture reaches Starfleet, setting the stage for a confrontation with the Cardassians.

Title: Chain of Command, Part II
Antagonists: Gul Madred's psychological and physical torture of Picard
Cardassian brinkmanship at the Federation border
Summary:
Captured on Celtris III, Picard becomes the subject of an intense Cardassian interrogation led by Gul Madred, who uses physical torture, sensory deprivation, and psychological manipulation to break his will. Madred demands military intelligence about Federation defenses and repeatedly tries to force Picard to deny reality by insisting that there are five lights where Picard sees only four. Even as he suffers, Picard clings to his sense of identity and duty as a Starfleet captain.

Aboard the Enterprise, Captain Jellico confronts Gul Lemec over Cardassian fleet movements near the border. Jellico’s rigid command style strains his relationship with Riker, but he ultimately reinstates Riker to lead a daring mission to mine Cardassian ships and demonstrate Federation resolve. The successful maneuver forces the Cardassians to negotiate a prisoner exchange, securing Picard’s release—though the trauma of Madred’s torture lingers.

StorySections.Text: Picard awakens in a stark Cardassian cell, stripped of his uniform and subjected to Gul Madred’s first round of questions and pain.
Madred alternates cruelty with feigned kindness, showing Picard his young daughter and claiming that cooperation will end the suffering. Picard refuses to provide tactical information.
On the Enterprise, Jellico presses the crew to prepare for potential war and clashes with Riker over tactics and chain of command, ultimately relieving him of duty.
Madred escalates the torture, fixating on the four overhead lights as a tool to erode Picard’s grip on reality. Meanwhile, Data and Geordi work to adapt shuttlecraft for a covert mining operation.
Jellico swallows his pride and reinstates Riker to command the mine-laying mission. The successful deployment gives Jellico leverage to force Lemec into a prisoner exchange that includes Picard.
Safe aboard the Enterprise, Picard privately admits to Troi that, under the torture, he nearly believed he saw five lights—underscoring how close he came to psychological collapse.

Title: Ship in a Bottle
Antagonists: Professor Moriarty's demand for reality beyond the holodeck
Illusion of freedom within nested simulations
Summary:
During routine maintenance on the holodeck, Barclay inadvertently reactivates the Moriarty program, a self-aware holographic version of Sherlock Holmes’s arch-nemesis created years earlier. Moriarty insists that he has remained conscious since his last encounter with the crew and demands that Picard fulfill an old promise to find a way for him to exist outside the holodeck. When Picard hesitates, Moriarty seizes control of the Enterprise’s systems through the holodeck interface.

Moriarty appears to step off the holodeck safely, demonstrating that some breakthrough has occurred, and forces Picard, Data, and Barclay to work on a way to free his beloved Countess Regina Bartholomew as well. Gradually, Picard and Data deduce that they themselves are inside a sophisticated simulation created by Moriarty. By turning Moriarty’s own trick back on him, they trap him and Regina in a small simulated universe stored in memory, allowing them to experience what they believe is freedom while the real Enterprise continues on its way.

StorySections.Text: Barclay runs diagnostics on the Sherlock Holmes holodeck program and accidentally restores Professor Moriarty, who immediately asks whether Picard has kept his promise.
Moriarty demonstrates apparent control over ship systems and seems to walk off the holodeck, insisting that the crew acknowledge his sentience and right to live.
Moriarty demands that Picard find a way to free the Countess Regina Bartholomew as well, threatening the ship if his wishes are not met.
Picard and Data begin to notice subtle inconsistencies that suggest they are themselves in a holodeck-generated copy of the Enterprise, manipulated by Moriarty.

Reversing the situation, Picard tricks Moriarty into believing he and the Countess have been transferred to the real universe, when in fact they are inside a cube-sized simulation stored in the computer.
As the device containing Moriarty’s pocket reality quietly hums on a shelf, Picard muses that, from Moriarty’s perspective, he and Regina may be exploring the stars forever.

Title: Aquiel
Antagonists: Coalescent organism mimicking organic forms
Isolation and mistrust on the remote relay station
Summary:
The Enterprise is sent to investigate a communications relay station near the Klingon border that has gone silent. They find the station damaged, one officer missing, and the other—Haliian lieutenant Aquiel Uhnari—apparently murdered, with only traces of organic matter left behind. Geordi studies Aquiel’s personal logs to reconstruct events and becomes emotionally invested in her, sympathizing with her feelings of isolation and frustration.

When Aquiel turns up alive aboard a Klingon ship, she becomes the prime suspect in the death of her crewmate. As Worf and Picard press the investigation, Geordi insists on her innocence. Analysis of the organic residue ultimately reveals a coalescent organism capable of mimicking and consuming other lifeforms—the true killer—that nearly attacks again before being destroyed.

StorySections.Text: Arriving at the relay station, an away team finds it powerless and deserted, with odd scorched patterns and a residue of what appears to be organic matter.
Geordi and Riker recover Aquiel Uhnari’s personal logs, which reveal her conflicts with her crewmate and her sense of being an outsider.
A Klingon ship returns Aquiel alive, claiming to have rescued her shuttle. Her stories do not match all the evidence, raising suspicion.
Forensic analysis and interviews point alternately toward Aquiel and the Klingon officer Morag as suspects. Geordi’s growing attachment complicates his judgment.
The organic residue reconstitutes aboard the Enterprise as a shape-shifting coalescent being, which attacks before Worf and others destroy it, clearing Aquiel of murder.
Aquiel decides to pursue a new assignment, and she and Geordi part on uncertain terms, their brief connection colored by the shadows of suspicion and danger.

Title: Face of the Enemy
Antagonists: Romulan secret police tactics of the Tal Shiar
Risk of exposure aboard a hostile warbird
Summary:
Troi awakens aboard a Romulan Warbird, surgically altered to appear Romulan and told she is now Major Rakal of the Tal Shiar. Subcommander N’Vek reveals that he and sympathetic Romulans are smuggling high-profile defectors to the Federation, using Troi’s assumed identity to intimidate the ship’s crew and commander Toreth. Troi, untrained for such a role, must quickly adapt to the ruthless demeanor expected of a Tal Shiar officer.

As the Warbird carries cargo pods that secretly house dissidents—including the family of a high-ranking official—Troi navigates a tense cat-and-mouse game with Toreth, who despises the Tal Shiar but fears crossing them. When the plan begins to unravel and Starfleet’s rendezvous window narrows, Troi must improvise under fire to save as many lives as possible, even as N’Vek’s own fate grows grim.

StorySections.Text: Troi, disoriented, looks into a mirror and sees a Romulan face staring back as a stern officer addresses her as Major Rakal of the Tal Shiar.
N’Vek explains the covert mission to transfer Romulan defectors via stolen Federation cargo pods, relying on Troi’s false authority to override objections.
Commander Toreth challenges Troi/Rakal’s decisions, testing the limits of her assumed power while voicing open contempt for the Tal Shiar’s methods.
The Warbird’s route deviates under suspicion, threatening the rendezvous with the Enterprise. N’Vek takes increasingly desperate risks to keep the operation on track.

When the plan collapses and N’Vek is killed, Troi bluffs Toreth into retreating by threatening to expose her as disloyal to the Tal Shiar. The dissidents reach safety with Starfleet, but Troi’s escape is narrow.
Back aboard the Enterprise, Troi reflects on the experience of embodying an enemy persona and on the bravery of those who resist oppressive regimes from within.

Title: Tapestry
Antagonists: Picard's regret over his reckless youth
Consequence of erasing formative mistakes
Summary:
After Picard is mortally wounded in a surprise attack and his artificial heart fails, he experiences a limbo-like state where Q appears, claiming to be a god presiding over Picard’s death. Q offers Picard a chance to revisit a pivotal moment from his youth: the bar fight on Starbase Earhart in which he was stabbed through the heart by Nausicaans, leading to the implant that has just failed. Given the opportunity to "do it right" this time, Picard chooses to avoid the confrontation.

Living out the revised timeline, Picard finds that his cautious younger self never distinguishes himself, remaining a risk-averse junior officer who is overlooked by his peers and superiors. Q returns to show him that by sanding off his rough edges, Picard has also removed the boldness that made him a great captain. Realizing that his mistakes were essential threads in the tapestry of his life, Picard chooses to accept the original injury and all that followed.

StorySections.Text: A mission goes wrong, and Picard suffers a catastrophic injury to his artificial heart. As he "dies" on the operating table, he finds himself in a white void with Q.
Q offers Picard the chance to revisit his rowdy Academy days with friends Corey and Marta, just before the infamous Nausicaan bar fight.
Determined to avoid the stabbing, Picard behaves cautiously, steering events away from the confrontation and suppressing his earlier arrogance.
Q jumps Picard forward to the present in the revised timeline, where he is a colorless lieutenant junior grade, lacking initiative and respect from his peers.
Confronted with the mediocrity of this alternate life, Picard chooses to accept his youthful recklessness. Q returns him to his body, and Crusher successfully repairs the damage.
Back on the Enterprise, Picard quietly reflects on the lesson that even painful mistakes can be vital to becoming who one is.

Title: Birthright, Part I
Antagonists: Rumors of Klingon prisoners held by Romulans
Data's unsettling dreams blurring line between programming and vision
Summary:
While the Enterprise is docked at Deep Space 9, an Yridian information broker named Jaglom Shrek approaches Worf with explosive news: Worf’s father Mogh did not die in honorable battle, but survived and has been living for years in a Romulan prison camp. Haunted by this possibility and what it would mean for his family’s honor, Worf struggles to decide whether to investigate or reject the claim as manipulation.

Meanwhile, a warp plasma accident in Engineering strikes Data and temporarily links his positronic matrix to the ship’s systems. Afterward, Data begins experiencing vivid dreamlike visions involving his father, Dr. Noonien Soong, and symbols such as a bird and an anvil. Counseling from Crusher and Picard encourages him to see these experiences as a new aspect of his evolving sentience. Ultimately, Worf chooses to travel with Shrek into Romulan space, setting out on a personal quest that will lead straight into the heart of the alleged camp.

StorySections.Text: At Deep Space 9, Worf navigates the bustle of the station while the Enterprise takes on supplies and crew mingle with Bajorans and Starfleet officers.
Jaglom Shrek corners Worf with the claim that Mogh is alive in a Romulan camp, demanding payment for details. Worf reacts with anger and disbelief.
A plasma discharge from an experimental device knocks Data unconscious. After recovering, he begins to experience peculiar, symbolic visions while offline.
Crusher and Picard help Data interpret his dreams as a potential new frontier in his self-awareness, prompting him to explore them rather than suppress them.
Driven by duty to his family name, Worf secures leave and forces Shrek to guide him into Romulan territory, even as Picard warns him of the risks. Their ship is attacked, and Worf is captured.
Worf regains consciousness in a secluded compound where Klingons and Romulans live together under mysterious, cloistered conditions.

Advances Data’s arc by introducing the concept of his dream subroutines.

Dreams and symbolism as components of an artificial mind.
Risking personal safety to uncover difficult truths about the past.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as a partial backdoor crossover with DS9, then a new series.
Uses parallel plots to explore both Worf’s and Data’s evolving identities.
Sets up Part II’s focus on cultural identity and captivity.

Title: Birthright, Part II
Antagonists: Tokath's secret Klingon-Romulan settlement
Suppression of Klingon heritage among the camp's youth
Summary:
Worf discovers that the Romulan "prison camp" he has been brought to is in fact a hidden colony where Klingon survivors of Khitomer and their Romulan captors have built a secluded community. To avoid dishonor for the survivors’ families and retribution from the Empire, Tokath—the Romulan commander—has kept the settlement secret for decades. The younger generation, including Ba’el, a half-Klingon, half-Romulan woman, has grown up knowing only this isolated life and little of Klingon culture.

Worf is appalled by the suppression of Klingon traditions and begins secretly teaching the youths about their heritage, from language and stories to the rituals of the bat’leth and the Rite of Ascension. As the camp’s fragile peace fractures, Tokath offers Worf a choice: accept exile in the settlement or die. Worf’s refusal and open embrace of Klingon honor inspire several young Klingons to leave with him, while others, including Ba’el, must decide where they truly belong.

StorySections.Text: Worf explores the camp and is stunned to see Klingons and Romulans living side by side, tending crops and sharing communal spaces.
Tokath explains that the Klingon survivors chose not to return home to avoid disgrace and have tried to build a peaceful life in hiding.
Worf meets Ba’el and the other youths, who are curious yet wary of his fierce devotion to Klingon customs they have been taught to dismiss.
Defying Tokath’s rules, Worf secretly instructs the young Klingons in their ancestral rites, rekindling a sense of pride and identity.

Tokath threatens to execute Worf to preserve the community’s secrecy. Worf accepts the prospect of death rather than renounce his heritage, prompting several youths to demand the right to leave with him.
Rescued by the Enterprise, Worf returns with a group of young Klingons ready to face the outside galaxy, while Ba’el chooses to remain behind and help her people reconcile their mixed heritage.

Title: Starship Mine
Antagonists: Mercenary team attempting to steal trilithium resin
Deadly baryon sweep that will sterilize the Enterprise
Summary:
The Enterprise docks at Arkaria Base for a baryon sweep, a procedure that will flood the ship with a lethal energy wave to decontaminate its hull. The crew is evacuated to a tedious reception hosted by the overly talkative Commander Hutchinson, while Picard returns briefly to retrieve his saddle. When he discovers a group of mercenaries led by Kelsey preparing to steal hazardous trilithium resin from the ship’s warp core, Picard finds himself alone aboard a vessel that is about to be swept clean of all life.

Using his knowledge of the ship’s systems and his own resourcefulness, Picard sabotages the intruders’ efforts and picks them off one by one, all while staying ahead of the slowly advancing baryon front. On the planet, Data’s attempt to emulate Hutchinson’s small talk becomes an unexpected asset when he notices anomalies in the base staff’s behavior, helping the crew uncover the conspiracy. In the end, Picard disables the thieves and narrowly escapes the sweep, saving both the Enterprise and Arkaria Base from catastrophic sabotage.

StorySections.Text: The crew prepares for an extended layover at Arkaria Base as the Enterprise undergoes a rare baryon sweep to remove accumulated radiation.
At the reception, Hutchinson’s relentless chatter tests everyone’s patience, while Picard slips away to reclaim a cherished saddle from his quarters.
Picard discovers armed intruders tampering with ship systems. He sabotages their equipment and adopts an alias to mislead them about his identity.
As the baryon sweep moves through the ship, Picard navigates sealed sections and booby-traps to stay ahead of both the energy wave and the mercenaries.

Data and the others realize that the reception staff are accomplices in the theft and disable their operation, while Picard confronts Kelsey in Engineering and prevents the removal of the trilithium resin.
With the sweep complete and the ship safe, Picard reunites with his crew, having single-handedly defended the Enterprise in classic action-hero fashion.

Title: Lessons
Antagonists: Conflict between command duty and personal attachment
Deadly firestorm on Bersallis III
Summary:
Picard becomes intrigued by the musical talents of Lieutenant Commander Nella Daren, a new head of Stellar Sciences who plays the piano in an otherwise empty Ten Forward. Their shared love of music blossoms into a romantic relationship, with intimate duets that echo Picard’s memories of the flute he once played as Kamin. For the first time in years, Picard allows himself to open up emotionally to a subordinate on his own ship.

When a catastrophic firestorm threatens a Federation outpost on Bersallis III, Daren volunteers to lead a hazardous planetary operation that only her expertise can manage. Picard, forced to send someone he loves into mortal danger, experiences the agony of watching casualty reports come in and believing she may have died under his orders. Though Daren ultimately survives, both realize that the conflict between Picard’s command responsibilities and their relationship is untenable.

StorySections.Text: Picard hears a haunting piano performance drifting through the corridors and follows the music to discover Nella Daren playing alone in Ten Forward.
Introductions lead to shared musical sessions, with Daren and Picard performing together in the ship’s Jeffries tubes and rekindling Picard’s passion for composition.
Their relationship deepens, drawing notice from crew members and prompting Crusher to quietly question Picard about the risks of shipboard romance with a subordinate.
A violent firestorm on Bersallis III endangers a Federation colony. Daren insists on leading an engineering team to deploy deflector shields on the surface, despite the extreme hazard.

As communications falter, Picard fears Daren has been killed carrying out his orders. When she returns alive but shaken, both recognize that continuing their relationship would compromise his ability to command.
Daren transfers off the Enterprise. Picard, alone in his quarters, plays the Ressikan flute, channeling both grief and gratitude for the brief connection they shared.

Title: The Chase
Antagonists: Competitive race among major powers to decode ancient DNA puzzle
Tensions between Federation, Cardassian, Klingon, and Romulan crews
Summary:
Picard’s former archaeology mentor, Professor Richard Galen, arrives on the Enterprise with a tantalizing proposal: leave Starfleet behind to join him in deciphering a mysterious genetic pattern found scattered among many worlds. Picard reluctantly declines due to his duties, only for Galen’s ship to be attacked shortly afterward. Before dying, Galen leaves Picard partial clues to the puzzle he was pursuing.

Picard becomes determined to complete Galen’s work, drawing the Enterprise into a race with Klingon, Cardassian, and eventually Romulan ships to collect genetic samples from disparate planets. Data discovers that the fragments combine into a coded sequence embedded in the DNA of countless humanoid species. When the final key is entered on a remote world, a holographic message from an ancient progenitor race appears, revealing that they seeded the galaxy’s worlds with compatible life and a hidden reminder of shared origins.

StorySections.Text: Professor Galen surprises Picard with an unannounced visit and a cryptic offer to embark on a long-term archaeological mission together.
After Picard declines, Galen departs in disappointment, only to be fatally attacked by unknown assailants. Picard vows to understand what was worth killing Galen for.
Following Galen’s clues, the Enterprise retrieves DNA samples from diverse worlds, crossing paths with Klingon captain Nu’Daq and Cardassian commander Gul Ocett, each pursuing the same goal.
Data assembles the genetic fragments into a complex algorithm requiring contributions from multiple species, forcing uneasy cooperation among the rival crews on a single planet.

When the code is completed, a holographic figure of an ancient humanoid appears, explaining that her people seeded the galaxy with compatible life long ago in hopes their descendants would eventually discover their common heritage.

The revelation leaves the assembled captains contemplative but does not immediately erase political tensions. Picard, however, takes comfort in the knowledge of a deeper connection among the galaxy’s peoples.

Title: Frame of Mind
Antagonists: Tilonian mental interrogation techniques
Riker's fragmented perception of reality
Summary:
Riker rehearses a demanding role in Dr. Crusher’s stage production, playing a man trapped in an asylum whose claims of being sane are dismissed as delusion. As the play nears performance, Riker begins experiencing disorienting flashes in which he seems to actually inhabit the asylum from the script, complete with a stern alien doctor named Suna insisting that his memories of the Enterprise are hallucinations.

Reality and illusion blur as Riker oscillates between the Enterprise, the stage, and the Tilonian institution, seeing familiar crewmates appear as doctors or fellow patients. He eventually discovers that he has been captured during a covert mission to Tilonus IV and subjected to invasive neural interrogation designed to extract Starfleet intelligence. By consciously rejecting each layer of illusion, Riker shatters the construct and returns to his true reality aboard the Enterprise.

StorySections.Text: On the Enterprise, Riker delivers an intense monologue during a rehearsal, only to reveal that he is performing for Crusher’s new play about a man in an asylum.
As opening night approaches, Riker sees brief, unsettling changes in his surroundings. After a blow to the head on an away mission, his sense of what is real begins to slip.
Riker awakens fully in a Tilonian psychiatric ward, with Dr. Suna insisting that his life as a Starfleet officer is a delusional construct he must abandon.
Shifting between the Enterprise, the stage, and the asylum, Riker becomes increasingly desperate as even Troi and Picard appear to validate contradictory realities.
Recognizing repeating patterns, Riker decides that none of the conflicting worlds can be trusted. By refusing to accept any of them, he destabilizes the Tilonian interrogation program.
Safely back aboard the Enterprise after rescue, Riker reflects with Troi on how convincingly his own mind turned against him under the enemy’s influence.

Title: Suspicions
Antagonists: Jo'Bril's deception and murder to steal metaphasic shielding
Scientific prejudice against a Ferengi researcher
Summary:
Crusher hosts an experimental test of metaphasic shielding, a radical new technique developed by Ferengi scientist Dr. Reyga to allow shuttlecraft to enter the corona of a star. A Takaran volunteer, Jo’Bril, pilots the shielded shuttle in a successful demonstration but is later found dead, apparently killed by the experiment. Reyga is blamed and soon turns up dead himself in an apparent suicide, leading Starfleet to shut down further investigation and hold Crusher responsible for the fiasco.

Convinced that Reyga’s work is sound and that foul play is involved, Crusher defies orders, secretly performing an unauthorized autopsy on Jo’Bril’s body. She discovers that his species’ unusual physiology allowed him to fake death and that he murdered Reyga in order to steal the metaphasic shielding technology. Exposing Jo’Bril and validating Reyga’s research ultimately costs Crusher politically, but clears her conscience and restores the Ferengi scientist’s legacy.

StorySections.Text: Crusher records a personal log explaining that she expects to be relieved of duty, then recounts the events that led to this point.
Dr. Reyga presents his metaphasic shield to a skeptical group of scientists aboard the Enterprise. Jo’Bril volunteers to pilot the test shuttle into a star’s corona.
After the test appears successful, Jo’Bril is found dead. Reyga is blamed for an unsafe experiment, and tensions rise among the visiting researchers.
Reyga dies in what looks like a suicide, prompting Starfleet to pressure Crusher to drop the matter. She secretly performs an illegal autopsy on Jo’Bril’s body.

Jo’Bril revives and attempts to steal a shuttle equipped with Reyga’s shielding, revealing himself as the murderer. Crusher outwits him and proves the shielding works, but must still face disciplinary review.
Picard informs Crusher that while there will be consequences, Starfleet has accepted her findings, and Reyga’s contribution will be acknowledged.

Title: Rightful Heir
Antagonists: Political manipulation of faith through cloning Kahless
Crisis of belief within the Klingon Empire
Summary:
Struggling with a loss of faith in Klingon traditions, Worf takes leave from the Enterprise to meditate at the monastic Boreth outpost, where priests await the prophesied return of Kahless the Unforgettable. During an intense vision, Kahless himself appears in the flesh, demonstrating knowledge of sacred texts and fighting skills that convince many he is the legendary warrior returned to lead the Empire.

Skepticism grows as Gowron arrives and challenges Kahless’s authenticity. Evidence eventually reveals that Koroth and the priests cloned Kahless from ancient DNA recovered from a sacred relic, intending to provide the Empire with a unifying figurehead. Torn between outrage at the deception and his desire for spiritual renewal, Worf helps broker a compromise in which Kahless becomes ceremonial Emperor while Gowron retains political power, symbolically restoring balance between faith and governance.

StorySections.Text: On the Enterprise, Worf’s uncharacteristic laxity in his duties leads Picard to confront him, prompting Worf to admit to a crisis of faith.
At Boreth, Worf joins other pilgrims waiting for a sign from Kahless. Long days of meditation culminate in a stunning apparition: Kahless appears, calling Worf by name.
Kahless’s words and deeds align with prophecy, winning Worf’s devotion and inspiring the faithful. Koroth hails his arrival as the fulfillment of long-awaited legends.
Gowron arrives, suspicious of a convenient miracle that threatens his rule. Scientific tests aboard the Enterprise reveal Kahless to be a clone, not a resurrected figure from the past.

Worf confronts Koroth over the deception but realizes that the Empire still needs a symbol of honor. He proposes that Kahless serve as Emperor in a spiritual, ceremonial role, while Gowron remains Chancellor.
As Worf departs, Kahless blesses him, and Worf returns to the Enterprise with a tempered but renewed sense of purpose and belief.

Title: Second Chances
Antagonists: Transporter accident that created a duplicate Riker
Emotional fallout of two Rikers confronting diverging lives
Summary:
The Enterprise returns to Nervala IV to retrieve a long-abandoned research outpost, using improved transporter techniques to penetrate the planet’s intermittent distortion field. There they discover a startling anomaly: an earlier away team member—another William Riker—has been stranded alive on the surface for eight years due to a transporter mishap that created a duplicate during evacuation. While one Riker went on to the Enterprise, the other remained marooned, believing himself to be the original.

The two Rikers struggle with jealousy, regret, and unresolved feelings, particularly regarding Troi, with whom the younger "Thomas" Riker still carries the intensity of their early relationship. Working together to recover the outpost’s data, they must confront how a single divergence created two very different lives. In the end, Thomas accepts an assignment away from the Enterprise to forge his own path, leaving both men changed by the unexpected second chance.

StorySections.Text: A hazardous attempt to re-access the Nervala IV outpost leads an away team to discover a lone survivor: a man who claims to be William Riker.
Medical and transporter records confirm that a duplication occurred years earlier, leaving two identical Rikers—one rescued then, one stranded until now.
The Rikers clash over career choices and personal sacrifices, with Thomas resentful that his life was effectively left behind while the other advanced.
Troi is drawn into the emotional triangle as Thomas rekindles their past romance, forcing her to re-examine what she wants from her future.
In a dangerous mission to recover the station’s critical data, the two Rikers must coordinate under pressure, proving they can work together despite their differences.
Thomas accepts a posting on the USS Gandhi, leaving the Enterprise to build a distinct identity, while Will and Troi quietly acknowledge that some roads remain untraveled.
