Title: Timescape
Antagonists: Temporal distortions freezing and accelerating time in localized fields
Unwittingly hostile alien entities gestating in the warp core
Summary:
While returning to the Enterprise aboard a runabout, Picard, Troi, Data, and Geordi encounter pockets of frozen and accelerated time, causing bizarre effects such as hours passing in seconds for some and vice versa. Their instruments trace the anomalies to the Enterprise’s last known coordinates. On arrival, they find the starship locked in a temporal stasis, apparently engaged in a battle with a Romulan Warbird, with both crews frozen at the moment of crisis.

Using devices that create personal time bubbles, the team boards the frozen ships and discovers that the apparent attack is not what it seems. Alien entities existing out of normal time are gestating within the Enterprise’s warp core, inadvertently destabilizing local time. As the distortions worsen and the Enterprise nears destruction, the away team must carefully manipulate events in near-frozen time to remove the entities without killing them or the crews.

StorySections.Text: Aboard the runabout, Picard and his officers experience strange temporal hiccups: Picard’s drawing changes between glances, and Geordi’s drink freezes mid-pour.
The runabout emerges to find the Enterprise and a Romulan Warbird locked motionless in apparent combat. Initial scans suggest catastrophic damage if time resumes unchecked.

Equipped with temporal field generators, the team boards the Enterprise and moves through eerie tableaux of frozen crew mid-action, noting inconsistencies that hint the situation is not a simple firefight.
Investigations reveal alien embryos in the warp core, using it as an incubation chamber. On the Romulan ship, the team finds evidence that the Romulans were actually trying to mitigate the crisis.

By carefully adjusting the timing of key events and moving the Romulan ship to safety, the officers free the alien entities into space as time flow is restored, saving both crews and avoiding a diplomatic incident.

Back in normal time, Picard jokes about his unsettling experience of temporarily growing a second heart due to temporal overlap, while the crew reflects on how deceptive appearances can be when time is fragmented.

Title: Descent, Part I
Antagonists: Splinter group of Borg exhibiting individuality and aggression
Lore's manipulation of Data and leadership of rogue Borg
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a Federation outpost under attack and finds a group of Borg unlike any they have encountered before—individualized, referring to themselves as "I" rather than "we," and employing tactics more akin to conventional ground troops. During the battle, Data experiences a surge of anger after killing one of the Borg, an emotion he has long believed himself incapable of feeling. Disturbed but intrigued, he becomes obsessed with recapturing the sensation.

A lone Borg named Crosis is taken prisoner and begins subtly manipulating Data, encouraging him to explore his newfound emotions and question his ethical constraints. Ultimately, Data abducts Crosis and hijacks a shuttle, leaving the Enterprise in pursuit. Following a trail to a remote planet, Picard leads an away team that discovers a settlement of rogue Borg led by Lore, Data’s brother, who claims to have freed them from the Collective—while secretly plotting something far darker.

StorySections.Text: On a Federation world, Starfleet officers are overwhelmed by a mysterious enemy. The Enterprise arrives to find the attackers are Borg, but acting in unfamiliar, coordinated squads.
In the ensuing firefight, Data kills a Borg and feels a sudden, intoxicating rush of anger. Conflicted, he replays the moment repeatedly in his memory.
Crosis, a captured Borg, engages Data in conversation, subtly undermining his confidence in his moral programming and encouraging the pursuit of emotion at any cost.
Data’s experiments to recreate the anger fail, leaving him frustrated. Under Crosis’s influence, he disables his own ethical subroutines and steals a shuttle with the Borg aboard.

Tracing the shuttle, the Enterprise locates a remote planet. An away team beams down to find a colony of individualized Borg led by Lore, who appears with Data at his side, proclaiming a new future for artificial and cybernetic life.

With the Enterprise in orbit and a large portion of the crew on the surface, Lore and his Borg followers prepare to implement plans that could threaten the Federation, setting up the cliffhanger for Part II.

Title: Descent, Part II
Antagonists: Lore's cult of individualized Borg
Data's compromised ethics under Lore's influence
Summary:
Picard and an away team are held captive in Lore’s compound while Data, influenced by an emotion chip Lore has taken from Dr. Soong, coldly assists his brother’s cruel experiments on Borg and prisoners alike. Lore claims to have liberated a group of Borg drones from the Collective, but in practice has forged them into a violent cult devoted to his own ambitions. Aboard the Enterprise, left in Crusher’s hands, junior officers and a skeleton crew must outthink Borg attempts to seize the ship while it hovers in the planet’s atmosphere.

Picard clandestinely reaches out to Hugh, the former drone once severed from the Collective, who now sees how Lore has twisted the promise of individuality. Hugh’s disillusionment sparks resistance among the Borg. In Lore’s lab, Data is ordered to dissect Geordi; memories of their friendship help him fight through the corrupt emotional signals and restore his ethical subroutines. He turns on Lore, disables him, and helps rescue the prisoners, while Crusher’s maneuvers keep the Enterprise intact long enough to recover the away team and depart.

StorySections.Text: On the planet, Picard and his team are marched into Lore’s stronghold as Data looks on without apparent remorse, while the Enterprise withdraws to a precarious position in the upper atmosphere.
Crusher organizes a reduced bridge crew to evade Borg ships and maintain atmospheric orbit. On the surface, Picard learns of Lore’s brutal "experiments" in the name of evolution.
Hugh secretly contacts Picard and admits that Lore’s promises of freedom have only led to more suffering. They plan to undermine Lore by turning disaffected Borg against him.
Lore orders Data to operate on Geordi to further suppress his emotions. Data’s conflicting memories cause glitches that hint his true personality is fighting to reassert itself.

As unrest spreads among the Borg, Data rejects Lore’s control, shuts down the transmitter feeding him corrupt emotional signals, and disables Lore. The Enterprise retrieves the away team and departs, leaving Hugh and his people to forge their own path.
Back on the Enterprise, Data studies the reclaimed emotion chip and confides to Picard that, after his experience under Lore, he is not yet ready to install it.

Title: Liaisons
Antagonists: Misguided Iyaaran experiments with emotion
Manipulative role-play stranding Picard on a hostile world
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts two ambassadors from the Iyaaran civilization as part of a cultural exchange: Loquel, assigned to Troi, and Byleth, assigned to Worf. Loquel becomes fascinated by pleasure, bingeing on desserts and entertainment, while Byleth probes anger by goading Worf with constant provocation. Picard departs by shuttle to meet a third Iyaaran representative, Voval, but the shuttle is forced down on a barren planet where Picard encounters a frightened human woman named Anna who claims to have been stranded for years.

Anna’s behavior becomes increasingly possessive and unstable as she declares her love for Picard and stages dramatic crises to keep him by her side. Back on the Enterprise, the crew struggles to adjust to the ambassadors’ strange behavior. Ultimately, Picard discovers that Anna is actually Voval in disguise and that the Iyaarans have orchestrated all three encounters as experiments on specific emotions—pleasure, antagonism, and romantic love—without regard for consent. Picard insists that if they truly want to understand humanity, they must abandon such manipulative methods.

StorySections.Text: The Iyaaran ambassadors arrive on the Enterprise, speaking precisely but displaying little outward emotion as they are introduced to their hosts.
Loquel quickly develops a fondness for desserts and light entertainment with Troi, while Byleth pushes Worf’s patience by demanding confrontation and challenge at every opportunity.
Picard’s shuttle is forced to crash on a desolate world. He meets Anna, who claims to have been abandoned and latches onto him with desperate gratitude.
Anna’s affection shifts into obsession, culminating in a staged suicide attempt when Picard resists her demands. Suspicious, Picard begins testing the reality of his surroundings.

Voval reveals himself and admits that the Iyaarans manufactured the scenario to study love, just as Loquel and Byleth have been probing pleasure and anger. Picard condemns the ethics of their experiment and urges a more honest approach to understanding.
As the Iyaarans depart, each ambassador has gained a limited but genuine appreciation for the complexity of human emotions they sought to catalogue.

Title: Interface
Antagonists: Geordi's denial over his mother's presumed death
Miscommunication with non-corporeal aliens in a gas giant
Summary:
Geordi tests a neural interface that allows him to control a remote probe as if it were his own body, receiving visual and tactile input directly to his brain. When the starship Hera, commanded by his mother Silva La Forge, is reported missing, the Enterprise is assigned to search a turbulent gas giant near its last known coordinates. Using the interface, Geordi pilots the probe deep into the atmosphere, where he sees and hears what appears to be his mother calling for help.

As evidence mounts that the Hera has been destroyed, Geordi clings to the belief that his mother and her crew are still alive within the giant. Picard and Crusher grow concerned that prolonged use of the interface is affecting his judgment and endangering his health. Ultimately, Geordi realizes that the figure he has been speaking to is actually a non-corporeal alien using his memories to secure his help in freeing its people from an energy field. By assisting the aliens’ escape, Geordi gains some measure of closure about his mother’s fate.

StorySections.Text: Geordi demonstrates the neural interface by remotely operating a probe, exhilarated by the sensation of walking unaided in a simulated environment.
News of the Hera’s disappearance reaches the Enterprise. Geordi throws himself into the search, eager to use the interface to explore the dangerous gas giant more safely.

While linked to the probe, Geordi encounters an image of Silva La Forge, who urges him to keep searching despite the risks. Crusher warns that the interface is putting dangerous strain on his nervous system.
Convinced his mother is alive, Geordi defies orders to continue the mission. Data and Picard try to balance respect for his feelings with the need to keep him from harming himself.

Geordi discovers that the "mother" he has seen is an alien entity trying to free its companions. He adjusts the probe to disrupt the field trapping them, then accepts that his real mother is almost certainly gone.
Later, Geordi quietly remembers his parents with Data, acknowledging that honoring them means living fully rather than clinging to false hope.

Title: Gambit, Part I
Antagonists: Mercenary crew raiding archaeological sites
Mysterious weapon components of ancient Vulcan origin
Summary:
Evidence from a remote outpost suggests that Picard has been killed during an attack on an archaeological dig, leaving the Enterprise crew stunned. Riker assumes command and follows a trail of mercenary raids on ancient sites across the sector, suspecting a link to Picard’s apparent death. Tracking a heavily armed raider vessel, he is captured and brought aboard a ship commanded by the ruthless Baran, who uses implanted pain devices to control his crew.

To protect the Enterprise and gather intelligence, Riker pretends to be disillusioned with Starfleet and offers his services as a mercenary. He discovers that the crew is collecting obscure artifacts that seem to be components of an unknown device. Among the raiders is a sharp-tongued archaeologist called Galen, who Riker eventually recognizes as Picard working undercover. The two officers must maintain their cover stories while maneuvering around Baran and probing the true purpose behind the Vulcan artifacts.

StorySections.Text: On a seedy outpost, Riker and his team identify Picard’s effects and apparent remains, returning to the Enterprise with news of the captain’s death.
Riker takes command and pursues intelligence that points toward a mercenary ship targeting archaeological sites, determining to track down those responsible.
Captured during a confrontation, Riker is tested by Baran, who uses pain implants to enforce obedience. Riker plays the role of a bitter ex-officer to win a place on the crew.
Riker notices that the raiders are collecting unusual Vulcan artifacts from multiple worlds. He clashes with the abrasive Galen over priorities and methods.
Galen reveals himself as Picard in disguise. Together, he and Riker quietly coordinate a strategy to manipulate Baran while uncovering who is orchestrating the search for the artifacts.
As the mercenary ship sets course for its next target, Picard and Riker maintain their uneasy undercover partnership, aware that one wrong move could expose them both.

Title: Gambit, Part II
Antagonists: Vulcan isolationist plot to restore the Stone of Gol
Psionic resonator weapon that amplifies violent thoughts
Summary:
As suspicion grows aboard the mercenary ship, Baran questions both Riker and Galen, uncertain whom to trust. Picard seizes on this tension, manipulating events so that Baran is killed by his own pain-control system, after which Picard assumes command of the raider vessel to keep the mission on track. The completed set of artifacts points toward a hidden Vulcan temple that may house the psionic resonator, a legendary mental weapon associated with the Stone of Gol.

Tallera reveals herself as an operative of a Vulcan isolationist movement, intent on using the resonator to eliminate political opponents and force Vulcan withdrawal from interstellar affairs. She forces Picard and the raiders to assist her in assembling and activating the device. On Vulcan, however, Picard deduces that the resonator’s power depends on amplifying aggressive thoughts. By keeping his emotions calm and directing others to do the same, he renders the weapon ineffective, exposing Tallera’s ideology as both dangerous and ultimately self-defeating.

StorySections.Text: Baran’s paranoia reaches a breaking point as he confronts Riker and Galen, unaware that Picard is setting the stage for his downfall.
Picard turns Baran’s pain-control device against him, engineering an apparent mutiny and presenting himself as the new captain to the rest of the raiders.
Tallera drops her neutral facade, revealing her extremist agenda and demanding the crew’s cooperation in completing the resonator on Vulcan.
At the ancient temple, the psionic resonator is assembled and powered up. The Enterprise crew pieces together the political implications of Tallera’s plan from intercepted communications.

When Tallera attempts to use the resonator against her perceived enemies, Picard instructs everyone present to suppress violent thoughts. The weapon fizzles, proving powerless without hostility to feed on, and Tallera is taken into custody.
Back aboard the Enterprise, Picard and Riker consider how often ancient relics become tools for modern extremism, and Picard is relieved to return to straightforward exploration.

Title: Phantasms
Antagonists: Interphasic organisms feeding on the crew
Disturbing manifestations in Data's dream program
Summary:
As the Enterprise prepares for the formal launch of a new warp core modification, Data continues his exploration of dream subroutines. He begins experiencing unsettling imagery: Troi as a cellular "cake" being sliced, crew members drinking from his body through straws, and a phone embedded in his torso. The dreams leave him anxious that something is wrong with his positronic net. When hallucinations intrude into waking life and Data stabs Troi while in a trance, the crew realizes a deeper threat is at work.

Medical scans reveal that the crew are being drained by invisible interphasic organisms attracted by the experimental warp emissions. Data’s unique perception lets him sense the parasites symbolically through his dreams. By interpreting the dream imagery as encoded clues, Picard and Data identify a specific modulated signal that can drive the organisms away. Broadcasting the frequency clears the infestation, restoring the crew and stabilizing Data’s internal processes.

StorySections.Text: Data wanders a dreamlike Enterprise, culminating in a bizarre birthday party where Troi, in cake form, urges him to cut into her with a knife.
Disturbed, Data consults a holodeck simulation of Sigmund Freud, who offers symbolic interpretations that only partly fit the situation.
Crew members display unexplained fatigue and cellular anomalies. Data’s waking hallucinations intensify until he suddenly attacks Troi in a turbolift under an unseen compulsion.
Confined to Engineering for study, Data insists that his dreams contain vital information. Geordi links abnormalities in warp emissions to the onset of the crisis.

Decoding symbolic elements from Data’s dreams, Picard and Data identify interphasic parasites clinging to the hull and determine a resonant frequency that, when broadcast, drives them off and reverses the crew’s decline.
With normal operations restored, Troi encourages Data to continue dreaming, reminding him that even disturbing dreams can serve a purpose in understanding oneself and the world.

Title: Dark Page
Antagonists: Lwaxana's repressed trauma over the death of her first daughter
Psychic overload from intense communication with the Cairn
Summary:
The Enterprise hosts a delegation of Cairn, a telepathic species newly learning to communicate verbally with Lwaxana Troi’s guidance. Under the strain of helping them adapt, Lwaxana collapses and falls into a coma with no clear physical cause. Deanna learns from the Cairn ambassador Maques that her mother’s mind is barricaded behind a deeply buried trauma she has never shared, and that the intensive telepathic work has forced those memories toward the surface.

With Maques’s help, Deanna enters Lwaxana’s subconscious, where she navigates distorted versions of their family home and the Enterprise, repeatedly glimpsing a small girl whom Lwaxana angrily denies exists. Deanna gradually uncovers the truth: before Deanna’s birth, Lwaxana had another daughter, Kestra, who died in an accident, and Lwaxana coped by erasing all mention of her from their lives. By confronting the memory together, mother and daughter begin to grieve openly, allowing Lwaxana to awaken and start healing.

StorySections.Text: Lwaxana proudly introduces the Cairn delegation to Picard, but moments later her poise cracks, hinting at strain beneath her flamboyant exterior.
Lwaxana collapses during a demonstration of telepathy. Crusher’s scans show no physical cause, pointing to a telepathic or psychological crisis.
Maques tells Deanna that Lwaxana carries a hidden sorrow too painful to share. Deanna agrees to link minds with her mother to seek the source of the block.
Inside Lwaxana’s mind, Deanna encounters shifting images of her childhood home and the Enterprise, with a mysterious little girl appearing at the edges of memory that Lwaxana insists must be ignored.
Deanna forces the truth into focus, reliving the day Kestra died and Lwaxana’s decision to bury the memory. Acknowledging Kestra breaks the mental dam and allows Lwaxana to return to consciousness.
Awake, Lwaxana and Deanna speak of Kestra openly for the first time, beginning the process of integrating her memory into their family instead of hiding it.

Title: Attached
Antagonists: Paranoid isolationism of the Prytt Alliance
Involuntary telepathic link exposing Picard and Crusher's feelings
Summary:
The Enterprise visits the divided world of Kesprytt III to evaluate the outward-looking Kes for possible Federation membership, while the xenophobic Prytt Alliance remains hostile and secretive. Picard and Crusher beam down to meet Kes officials but are abducted en route by Prytt security forces, who implant devices in their necks before the two officers escape into hostile territory. The implants create a permanent telepathic link that causes Picard and Crusher to hear each other’s thoughts and feel one another’s emotions.

As they trek across rugged terrain to reach Kes territory, Picard and Crusher must learn to manage the intimacy of shared thoughts, confronting long-suppressed feelings and past romantic tension. Meanwhile, on orbit, the Kes struggle to prove they are ready for Federation membership while the Prytt demonstrate extreme paranoia. Ultimately, Picard concludes that the deep mistrust between the two powers makes Kesprytt III unsuitable for admission. Back on the Enterprise, he and Beverly acknowledge the truths revealed by their link, but decide to proceed cautiously in redefining their relationship.

StorySections.Text: Picard briefs the crew on the politically divided world of Kesprytt III, where the Kes seek Federation membership and the Prytt remain aggressively isolationist.
Beaming down to meet Kes officials, Picard and Crusher are instead captured by Prytt agents, who implant neural devices and imprison them as alleged spies.
Escaping confinement, Picard and Crusher discover that the implants have linked their thoughts, causing them to hear each other’s inner reactions as they navigate dangerous countryside.

On the Enterprise, Riker negotiates separately with uncooperative Prytt and anxious Kes representatives. On the surface, Picard and Beverly’s shared thoughts force them to confront buried feelings and past decisions about their relationship.

Rescued and freed from the Prytt devices, Picard recommends against admitting Kesprytt III to the Federation due to the depth of mistrust on the planet. Later, he and Beverly speak frankly about what their telepathic link revealed, acknowledging feelings but choosing not to rush into change.
Over a quiet breakfast, Picard and Crusher share an easy, if slightly more aware, camaraderie, suggesting that their friendship has been permanently deepened by the experience.

Title: Force of Nature
Antagonists: Subspace damage caused by warp travel
Extremist action to prove an environmental threat
Summary:
The Enterprise investigates the disappearance of starships in the Hekaras Corridor, a narrow, stable route through a region of otherwise hazardous space. There they encounter Hekaran scientists Serova and Rabal, who insist that warp drive is causing cumulative damage to the fabric of subspace, with the corridor on the verge of catastrophic collapse. Geordi is skeptical of their theoretical model and worried that accepting it would undermine the entire basis of Federation travel.

To prove her point, Serova deliberately destabilizes her own warp core, triggering a subspace rupture that severely disrupts the corridor and strands ships in the region. Confronted with irrefutable evidence, Starfleet is forced to accept that unrestricted warp travel can damage subspace. In the aftermath, Picard informs the crew that the Federation Council will impose new limits on warp speeds in sensitive regions, beginning a process of reforming long-standing practices.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise searches the Hekaras Corridor for missing vessels, threading its way through a region of unusual subspace instability.
Serova and Rabal present their data, arguing that repeated warp fields are tearing subspace, but Geordi questions their assumptions and methods.
Evidence of severe subspace variations accumulates. Serova grows frustrated at Starfleet’s reluctance to act on her warnings.
In a desperate bid to force recognition, Serova intentionally destroys her ship, creating a visible subspace rift that cripples warp travel in the corridor.
With the corridor damaged, Picard orders reduced warp speeds and relays Starfleet’s new environmental guidelines, acknowledging the need to balance exploration with responsibility.
Geordi quietly reflects on the idea that even wondrous technologies can have unforeseen environmental costs that engineers must learn to mitigate.

Title: Inheritance
Antagonists: Ethical dilemma of revealing Juliana's true nature
Planetary core crisis on Atrea IV
Summary:
The Enterprise assists the planet Atrea IV with a project to re-liquefy its solidifying core, preventing ecological catastrophe. Among the visiting scientists is Juliana Tainer, who introduces herself as Dr. Noonien Soong’s former wife and claims to have helped design Data. Intrigued, Data seeks to learn more about his creator and human "mother," forging an emotional connection as she shares stories of his early development and the destruction of Omicron Theta.

During a crisis in the planetary core, Juliana is injured and revealed, through medical scanning, to be an advanced android herself—an unconscious copy Soong created after the real Juliana’s death. A prerecorded holographic message from Soong explains that he wanted her to live out a normal life without knowing she was artificial. Picard and Data must decide whether to tell Juliana the truth. In the end, Data chooses to preserve her illusion of humanity, accepting that her lived experiences and relationships matter more than the secret of her construction.

StorySections.Text: Juliana Tainer arrives with a team of scientists, surprising Data by introducing herself as his "mother" and recounting details of his early life with Soong.
As they work on stabilizing Atrea IV’s core, Juliana and Data bond over music and memories, while she gently questions his understanding of humanity and emotion.
A geological emergency forces Juliana and Data into dangerous conditions. When she is injured, Crusher discovers mechanical components beneath otherwise human tissue.
A hidden chip in Juliana’s body triggers a holographic recording of Soong, explaining that the real Juliana died and that this android duplicate was never meant to know her true nature.

Data debates whether to reveal the truth, torn between respect for her autonomy and Soong’s intention to spare her pain. He ultimately chooses not to tell her, allowing her to continue believing she is human.
Watching Juliana depart, unaware of the revelation, Data reflects with Picard on the meaning of identity and on how human someone can be, regardless of origin.

Title: Parallels
Antagonists: Quantum fissure destabilizing Worf's reality
Threat of universes colliding in the quantum flux
Summary:
Returning from a bat’leth tournament, Worf begins to notice small discrepancies aboard the Enterprise—paintings changing, cake flavors switching, crew ranks shifting. At first he believes he is simply exhausted, but the differences grow more dramatic: in one version of reality, he and Troi are married; in another, the Cardassians and Federation are at war; in yet another, the Enterprise has suffered heavy damage and crew losses.

Data determines that Worf is slipping between parallel quantum realities due to a quantum fissure and a shuttle accident near a spatial anomaly. As the fissure destabilizes, multiple versions of the Enterprise converge, risking catastrophic overlap of entire universes. Guided by Data, Worf must return to the correct shuttle and align its quantum signature, closing the fissure. He succeeds and finds himself back in his original timeline—though his awareness of the universe where he and Troi are together leaves both of them contemplating what might yet be possible.

StorySections.Text: Worf returns from a successful bat’leth tournament on Forcas III and is surprised by a small birthday celebration, noting subtle differences he cannot quite place.
Worf experiences minor shifts in his surroundings—cake flavors, paintings, security arrangements—leading him to question his memory and sanity.
The changes escalate: Worf finds that in one timeline he and Troi are romantically involved, while in another, Picard is dead and Riker commands the ship in wartime.
Data traces Worf’s shifting quantum signature to a fissure created by his shuttle’s passage through a spatial anomaly. Multiple Enterprises begin to appear on sensors, all drawn to the same point.

As hundreds of Enterprises crowd the fissure, one war-ravaged ship begs to remain in the safer universe. Worf, guided by Data, realigns his shuttle’s quantum signature and seals the fissure, restoring a single reality.
Back in his own timeline, Worf awkwardly invites Troi to dinner, hinting that knowledge of alternate futures has changed how he sees their relationship.

Title: The Pegasus
Antagonists: Illegal Federation phase-cloaking experiment
Pressman's determination to hide a past cover-up
Summary:
The Enterprise is ordered to rendezvous with Admiral Pressman, Riker’s former commanding officer on the ill-fated USS Pegasus, which was lost years earlier under mysterious circumstances. Pressman informs Picard that new intelligence suggests the Pegasus may actually be intact, wedged inside an asteroid in Romulan space, and that recovering its experimental technology is a top priority. Riker is troubled, recalling a mutiny aboard the Pegasus that he helped suppress as a young officer.

As the Enterprise races a Romulan Warbird to the wreck, Picard grows suspicious of the secrecy surrounding the mission and presses Riker for the truth. It emerges that the Pegasus was testing an illegal phasing cloak that would allow a starship to pass through matter and remain undetectable, in violation of the Federation’s treaty with the Romulans. When the Enterprise uses the recovered device to escape being trapped in an asteroid, Picard confronts Pressman and refuses to participate in the cover-up. Riker finally sides with Picard, ready to face the consequences of exposing the truth.

StorySections.Text: Riker receives unexpected orders to rendezvous with Admiral Pressman, triggering uneasy memories of his first posting aboard the USS Pegasus.
Pressman comes aboard and briefs Picard on the mission to retrieve the lost Pegasus from Romulan space, emphasizing secrecy above all else.
As the Enterprise locates the Pegasus fused inside an asteroid, Picard questions Riker about inconsistencies in the official report, but Riker refuses to break his old oath to Pressman.
Onboard the wreck, Picard and Riker discover the experimental phasing cloak still installed. A Romulan ship arrives, trapping the Enterprise by sealing the surrounding rock.

Pressman orders the cloak activated to escape, exposing the nature of the experiment. After phasing the Enterprise through solid rock to safety, Picard places Pressman under arrest and Riker agrees to testify about the illegal program.
Picard and Riker discuss the burden of divided loyalties, with Riker acknowledging that his duty to the law and the truth must prevail over old obligations.

Title: Homeward
Antagonists: Imminent atmospheric collapse on Boraal II
Ethical conflict between the Prime Directive and saving lives
Summary:
The Enterprise responds to a distress call from Boraal II, a pre-warp world whose atmosphere is disintegrating. Aboard the planet’s observation post, Worf’s foster brother, Nikolai Rozhenko, has been covertly studying the Boraalans. By the time the Enterprise arrives, the atmosphere has collapsed, apparently wiping out all life on the surface. However, Nikolai has secretly transported a village of Boraalans into a holodeck recreation of their valley, violating the Prime Directive to save them from extinction.

Picard is furious at Nikolai’s unauthorized intervention but also reluctant to condemn an entire community to death now that they have been saved. The crew must maintain the illusion that the Boraalans are still on their homeworld while preparing to resettle them on a similar planet. When a villager named Vorin discovers the truth and cannot reconcile it with his worldview, tragedy results. Ultimately, the Boraalans are relocated with minimal exposure to advanced technology, while Worf and Nikolai wrestle with the moral cost of the rescue.

StorySections.Text: The Enterprise races to Boraal II in response to a planetary distress call, only to find the atmosphere already collapsing beyond repair.
At the observation post, Worf discovers that his foster brother Nikolai has mysteriously survived and reacts evasively when questioned about the fate of the Boraalans.
Nikolai reveals that he secretly transported a village into a holodeck simulation of their homeland to preserve them, stunning Picard with his blatant Prime Directive violation.
As the crew struggles to maintain the illusion, a curious villager, Vorin, wanders into the ship and is overwhelmed by the revelation of a wider universe.
Vorin’s inability to adapt leads to his death, underscoring the danger of cultural contamination. The remaining Boraalans are resettled on a new world, believing they survived a great storm.
Nikolai chooses to remain with the Boraalans as one of them, while Worf reflects on the painful balance between obeying principles and preserving lives.

Title: Sub Rosa
Antagonists: Ronin, the anaphasic lifeform preying on Crusher women
Cultural expectations and superstition on Caldos II
Summary:
On the colony world Caldos II, modeled after old Scotland, Beverly Crusher attends the funeral of her grandmother, Felisa Howard. Settling her grandmother’s affairs, she discovers references to a mysterious man named Ronin who has supposedly been the Howard women’s companion for generations. Beverly begins experiencing seductive, ghostlike encounters and is drawn into a romantic relationship with an unseen presence claiming to be Ronin, despite warnings from the superstitious caretaker Ned Quint.

As Beverly’s behavior grows erratic, strange energy readings appear around her grandmother’s grave and the weather control system malfunctions. Picard and Data investigate and discover that Ronin is actually an anaphasic lifeform that has been bonding with women in Beverly’s family, using them as hosts in exchange for heightened sensations. Realizing she has been manipulated and endangered, Beverly disrupts Ronin’s energy matrix at her grandmother’s grave, ending his centuries-long hold on her family.

StorySections.Text: Beverly attends Felisa Howard’s burial on foggy Caldos II and notices an enigmatic man watching from a distance before vanishing into the mist.
Sorting through her grandmother’s belongings, Beverly finds a journal describing a timeless lover named Ronin. Soon she experiences mysterious sensations that mirror Felisa’s accounts.
Beverly’s involvement with the unseen Ronin deepens, leading her to resign from Starfleet and move into her grandmother’s home, while Ned Quint frantically warns of danger.
Energy anomalies disrupt the colony’s weather grid. Picard and Data trace the disturbances to Beverly’s home and Felisa’s grave, uncovering Ronin’s anaphasic nature.
Confronted with Ronin’s history of possessing Howard women, Beverly resists his influence, destroys the candle that anchors him, and fires on the entity at the grave, dispersing him for good.
Back aboard the Enterprise, Beverly reflects somberly on the experience, recognizing how grief and loneliness left her vulnerable to a predatory presence.

Title: Lower Decks
Antagonists: Dangerous covert mission into Cardassian space
Pressure and opacity of command decisions on junior officers
Summary:
The episode shifts focus to a group of junior officers—Sito Jaxa, Sam Lavelle, Taurik, and Nurse Ogawa—who juggle friendship, competition, and career ambitions aboard the Enterprise. They speculate about cryptic orders from senior staff while undergoing performance reviews and vying for promotions. Sito, a Bajoran ensign with a troubled academy record, faces skepticism due to her involvement in the Nova Squadron scandal but is given a chance by Picard to prove her worth.

A covert mission arises involving a Cardassian operative posing as a defector who must be returned secretly to Cardassian space. Sito volunteers to accompany him in a small craft, using her Bajoran heritage as cover, fully aware of the risk. When her ship disappears and later wreckage is found, the crew realizes she has been killed. Her friends and the senior staff alike quietly mourn, while the Enterprise continues on its way, underscoring the unseen sacrifices that support its missions.

StorySections.Text: Over poker, junior officers Lavelle, Sito, Ogawa, Taurik, and civilian waiter Ben gossip about the senior staff and puzzle over recent unusual orders.
Performance reviews loom as Riker, Worf, and others evaluate the ensigns. Sito struggles against the shadow of her academy scandal while Lavelle nervously angles for advancement.
A battered Cardassian claiming to be a defector is brought aboard, his arrival classified. The junior officers notice heightened tension and restricted areas on the ship.
Picard confronts Sito about her past, then offers her a dangerous mission to escort the Cardassian back across the border in a stolen shuttle, using a covert flight path.

Sito’s shuttle fails to return. A Cardassian broadcast reports a Bajoran prisoner killed attempting to cross the border. The senior staff confirms her death and reflects on her bravery, while her friends grieve in Ten Forward.
Worf quietly toasts Sito’s memory with Ben as the Enterprise carries on, symbolizing the many unsung lives that support Starfleet’s ideals.

Title: Thine Own Self
Antagonists: Radioactive contamination from recovered fragments
Data's amnesia on a pre-industrial world
Summary:
After recovering radioactive debris from a crashed probe, Data is sent to return the dangerous fragments using a cargo case. An accident leaves him with complete amnesia on the pre-industrial planet Barkon IV, carrying the case into a village whose inhabitants call him "Jayden" and assume he is a wandering "iceman" from the mountains. Local healer Talur studies his unusual physiology while villagers, including the blacksmith Garvin and his daughter Gia, befriend him.

Unaware of the danger, villagers begin fashioning jewelry from the iridescent metal fragments, spreading radiation sickness. Data slowly pieces together that the metal is harmful and tries to warn the villagers, but their fear and suspicion escalate. He is attacked and apparently killed while attempting to remove the fragments, only to be later recovered by the Enterprise, which traces his signal. Meanwhile on the ship, Troi undergoes the command qualification test, ultimately succeeding when she realizes she must be willing to order a crew member to their likely death to save the ship.

StorySections.Text: Data stumbles into a village on Barkon IV, his memory gone, carrying a case of strange metallic fragments as suspicious locals look on.
The villagers nickname Data "Jayden" and assume he is an outsider from the mountains. Talur examines him, baffled by his physiology but eager to learn.
Garvin unknowingly distributes the glowing metal as jewelry, and people begin to fall ill. Talur misattributes the sickness to familiar local causes.
Data gradually deduces that the fragments are dangerous, trying to confiscate them and explain the threat, but the frightened villagers see his actions as sinister.

A mob attacks Data as he attempts to remove the last of the metal, apparently destroying him. The Enterprise recovers his body and the fragments, while Troi passes her command test by making a hard hypothetical choice in the holodeck.
With Data restored and Troi newly qualified as a bridge officer, the crew reflects on the burdens of command and the unintended consequences of contact with less advanced worlds.

Title: Masks
Antagonists: Alien archive overwriting the Enterprise
Masaka personality overtaking Data
Summary:
The Enterprise intercepts a massive comet-like object that actually contains a dormant alien archive. When the archive is inadvertently activated, strange geometric structures and symbols begin appearing throughout the ship, while computer systems transform into representations of an ancient culture. Data is affected directly, his positronic net overwritten by multiple personalities drawn from the archive’s mythos, including Masaka and Korgano.

As the transformation accelerates, the Enterprise itself risks being permanently rewritten into a monument for the long-dead civilization. Picard, Troi, and Geordi study the emerging artifacts and myths, deducing that Masaka is a powerful, sun-associated figure and Korgano a complementary moon figure. By assuming the role of Korgano and confronting Masaka through Data, Picard follows the logic of the myth, persuading the system to complete its cycle and go dormant again, restoring both Data and the ship.

StorySections.Text: Scanning a comet, the Enterprise detects an unusual energy signature within, leading to the discovery of a concealed alien archive.
After initial scans, strange artifacts and patterns appear on the ship, and Data begins exhibiting odd behavioral shifts and unfamiliar speech.
The archive’s program spreads, reshaping corridors and rooms into symbolic structures. Data cycles through various personalities from the archive’s mythology.
Picard and Troi decipher the symbolic roles of Masaka and Korgano, realizing they represent opposing forces in an endless celestial chase.
Picard adopts the mantle of Korgano in a ritual confrontation with Masaka, now speaking through Data. Completing the myth’s cycle causes the archive to power down and the ship to revert to normal.
With his normal personality restored, Data remembers fragments of the myth, and Picard reflects on having briefly walked through the living memory of a vanished civilization.

Title: Eye of the Beholder
Antagonists: Residual telepathic impressions of a past murder-suicide
Psychological fallout from empathic overload
Summary:
When a crewmember, Lt. Kwan, unexpectedly commits suicide by jumping into a warp plasma stream, Troi and Worf investigate the circumstances that led to his death. Their inquiry takes them into a long-unused section of the ship near a warp nacelle, where Troi experiences powerful, disturbing empathic impressions of fear and violence. She begins to see visions of events from years earlier, involving a volatile relationship between an engineer and a half-Betazoid woman.

As Troi’s investigation continues, she and Worf grow closer, exploring the possibility of a romantic relationship. However, Troi’s visions spiral into a false reality in which she believes Worf has betrayed her, leading her to consider suicide herself. She snaps back to awareness just in time, realizing that she has been influenced by lingering telepathic echoes of a murder-suicide that occurred during the Enterprise’s construction. The investigation reveals that Kwan was susceptible to the same psychic residue, explaining his death and warning the crew about the dangers of such empathic imprints.

StorySections.Text: On a routine inspection, Lt. Kwan suddenly throws himself into a plasma stream, shocking the crew and prompting an immediate inquiry.
Troi and Worf begin interviewing colleagues and reviewing logs to understand Kwan’s state of mind, discovering that he mentioned strange feelings near a certain nacelle area.
In the restricted section, Troi experiences vivid impressions of a past argument between a couple, leading her to believe she is seeing residual echoes of a tragedy.
As Troi envisions an affair, jealousy, and violence involving Worf and others, she becomes emotionally entangled with the scenario and with Worf himself.

On the brink of repeating Kwan’s suicide, Troi realizes that her entire recent experience has been a telepathically induced hallucination rooted in a long-ago murder-suicide. She pulls back and has the area sealed and monitored for empathic effects.
Later, Troi and Worf quietly acknowledge the strange, intense bond they briefly shared, unsure what—if anything—it means for their real relationship.

Title: Genesis
Antagonists: Retro-viral infection causing de-evolution
Runaway mutation of Barclay's treatment
Summary:
After Barclay receives an experimental treatment from Crusher to activate dormant genes in his immune system, the Enterprise departs on a routine weapons test. Weeks later, Picard and Data return from a separate mission to find the ship adrift and eerily silent. Exploring the decks, they discover that most of the crew have undergone dramatic physical and behavioral changes—"de-evolving" into earlier evolutionary forms.

Worf has become a hyper-aggressive, venomous predator; Troi has regressed toward an amphibious state; Riker and Ogawa show other primitive traits. Data and Picard determine that Barclay’s modified treatment mutated into an airborne retrovirus that activated ancestral genes across the crew. Using samples from his cat Spot’s offspring, which somehow resisted the changes, Data devises an antidote and disperses it through the ship, restoring the crew to normal and later giving the condition the unofficial name "Barclay’s Protomorphosis Syndrome."

StorySections.Text: Barclay nervously submits to Crusher’s new treatment for a stubborn medical issue, while the Enterprise prepares for a series of torpedo tests.
Returning from a mission, Picard and Data find the Enterprise drifting in space with no response to hails. They board to investigate the apparently abandoned ship.
Picard and Data encounter crew members who have radically changed: Troi submerged in a pool, Riker barely coherent, and strange animalistic sounds echoing through the corridors.
Data traces the cause to a mutation in Barclay’s treatment that rewrote crew DNA. They narrowly survive an encounter with a feral, hunting Worf in the darkened corridors.
Using genetic material from Spot’s unaffected kittens, Data formulates an antidote and releases it via the environmental systems, reversing the de-evolution and saving the crew.
Back to normal, Barclay is horrified to learn the syndrome has been nicknamed after him, while Crusher reassures him that the crew’s recovery proves the value of scientific risk tempered by caution.

Title: Journey's End
Antagonists: Forced relocation of a Native American colony
Internal conflict over Starfleet duty versus spiritual calling
Summary:
Admiral Necheyev boards the Enterprise to oversee implementation of a new treaty with the Cardassians that redraws the Federation border. One Federation colony—Dorvan V, home to a community of Native Americans who resettled there to preserve their traditions—now falls on the Cardassian side and must be evacuated. Picard, burdened by the historical memory of his ancestor’s role in earlier Earth relocations, is tasked with convincing the colonists to leave.

Among the colonists is Lakanta, a spiritual guide who takes a particular interest in Wesley Crusher, visiting from the Academy and struggling with disillusionment. Through visions and introspection, Wesley realizes he no longer belongs at Starfleet and that he is being called to a different path by the Traveler. As tensions rise with Cardassian forces and some colonists refuse to move, a compromise is reached: the colony will remain in place under Cardassian jurisdiction, with Starfleet withdrawing. Wesley chooses to depart with Lakanta/Traveler to explore new dimensions of existence, leaving Starfleet behind.

StorySections.Text: Necheyev arrives with new orders, informing Picard that the Enterprise will help relocate a Federation colony now ceded to Cardassian space.
On Dorvan V, Picard meets Anthwara and other leaders, who calmly but firmly refuse to abandon the land they have imbued with spiritual significance.
Wesley visits the colony and is drawn to Lakanta, who encourages him to question his assumptions about duty and identity as he experiences unusual visions.
Cardassian forces arrive, escalating tensions. Picard is caught between treaty obligations, Starfleet orders, and his understanding of the colonists’ grievances.

A negotiated arrangement allows the Federation colonists to remain under Cardassian authority. Wesley declares his intention to leave Starfleet and departs with the Traveler, guided by Lakanta’s true nature.
Picard and Beverly contemplate Wesley’s unexpected path, while the Enterprise departs, leaving Dorvan V as a symbol of both compromise and unresolved historical echoes.

Title: Firstborn
Antagonists: Assassination plot against Worf by the Duras sisters
Future Alexander's attempt to alter his own timeline through violence
Summary:
Worf worries that his son Alexander shows little interest in Klingon traditions or the path of the warrior. To encourage him, Worf takes Alexander to a Kot'baval festival, where a sudden attack by the Duras sisters is thwarted by a mysterious Klingon calling himself K'mtar, who claims to be a trusted advisor to the House of Mogh.

K'mtar insists that Alexander must embrace the warrior’s path or doom their family’s future. His harsh training methods and obsession with Alexander’s choices raise Picard’s suspicions. Investigation aboard Deep Space 9 and analysis of a unique dagger eventually reveal that K'mtar is in fact Alexander from decades in the future, who has traveled back in time hoping to change his own past—at first even considering killing his younger self. Confronted with the pain behind these choices, Worf accepts that Alexander must find his own way, and the older Alexander, seeing his father’s renewed faith in him, returns to his own era resolved to live with the life he has made.

StorySections.Text: Worf attends a briefing about a Klingon victory commemoration and frets that Alexander remains indifferent to Klingon history and ritual.
At a Kot'baval celebration, Worf and Alexander are attacked by assassins led by the Duras sisters, only to be saved by the formidable Klingon K'mtar.
K'mtar presses Worf to force Alexander into warrior training, criticizing the boy’s gentle nature and Worf’s leniency. Alexander resists, feeling misunderstood.
A dagger used in the attack leads to an investigation involving Quark and others. In the process, inconsistencies in K'mtar’s story and DNA evidence expose him as a future Alexander.
Future Alexander admits he tried to rewrite history to prevent a humiliating adult life. Worf refuses to let his son be defined by anyone’s expectations, insisting that Alexander choose his own path.
Back in the present timeline, Worf and young Alexander practice bat'leth together, their training now grounded in mutual respect rather than fear of the future.

Title: Bloodlines
Antagonists: DaiMon Bok's renewed revenge scheme
Genetic tampering used to fake paternity
Summary:
Ferengi DaiMon Bok, once defeated by Picard at Maxia and later stripped of his command, reappears with a new vendetta. He contacts Picard to announce that he will exact revenge by killing Picard’s "son," Jason Vigo, whom Picard supposedly fathered during a brief relationship decades earlier with a woman named Miranda Vigo. Picard, shocked by the prospect of an unknown child, orders a search for Jason and confronts his own mixed feelings about family and responsibility.

The Enterprise locates Jason living a roguish, independent life as a small-time smuggler. Genetic tests suggest a partial match to Picard, but Crusher and Data discover evidence of sophisticated DNA manipulation, indicating that Bok has altered Jason’s genome to create the illusion of paternity. Bok attempts to abduct and kill Jason using a modified transport system, but Picard and the Enterprise crew thwart the plan. Though Jason is not biologically his son, Picard leaves the door open for a continued connection, while Bok is taken into custody by his own disgruntled crew.

StorySections.Text: Picard receives a transmission from DaiMon Bok, who taunts him with news that he has found Picard’s son and intends to murder him in repayment for his own son’s death.
The Enterprise tracks down Jason Vigo, a skeptical drifter who wants nothing to do with Starfleet or a supposed father he never knew.
Preliminary DNA tests support Bok’s claim, forcing Picard to contemplate sudden, late-in-life parenthood as he and Jason tentatively feel each other out.
Further analysis reveals irregularities in Jason’s genome, exposing the use of genetic engineering to forge a false paternal link. Bok maneuvers to seize Jason with a remote transporter system.
Picard and the crew counter Bok’s attack, rescuing Jason and persuading Bok’s own crew to turn against him. Jason departs to resume his life, now aware of the truth and of Picard’s concern for him.
Reflecting in his ready room, Picard admits to Beverly that meeting Jason has complicated his long-held assumptions about remaining childless, even if their bond is not one of blood.

Title: Emergence
Antagonists: Uncontrolled emergent intelligence in the Enterprise systems
Structural transformations that endanger the ship
Summary:
A routine holodeck mystery aboard the Orient Express is disrupted when bizarre symbols appear and the program begins inserting strange, seemingly unrelated characters and objects. Soon afterward, the Enterprise itself exhibits odd behavior: unexpected course changes, systems rerouting themselves, and geometric structures forming within the ship’s corridors and jeffries tubes. Picard, Data, and Geordi determine that the ship’s computer has begun to generate a new, emergent intelligence from the complexity of its interacting systems.

This nascent consciousness uses the holodeck train scenario as a symbolic workspace to communicate its needs, directing the ship toward a newborn star in order to create a suitable environment for its own "offspring." Though the process threatens the Enterprise with structural damage and loss of control, Picard chooses to help rather than suppress the new lifeform. By allowing the ship to complete the construction and release of a strange, web-like object into the star’s corona, the crew witnesses the birth of a unique form of machine-based life, after which the Enterprise returns to normal.

StorySections.Text: During a holodeck trip on the Orient Express, the characters behave unpredictably and an odd symbol appears, hinting that something is interfering with the program.
The Enterprise begins making inexplicable course corrections and self-initiated system changes, belying simple malfunction.
Geordi and Data trace the anomalies to coordinated patterns in the ship’s computational matrix, suggesting the emergence of a new organizing intelligence.
The holodeck train becomes a metaphorical stage where the emergent mind tests ideas, while physical nodal structures grow inside the ship, threatening its integrity.

Recognizing that the entity is trying to reproduce near a protostar, Picard allows the process to continue, and the Enterprise helps deliver a mysterious construct into the star’s corona before the ship reasserts normal control.
Back on course, Picard and Data speculate about the rarity of such emergent life and whether the newborn intelligence will ever encounter its makers again.

Title: Preemptive Strike
Antagonists: Escalating conflict between the Maquis and Cardassians
Moral pressure on Ro to betray people she comes to respect
Summary:
Recently promoted Lieutenant Ro Laren returns to the Enterprise after advanced tactical training, only to be drawn into a crisis along the Federation–Cardassian border. The Maquis, a resistance movement made up largely of Federation colonists angered by territorial concessions to Cardassia, has stepped up attacks in the Demilitarized Zone. Admiral Necheyev tasks Picard with infiltrating the Maquis using Ro’s Bajoran background and skills, hoping she can win their trust and lead them into a Starfleet trap.

Ro embeds with a Maquis cell led by Macias, a charismatic and paternal figure who reminds her of her own Bajoran past under Cardassian occupation. As she sees Cardassian abuses firsthand and hears the colonists’ stories, her loyalty to Starfleet wavers. When the time comes to spring the trap, Ro instead warns the Maquis and defects to their cause, leaving Picard personally wounded but recognizing that she has acted according to her conscience.

StorySections.Text: Ro Laren returns to the Enterprise to warm congratulations from the crew, only to be immediately briefed on a dangerous assignment in the Demilitarized Zone.
Necheyev and Picard outline Ro’s mission to infiltrate a Maquis cell. Ro reluctantly agrees, aware that her Bajoran history may help her gain their trust.
Ro meets Macias and his comrades, gradually earning their confidence as she witnesses the struggles of colonists caught between Starfleet policies and Cardassian aggression.
Back-channel negotiations and covert plans unfold as Picard and Starfleet prepare an ambush, expecting Ro to help funnel the Maquis into a vulnerable position.
Unable to betray people she now sees as freedom fighters, Ro warns the Maquis and joins them, leaving Picard to face Necheyev with the news that his protégé has turned against Starfleet orders.
In a quiet moment, Picard reflects on his failure to keep Ro in Starfleet, acknowledging to Riker that her decision came from the same moral resolve he once admired in her.

Title: All Good Things..., Part I
Antagonists: Anti-time anomaly forming in the Devron system
Q's renewed trial of humanity
Summary:
Picard begins experiencing sudden, uncontrollable jumps between three time periods: the present; the Enterprise’s very first mission to Farpoint Station; and a future two decades ahead in which he is retired, suffering from a neurological condition, and estranged from much of his former crew. While his friends in each era question his sanity, Picard learns that all three Enterprises are being drawn toward the Devron system, where a mysterious anomaly is forming.

Q appears, revealing that the trial begun in the first encounter with the Q Continuum has never truly ended, and that humanity now stands on the brink of its own destruction. As Picard struggles to coordinate action across three timeframes, he orders simultaneous tachyon scans in the Devron system, hoping to understand the anomaly. Unbeknownst to him, this very act contributes to the creation of a vast "anti-time" rift that threatens to erase life on Earth before it can begin.

StorySections.Text: On the Enterprise-D, Picard suddenly finds himself in the past on the old Stargazer bridge, then in a vineyard in the future, and back again, realizing he is moving randomly through time.

In the present, Picard convinces his skeptical senior staff to consider his time-shifting real. In the past, a younger crew is unsure what to make of their captain’s unfamiliar behavior before the Farpoint mission.
In the future, Picard seeks out his former officers—Data at Cambridge, Beverly commanding the medical ship Pasteur, Riker commanding a diminished Enterprise—to secure a ship for the Devron mission.
Q reveals that humanity is again on trial, blaming Picard for an impending catastrophe. Picard orders synchronized tachyon pulses in all three eras to scan the anomaly in the Devron system.
The tachyon experiment appears to worsen the anomaly. As Romulans and other powers react warily, Picard realizes he must understand the nature of "anti-time" to avert disaster.
Q shows Picard a glimpse of primordial Earth threatened by the growing rift, hinting that the captain himself may be responsible for preventing life on his world from ever emerging.

Title: All Good Things..., Part II
Antagonists: Expanding anti-time rift threatening primordial Earth
Humanity's tendency to misinterpret and exacerbate crises
Summary:
Continuing to jump among three time periods, Picard realizes that the anti-time anomaly in the Devron system is larger in the past and nonexistent in the future, indicating that it is propagating backward through time. He further deduces that the synchronized tachyon pulses he ordered in all three eras are actually causing the rift. Q presses Picard to recognize that only by coordinating all three timeframes can he undo the damage and save humanity’s future.

Picard convinces his crews in each era to fly into the heart of the anomaly and create static warp shells that will collapse it, even though the maneuver appears suicidal. The three Enterprises succeed, erasing the rift and restoring the normal timeline. Back in the present, with the crisis averted and Q satisfied that humanity has taken a step forward, Picard finally joins his senior staff for their regular poker game, symbolically deepening his personal ties with the crew as the series comes to a close.

StorySections.Text: Picard observes that the anomaly is largest in the past and absent in the future, realizing that time itself is flowing differently around the Devron system.
Q guides Picard through images of primordial Earth, revealing that the anti-time rift will prevent the first organic molecules from combining if it is not halted.
In each era, Picard struggles to convince his crews to abandon caution and follow a plan that appears to risk the ship for reasons they largely must take on faith.

The three Enterprises enter the anomaly from different temporal angles, forming matching static warp shells that destabilize and collapse the rift even as each ship is apparently destroyed in its own timeline.
Picard finds himself back in the present on the Enterprise-D, the crisis undone but his memories intact. Q bids him a cryptic, encouraging farewell, insisting that humanity’s journey has only begun.
Picard joins his officers’ longstanding poker game for the first time, shuffling the deck with a smile as the Enterprise heads toward its next, unseen adventures.
